title\n\nAutomotive design\n\nAutomotive design is a set of typically non-professional[1] vocations or occupations involved in the development of the appearance, and to some extent the ergonomics, of motor vehicles or more specifically road vehicles.\n\nThis most commonly refers to automobiles but also refers to motorcycles, trucks, buses, coaches, and vans. The functional design and development of a modern motor vehicle is typically done by a large team from many different disciplines included within automotive engineering however design roles are not associated with requirements for Professional or Chartered Engineer qualifications. Automotive design in this context is primarily concerned with developing the visual appearance or aesthetics of the vehicle, though it is also involved in the creation of the product concept. Automotive design is practiced by designers who may have an art background and a degree in industrial design or transportation design.\n\n1 Design elements\n\n1.1 Exterior design 1.2 Interior design 1.3 Color and trim design\n\n1.4 Graphic design\n\n1.5 Computer-aided styling and Class-A development\n\n2 Development process\n\n2.1 Styling development cycle 2.2 Development team\n\n3 Components 4 History\n\n4.1 U.S. 4.2 Europe 4.2.1 France 4.2.2 Great Britain 4.2.3 Germany\n\n4.2.4 Italy\n\n4.2.5 Scandinavia\n\n4.2.6 Czechoslovakia\n\n5 See also 6 References\n\n7 Further reading\n\n8 External links\n\nDesigners at work in 1961. Standing by the scale model\u0027s left front fender is Richard Teague, an automobile designer at American Motors Corporation (AMC)\n\nContents\n\nDesign elements\n\nThe task of the design team is usually split into three main aspects: exterior design, interior design, and color and trim design. Graphic design is also an aspect of automotive design; this is generally shared amongst the design team as the lead designer sees fit. Design focuses not only on the isolated outer shape of automobile parts, but concentrates on the combination of form and function, starting from the vehicle package.\n\nThe aesthetic value will need to correspond to ergonomic functionality and utility features as well. In particular, vehicular electronic components and parts will give more challenges to automotive designers who are required to update on the latest information and knowledge associated with emerging vehicular gadgetry, particularly dashtop mobile devices, like GPS navigation, satellite radio, HD radio, mobile TV, MP3 players, video playback, and smartphone interfaces. Though not all the new vehicular gadgets are to be designated as factory standard items, some of them may be integral to determining the future course of any specific vehicular models.\n\nThe stylist responsible for the design of the exterior of the vehicle develops the proportions, shape, and surfaces of the vehicle. Exterior design is first done by a series of digital or manual drawings. Progressively, drawings that are more detailed are executed and approved by appropriate layers of management. Clay (industrial plasticine) and or digital models are developed from, and along with the drawings. The data from these models are then used to create a full sized mock-up of the final design (body in white). With three- and five-axis CNC milling machines, the clay model is first designed in a computer program and then \"carved\" using the machine and large amounts of clay. Even in times of high-class 3d software and virtual models on power walls, the clay model is still the most important tool to evaluate the design of a car and therefore used throughout the industry.\n\nThe stylist responsible for the design of the vehicle interior develops the proportions, shape, placement, and surfaces for the instrument panel, seats, door trim panels, headliner, pillar trims, etc. Here the emphasis is on ergonomics and the comfort of the passengers. The procedure here is the same as with exterior design (sketch, digital model and clay model).\n\nThe color and trim (or color and materials) designer is responsible for the research, design, and development of all interior and exterior colors and materials used on a vehicle. These include paints, plastics, fabric designs, leather, grains, carpet, headliner, wood trim, and so on. Color, contrast, texture, and pattern must be carefully combined to give the vehicle a unique interior environment experience. Designers work closely with the exterior and interior designers.\n\nDesigners draw inspiration from other design disciplines such as: industrial design, fashion, home furnishing, architecture, and sometimes product design. Specific research is done into global trends to design for projects two to three model years in the future. Trend boards are created from this research in order to keep track of design influences as they relate to the automotive industry. The designer then uses this information to develop themes and concepts that are then further refined and tested on the vehicle models.\n\nA Bertone Birusa concept car on display at an International Car Show. In the Background are some concept sketches\n\nDraft of OScar design proposal\n\nA futuristic original sketch for Ferrari Modulo 512-S by Paul Martin in 1967. There are already many features of the final concept, including the reduced height, wheels coved for low drag and the characteristic entry system.\n\nExterior design\n\nInterior design\n\nColor and trim design\n\nThe design team also develops graphics for items such as: badges, decals, dials, switches, kick or tread strips, liveries.\n\nThe sketches and rendering are transformed into 3D Digital surface modelling and rendering for real-time evaluation with Math data in initial stages. During the development process succeeding phases will require the 3D model fully developed to meet the aesthetic requirements of a designer and well as all engineering and manufacturing requirements. The fully developed CAS digital model will be re-developed for manufacturing meeting the Class-A surface standards that involves both technical as well as aesthetics. This data will be further developed by Product Engineering team. These modelers usually have a background in Industrial design or sometimes tooling engineering in case of some Class-A modelers. Autodesk Alias and ICEM Surf are the two most widely used software tools for Class-A development.\n\nSeveral manufacturers have slightly varied development cycles for designing an Automobile, but in practice these are the following.\n\nDesign and User Research Concept Development sketching Class A surfaces\n\nClay modeling\n\nInterior Buck Model\n\nVehicle ergonomics\n\nClass A surfaces\n\nColour and Trim\n\nVehicle Graphics\n\nThe design process occurs concurrently with other product Engineers who will be engineering the styling data for meeting performance, manufacturing and safety regulations. From mid-phase, back and forth interactions between the designers and product engineers culminates into a finished product be manufacturing ready.\n\nApart from this the Engineering team parallelly works in the following areas. Product Engineering (Body In White Sheetmetal Design and Plastic engineering), NVH Development team, Prototype development, Powertrain engineering, Physical Vehicle validation, Tool and Die development and Manufacturing process design.\n\nThe styling team for a specific model consists of a chief designer and an Exterior as well as interior designer. In some cases all three roles are done by one designer. Several junior designers are involved in the development process as well who make specific contributions all overseen by the chief designer. Apart from this the Color and trim designer works closely with other designers. The Clay model team and Digital model team works closely with the styling team all located within the studio. Apart from this there would be studio head, studio managers and prototype engineers who would work across all teams in the studio. The total team size for developing a full sedan usually ranges from 25 to 40 members and the development time lasts for more than 24 months till signed-off for tooling and production. Thereafter a smaller team would be working until vehicle launch.\n\nGraphic design\n\nComputer-aided styling and Class-A development\n\nDevelopment process\n\nA 1986 Ford Taurus clay model on display in Ford Detroit Styling Studio\n\nStyling development cycle\n\nDevelopment team\n\nComponents\n\nIntegration of an automobile involves fitting together separate parts to form a monocoque body or units and mounting these onto a frame, the chassis.\n\nAn automobile chassis basically comprises the following:[2]\n\n1. The body shell, which forms the skeleton of the vehicle.\n\n2. The engine, is the power unit of the vehicle; which in the past has been in large part, the internal combustion engine. 3. Transmission system, which aids in transferring the drive from the engine to the wheels. Its main components are the clutch, gearbox, final drive, and differential.\n\n4. Suspension system, which is used to connect the wheels to the body or chassis frame. 5. Steering\n\n6. Brakes\n\n7. Electrical equipment\n\nThe chassis is complete in itself as a road vehicle. It can drive and control itself just as in case of a complete car and therefore, in many motor works, the chassis is usually tested on the road before the complete body of the vehicle is attached as the chassis alone can behave as the propulsion means.[3]\n\nIn the United States, automotive design reached a turning point in the 1920\u0027s when the American national automobile market began reaching saturation. To maintain unit sales, General Motors head Alfred P. Sloan Jr. suggested annual model-year design changes to convince car owners that they needed to buy a new replacement each year, an idea borrowed from the bicycle industry (though Sloan usually gets the credit, or blame).[4] Critics called his strategy planned obsolescence. Sloan preferred the term \"dynamic obsolescence\". This strategy had far-reaching effects on the auto business, the field of product design, and eventually the American economy.\n\nThe smaller automakers could not maintain the pace and expense of yearly restyling. Henry Ford did not like the model-year change because he clung to an engineer\u0027s notions of simplicity, economics of scale, and design integrity. GM surpassed Ford\u0027s sales in 1931, and became the dominant company in the industry thereafter. The frequent design changes also made it necessary to use a body-on- frame rather than the lighter but less adaptable monocoque design used by most European automakers.\n\nSome U.S. designers include Gordon Buehrig, who was responsible for the Auburn 851, as well as the Cord 810 and 812 (hence also the Hupmobile Skylark and the Graham Hollywood).\n\nIn the 1930s, Chrysler\u0027s innovations with aerodynamics helped launch the Chrysler Airflow in 1934, which was revolutionary and radical compared to the contemporary vehicles. However, inadequate consumer acceptance of the advanced appearance of the cars forced a re-design of succeeding models of the Airflow. This marketing experience made the entire industry take note of the high risks involved in incorporating major design advancements into their production cars.\n\nA major influence on American auto styling and marketing was Harley Earl,[5] who brought the tailfin and other aeronautical design references to auto design starting with the rear fenders of the 1948 Cadillac. Another notable designer was Chrysler group\u0027s designer Virgil Exner, who developed the Forward look design in the mid-1950s. Exner is also\n\nHistory\n\nU.S.\n\nAn early example of Sloan\u0027s work, 1939 LaSalle\n\nAn early example of the Forward look design, 1956 Plymouth Fury\n\nA design that was imitated by other automakers, Jeep Cherokee (XJ)\n\ncredited with using wind tunnel testing to justify incorporating tailfins, thus moving the company away from boxy-looking cars into more aerodynamic and futuristic designs. Raymond Loewy was responsible for a number of Studebaker vehicles, including the Starlight (including the bullet-nose).\n\nStarting in the 1960s, Richard A. Teague, who spent most of his career with American Motors Corporation (AMC), originated the concept of using interchangeable body panels so as to create a wide array of different vehicles using the same stampings, starting with the AMC Cavalier.[6] Teague was responsible for unique automotive designs such as the two-seat AMC AMX muscle car, the subcompact Gremlin, the Pacer, and Matador coupe, as well as the original and market segment-creating, Jeep Cherokee (introduced in 1983, and built to 2001 in the U.S. and through 2005 in China).[7][8]\n\nAdditionally during the 1960s, Ford\u0027s first generation Ford Mustang and Thunderbird marked another era leading into new market segments from Detroit. The Ford Mustang achieved record sales in its first year of production and established the pony car segment.\n\nPersonal injury litigation has had an efect on the design and appearance of the car in the 20th century.[9]\n\nUntil World War I, most of the automakers were concerned with mechanical reliability rather than its external appearance. Later, luxury and aesthetics became a demand and also an effective marketing tool. Designs from each nation with its own strong cultural identity, reflected in their exterior and interior designs. World War II slowed the progress, but after the early-1950s, Italian designers set the trend and remained the driving force until the early part of the 1980s.\n\nIn France notable designs came from Bugatti and Avions Voisin. Of the mass selling cars Citroën, launched their vehicles with innovative designs and engineering and mostly aided by the styling of Flaminio Bertoni as evident from Citroën DS.[10] After World War II, with the disappearance of the coach building industry,[11] French automakers (except Citroën) followed British and other popular trends until they gained financial stability. During the 1980s, manufactures like Renault cultivated their own strong design identities with designers like Patrick Le Quement. Peugeot, which was dependent on Pininfarina since early post-war period, later established its own brand identity from the 1980s onwards. Its other company, Citroën, still retains its distinctive French innovations for its designs.\n\nGreat Britain was Europe\u0027s leading manufacturer of automobiles until the late-1960s. During that era there were more British-based automakers than in the rest of Europe combined. The British automobile industry catered to all segments ranging from compact, budget, sports, utility, and luxury-type cars. Car design in Britain was markedly different from other European designs largely because British designers were not influenced by other European art or design movements, as well as the British clay modelers used a diferent sweep set.\n\nBritish cars until World War II were sold in most of the British colonies. Innovations in vehicle packaging and chassis engineering combined with global familiarity with British designs meant vehicles were acceptable to public tastes at that time. British skilled resources like panel beaters, die machinists, and clay modelers were also available also partly due their involvement with motorsport industry.\n\nEurope\n\nAn early radical French Voisin C26\n\nFrance\n\nCitroën DS\n\nGreat Britain\n\n1981 Ford Sierra with \"jelly-mould\" or \"aero look\" (low CD) styling was advanced for its time\n\nStill during the 1960s, British manufacturers sought professional help from the Italians, such as Giovanni Michelotti, Ercole Spada, and Pininfarina. Notable British contributions to automobile designs were Morris Mini by Alec Issigonis, several Jaguar Cars by Sir William Lyons and Malcolm Sayer,[12] Aston Martin DB Series, and several cars from Triumph and MG. Ford Europe based in Great Britain, is notable for the Ford Sierra line, a creation of Uwe Bahnsen, Robert Lutz, and Patrick le Quément. Other British designers were William Towns for Aston Martin cars and David Bache for Land Rover and Range Rover vehicles.\n\nGermany is often considered the birthplace of industrial design with Bauhaus School of Design. However, the Nazi regime closed down the design school. Ferdinand Porsche and his family played a significant role in German design. Mercedes Benz passenger cars were also in luxury segment and played more importance to aesthetics. After the 1980s, German design evolved into a distinctive Teutonic style often to complement their high engineered cars suited to Autobahns. The early German design clues of present-day owes some part to Italian designers like Giovanni Michelotti, Ercole Spada, Bruno Sacco, and Giorgetto Giugiaro. During the mid- and late-20th century one of the most influential coach builder/designer in Germany was Karmann.\n\nGerman designs started gaining popularity after the 1980s, notable after the formation of Audi. Volkswagen, which was dependent on Marcello Gandini, Giorgetto Giugiaro, and Karmann, later formed the contemporary design language along with Audi. BMW entered the automobile design with a sporty-looking everyday sedans using Giovanni Michelotti. These models were later enhanced by Ercole Spada into the 1980s, and Klaus Luthe until the mid-1990s. The American born designer Chris Bangle was hired by BMW in the late-1990s to re-define the brand. Bangle incorporated new single press technology for compound curves to add controversial styling elements to his designs.\n\nThe Porsche family contribution were instrumental in the evolution of Porsche cars, while the Italian designer Bruno Sacco helped create various Mercedes Models from the 1960s to the 1990s.\n\nIn Italy, companies like Fiat and Alfa Romeo played a major role in car design. Many coach builders were dependent on these two major manufacturers. Italian manufacturers had a large presence in motorsports leading to several sport car manufacturers like Ferrari, Lancia, Lamborghini, Maserati, etc. During the late-1950s, Italian automobile designs gained global popularity coinciding with the modern fashion and architecture at that time around the world. Various design and technical schools in Turin turned out designers in large scale. By the late-1960s almost all Italian coach builders transformed into design studios catering to automakers around the world. The trend continued in the 1990s, when the Japanese and Korean manufacturers sourced designs from these styling studios. One example is Pininfarina.\n\nItalian designers whose designs services were sought globally are Giovanni Michelotti, Ercole Spada, Bruno Sacco, Marcello Gandini, Giorgetto Giugiaro, and Walter de Silva.\n\nSweden had Volvo and Saab as domestic automakers, and the nation\u0027s northern location required that cars needed to withstand Nordic climate conditions. The Scandinavian design elements are known for their minimalism and simplicity. One of the early original Scandinavian designs was the Saab 92001 by Sixten Sason and Gunnar Ljungström.\n\nGermany\n\nThe 1972 BMW 2002 by Giovanni Michelotti\n\nItaly\n\nFerrari Testarossa from Pininfarina Studios by Leonardo Fioravanti\n\nScandinavia\n\nPrior to World War II and until the early-1990s, Czechoslovakia had strong presence in the automotive industry with manufacturers like Skoda, Jawa, Tatra, CZ, Praga, and Zetor. Czech automobiles were generally known for their originality in mechanical simplicity and designs were remarkably Bohemian as evident from Tatra cars and Jawa motorcycles. During the Communist regime, design started falling back and ultimately the domestic automakers ended up as subsidiaries of EU-based companies.\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics Automotive Engineering\n\nAutomotive Engineering industrial design\n\nAlternative propulsion Automobile layout Automotive design terminology Coachbuilder Car body style Car classification Car model\n\nCar safety Cab forward Computer-aided\n\nConcept vehicle Dashtop mobile List of automotive designers Ecodesign Facelift (automobile) Virtual tuning H-point Industrial Design Mass production Packages Platform Ponton styling Pre-production car Prototype\n\nSolid freeform fabrication Three-box design Wind tunnel\n\n1. Swales, Neville (21 October 2011). \"Designing the XJ13\" (http://www.xj1 3.eu/XJ13Blog/post/2010/10/22/Designing-the-XJ13.aspx). www.xj13.eu. Retrieved 9 January 2014.\n\nFurther reading\n\nExternal links","no title"],"extracted_metadata":{"publicationdate":"2017-11-06","sha1":"43cc85a62413dd1af1966a434f2dadeaa5d79c0b","filename":"Automotive_design.pdf","file_type":"pdf","title":"no title"},"result_metadata":{"score":0.88477147},"html":"\u003c?xml version\u003d\u00271.0\u0027 encoding\u003d\u0027UTF-8\u0027 standalone\u003d\u0027yes\u0027?\u003e\u003chtml\u003e\n\u003chead\u003e\n    \u003cmeta content\u003d\"text/html; charset\u003dUTF-8\" http-equiv\u003d\"Content-Type\"/\u003e\u003cmeta content\u003d\"2017-11-06\" name\u003d\"publicationdate\"/\u003e\u003ctitle\u003eno title\u003c/title\u003e\u003c/head\u003e\n\u003cbody\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutomotive design\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eAutomotive design\u003c/b\u003e is a set of typically non-\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profession\"\u003eprofessiona\u003c/a\u003el[1] vocations or occupations involved in the development of the appearance, and to some extent the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergonomics\"\u003eergonomics\u003c/a\u003e, of motor vehicles or more specifically road vehicles.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis most commonly refers to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile\"\u003eautomobile\u003c/a\u003es but also refers to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motorcycle\"\u003emotorcycle\u003c/a\u003es,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truck\"\u003etrucks\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus\"\u003ebuses\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coach_(vehicle)\"\u003ecoaches\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van\"\u003evans\u003c/a\u003e. The functional design and development of a modern motor vehicle is typically done by a large team from many different disciplines included within \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_engineering\"\u003eautomotive engineerin\u003c/a\u003eg however design roles are not associated with requirements for Professional or Chartered Engineer qualifications. Automotive design in this context is primarily concerned with developing the visual appearance or aesthetics of the vehicle, though it is also involved in the creation of the product concept. Automotive design is practiced\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_design\"\u003eby designers who may have an art background and a degree in industria\u003c/a\u003el design or transportation design.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e1 Design elements\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e1.1 Exterior design 1.2 Interior design 1.3 Color and trim design\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e1.4 Graphic design\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e1.5 Computer-aided styling and Class-A development\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e2 Development process\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e2.1 Styling development cycle 2.2 Development team\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e3 Components 4 History\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4.1 U.S. 4.2 Europe 4.2.1 France 4.2.2 Great Britain 4.2.3 Germany\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4.2.4 Italy\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4.2.5 Scandinavia\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4.2.6 Czechoslovakia\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e5 See also 6 References\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e7 Further reading\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e8 External links\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eDesigners at work in 1961. Standing by the scale model\u0027s left front fender is\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_A._Teague\"\u003eRichard Teague\u003c/a\u003e, an automobile designer at \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Motors\"\u003eAmerican Motors Corporatio\u003c/a\u003en (AMC)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eContents\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eDesign elements\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe task of the design team is usually split into three main aspects: exterior design, interior design, and color and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trim_package\"\u003etrim\u003c/a\u003e design. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphic_design\"\u003eGraphic design\u003c/a\u003e is also an aspect of automotive design; this is generally shared amongst the design team as the lead designer sees fit. Design focuses not only on the isolated outer shape of automobile parts, but concentrates on the combination of form and function, starting from the vehicle package.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe aesthetic value will need to correspond to ergonomic functionality and utility features as well. In particular, vehicular electronic components and parts will give more challenges to automotive designers who are required to update on the latest information and knowledge associated with emerging vehicular gadgetry, particularly \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dashtop_mobile\"\u003edashtop mobil\u003c/a\u003ee devices, like GPS navigation, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite_radio\"\u003esatellite radi\u003c/a\u003eo, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HD_Radio\"\u003eHD radi\u003c/a\u003eo, mobile TV, MP3 players, video playback, and smartphone interfaces. Though not all the new vehicular gadgets are to be designated as factory standard items, some of them may be integral to determining the future course of any specific vehicular models.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe stylist responsible for the design of the exterior of the vehicle develops the proportions, shape, and surfaces of the vehicle. Exterior design is first done by a series of digital or manual drawings. Progressively, drawings that are more detailed\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clay_(industrial_plasticine)\"\u003eare executed and approved by appropriate layers of management. Clay (industria\u003c/a\u003el plasticine) and or digital models are developed from, and along with the drawings. The data from these models are then used to create a full sized mock-up of the final design (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_in_white\"\u003ebody in white\u003c/a\u003e). With three- and five-axis CNC milling machines, the clay model is first designed in a computer program and then \"carved\" using the machine and large amounts of clay. Even in times of high-class 3d software and virtual models on power walls, the clay model is still the most important tool to evaluate the design of a car and therefore used throughout the industry.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe stylist responsible for the design of the vehicle interior develops the proportions, shape, placement, and surfaces for the instrument panel, seats, door trim panels, headliner, pillar trims, etc. Here the emphasis is on ergonomics and the comfort of the passengers. The procedure here is the same as with exterior design (sketch, digital model and clay model).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe color and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trim_package\"\u003etrim\u003c/a\u003e (or color and materials) designer is responsible for the research, design, and development of all interior and exterior colors and materials used on a vehicle. These include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paint\"\u003epaints\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plastic\"\u003eplastic\u003c/a\u003es, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Textile\"\u003efabric\u003c/a\u003e designs, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leather\"\u003eleathe\u003c/a\u003er, grains, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpet\"\u003ecarpe\u003c/a\u003et, headliner, wood trim, and so on. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color\"\u003eColo\u003c/a\u003er, contrast, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texture_(visual_arts)\"\u003etextur\u003c/a\u003ee, and pattern must be carefully combined to give the vehicle a unique interior environment experience. Designers work closely with the exterior and interior designers.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDesigners draw inspiration from other design disciplines such as: industrial design, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fashion\"\u003efashion\u003c/a\u003e, home furnishing, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture\"\u003earchitectur\u003c/a\u003ee, and sometimes \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Product_design\"\u003eproduct design\u003c/a\u003e. Specific research is done into global trends to design for projects two to three \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_year\"\u003emodel year\u003c/a\u003es in the future. Trend boards are created from this research in order to keep track of design influences as they relate to the automotive industry. The designer then uses this information to develop themes and concepts that are then further refined and tested on the vehicle models.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eA Bertone Birusa concept car on display at an International Car Show. In the Background are some concept sketches\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eDraft of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OScar\"\u003eOScar\u003c/a\u003e design proposal\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrari_Modulo\"\u003eA futuristic original sketch for Ferrar\u003c/a\u003ei Modulo 512-S by Paul Martin in 1967. There are already many features of the final concept, including the reduced height, wheels coved for low drag and the characteristic entry system.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eExterior design\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eInterior design\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eColor and trim design\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe design team also develops graphics for items such as: badges, decals, dials, switches, kick or tread strips, liveries.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe sketches and rendering are transformed into 3D Digital surface modelling and rendering for real-time evaluation with Math data in initial stages. During the development process succeeding phases will require the 3D model fully developed to meet the aesthetic requirements of a designer and well as all engineering and manufacturing requirements. The fully developed CAS digital model will be re-developed for manufacturing meeting the Class-A surface standards that involves both technical as well as aesthetics. This data will be further developed by Product Engineering team. These modelers usually have a background in Industrial design or sometimes tooling engineering in case of some Class-A modelers. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autodesk_Alias\"\u003eAutodesk Alia\u003c/a\u003es and I\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ICEM_Surf\"\u003eCEM Sur\u003c/a\u003ef are the two most widely used software tools for Class-A development.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSeveral manufacturers have slightly varied development cycles for designing an Automobile, but in practice these are the following.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDesign and User Research Concept Development\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sketch_(drawing)\"\u003e sketchin\u003c/a\u003eg\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dCAS_(Computer_Aided_Styling)\u0026amp;action\u003dedit\u0026amp;redlink\u003d1\"\u003eClass A surface\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clay_modeling\"\u003eClay modeling\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eInterior Buck Model\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eVehicle ergonomics\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dClass-A_Surface_Development\u0026amp;action\u003dedit\u0026amp;redlink\u003d1\"\u003eClass A surface\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eColour and Trim\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eVehicle Graphics\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe design process occurs concurrently with other product Engineers who will be engineering the styling data for meeting performance, manufacturing and safety regulations. From mid-phase, back and forth interactions between the designers and product engineers culminates into a finished product be manufacturing ready.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eApart from this the Engineering team parallelly works in the following areas. Product Engineering (Body In White Sheetmetal Design and Plastic engineering), NVH Development team, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prototype\"\u003ePrototyp\u003c/a\u003ee development, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powertrain\"\u003ePowertrai\u003c/a\u003en engineering, Physical Vehicle validation, Tool and Die development and\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Production_line\"\u003e Manufacturing proces\u003c/a\u003es design.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe styling team for a specific model consists of a chief designer and an Exterior as well as interior designer. In some cases all three roles are done by one designer. Several junior designers are involved in the development process as well who make specific contributions all overseen by the chief designer. Apart from this the Color and trim designer works closely with other designers. The Clay model team and Digital model team works closely with the styling team all located within the studio. Apart from this there would be studio head, studio managers and prototype engineers who would work across all teams in the studio. The total team size for developing a full sedan usually ranges from 25 to 40 members and the development time lasts for more than 24 months till signed-off for tooling and production. Thereafter a smaller team would be working until vehicle launch.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eGraphic design\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eComputer-aided styling and Class-A development\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eDevelopment process\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eA 1986 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Taurus\"\u003eFord Taurus\u003c/a\u003e clay model on display in Ford Detroit Styling Studio\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eStyling development cycle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eDevelopment team\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eComponents\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eIntegration of an automobile involves fitting together separate parts to form a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monocoque\"\u003emonocoqu\u003c/a\u003ee body or units and mounting these onto a frame, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chassis\"\u003echassi\u003c/a\u003es.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn automobile chassis basically comprises the following:[2]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e1. The body shell, which forms the skeleton of the vehicle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e2. The engine, is the power unit of the vehicle; which in the past has been in large part, the internal combustion engine. 3. Transmission system, which aids in transferring the drive from the engine to the wheels. Its main components are the clutch, gearbox, final drive, and differential.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4. Suspension system, which is used to connect the wheels to the body or chassis frame. 5. Steering\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e6. Brakes\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7. Electrical equipment\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe chassis is complete in itself as a road vehicle. It can drive and control itself just as in case of a complete car and therefore, in many motor works, the chassis is usually tested on the road before the complete body of the vehicle is attached as the chassis alone can behave as the propulsion means.[3]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the United States, automotive design reached a turning point in the 1920\u0027s when the American national automobile market began reaching saturation. To maintain unit sales, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Motors\"\u003eGeneral Motors\u003c/a\u003e head \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_P._Sloan\"\u003eAlfred P. Sloan Jr.\u003c/a\u003e suggested annual model-year design changes to convince car owners that they needed to buy a new replacement each year, an idea borrowed from the bicycle industry (though Sloan usually gets the credit, or blame).[4] Critics called his strategy \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planned_obsolescence\"\u003eplanned obsolescenc\u003c/a\u003ee. Sloan preferred the term \"dynamic obsolescence\". This strategy had far-reaching effects on the auto business, the field of product design, and eventually the American economy.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe smaller automakers could not maintain the pace and expense of yearly restyling. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Ford\"\u003eHenry Ford\u003c/a\u003e did not like the model-year change because he clung to an engineer\u0027s notions of simplicity, economics of scale, and design integrity. GM surpassed Ford\u0027s sales in 1931, and became the dominant company in the industry\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body-on-frame\"\u003ethereafter. The frequent design changes also made it necessary to use a body-on\u003c/a\u003e- frame rather than the lighter but less adaptable monocoque design used by most European automakers.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome U.S. designers include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Buehrig\"\u003eGordon Buehri\u003c/a\u003eg, who was responsible for the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auburn_Automobile\"\u003eAubur\u003c/a\u003en 851, as well as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cord_Automobile\"\u003eCord\u003c/a\u003e 810 and 812 (hence also the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hupmobile\"\u003eHupmobil\u003c/a\u003ee Skylark and the\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graham-Paige\"\u003eGraham\u003c/a\u003e Hollywood).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the 1930s, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysler\"\u003eChrysler\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s innovations with aerodynamics helped launch the Chrysler Airflow in 1934, which was revolutionary and radical compared to the contemporary vehicles. However, inadequate consumer acceptance of the advanced appearance of the cars forced a re-design of succeeding models of the Airflow. This marketing experience made the entire industry take note of the high risks involved in incorporating major design advancements into their production cars.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA major influence on American auto styling and marketing was \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harley_Earl\"\u003eHarley Earl\u003c/a\u003e,[5] who brought the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_tailfin\"\u003etailfin\u003c/a\u003e and other aeronautical design references to auto design starting with the rear fenders of the 1948 Cadillac. Another notable designer was \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysler\"\u003eChrysle\u003c/a\u003er group\u0027s designer \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgil_Exner\"\u003eVirgil Exne\u003c/a\u003er, who developed the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_look\"\u003eForward loo\u003c/a\u003ek design in the mid-1950s. Exner is also\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eHistory\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eU.S.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn early example of Sloan\u0027s work, 1939 LaSalle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn early example of the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_look\"\u003e Forward loo\u003c/a\u003ek design, 1956 Plymouth Fury\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eA design that was imitated by other automakers, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeep_Cherokee_(XJ)\"\u003eJeep Cherokee (XJ\u003c/a\u003e)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003ecredited with using wind tunnel testing to justify incorporating tailfins, thus moving the company away from boxy-looking cars into more aerodynamic and futuristic designs. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Loewy\"\u003eRaymond Loew\u003c/a\u003ey was responsible for a number of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Studebaker\"\u003eStudebake\u003c/a\u003er vehicles, including the\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Studebaker_Starlight\"\u003eStarligh\u003c/a\u003et (including the bullet-nose).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eStarting in the 1960s, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_A._Teague\"\u003eRichard A. Teague\u003c/a\u003e, who spent most of his career with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Motors\"\u003eAmerican Motors Corporatio\u003c/a\u003en (AMC), originated the concept of using interchangeable body panels so as to create a wide array of different vehicles using the same stampings, starting with the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_Cavalier\"\u003eAMC Cavalie\u003c/a\u003er.[6] Teague was responsible for unique automotive designs such as the two-seat \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_AMX\"\u003eAMC AMX\u003c/a\u003e muscle car, the subcompact \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_Gremlin\"\u003eGremlin\u003c/a\u003e, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_Pacer\"\u003ePacer\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_Matador\"\u003eMatador coup\u003c/a\u003ee, as well as the original and market segment-creating, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeep_Cherokee_(XJ)\"\u003eJeep Cheroke\u003c/a\u003ee (introduced in 1983, and built to 2001 in the U.S. and through 2005 in China).[7][8]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAdditionally during the 1960s, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford\"\u003eFord\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s first generation \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Mustang\"\u003eFord Mustang\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Thunderbird\"\u003eThunderbir\u003c/a\u003ed marked another era leading into new market segments from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit\"\u003eDetroi\u003c/a\u003et. The Ford Mustang achieved record sales in its first year of production and established th\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pony_car\"\u003ee pony ca\u003c/a\u003er segment.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003ePersonal injury litigation has had an e\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eect on the design and appearance of the car in the 20th century.[9]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eUntil \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I\"\u003eWorld War I\u003c/a\u003e, most of the automakers were concerned with mechanical reliability rather than its external appearance. Later, luxury and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aesthetics\"\u003eaesthetic\u003c/a\u003es became a demand and also an effective marketing tool. Designs from each nation with its own strong cultural identity, reflected in their exterior and interior designs. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II\"\u003eWorld War II\n\u003c/a\u003eslowed the progress, but after the early-1950s, Italian designers set the trend and remained the driving force until the early part of the 1980s.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France\"\u003eFranc\u003c/a\u003ee notable designs came from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bugatti\"\u003eBugatti\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avions_Voisin\"\u003eAvions Voisin\u003c/a\u003e. Of the mass selling cars \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn\"\u003eCitroën\u003c/a\u003e, launched their vehicles with innovative designs and engineering and mostly aided by the styling of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flaminio_Bertoni\"\u003eFlaminio Berton\u003c/a\u003ei as evident from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS\"\u003eCitroën DS\u003c/a\u003e.[10] After World War II, with the disappearance of the coach building industry,[11] French automakers (except Citroën) followed British and other popular trends until they gained financial stability. During the 1980s, manufactures like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault\"\u003eRenaul\u003c/a\u003et cultivated their own strong design identities with designers like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patrick_Le_Quement\"\u003ePatrick Le Quemen\u003c/a\u003et.\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot\"\u003ePeugeo\u003c/a\u003et, which was dependent on \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pininfarina\"\u003ePininfarin\u003c/a\u003ea since early post-war period, later established its own brand identity from the 1980s onwards. Its other company, Citroën, still retains its distinctive French innovations for its designs.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGreat Britain was Europe\u0027s leading manufacturer of automobiles until the late-1960s. During that era there were more British-based automakers than in the rest of Europe combined. The British automobile industry catered to all segments ranging from compact, budget, sports, utility, and luxury-type cars. Car design in Britain was markedly different from other European designs largely because British designers were not influenced by other European art or design movements, as well as the British clay modelers used a di\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eerent sweep set.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBritish cars until World War II were sold in most of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Empire\"\u003eBritish colonie\u003c/a\u003es. Innovations in vehicle packaging and chassis engineering combined with global familiarity with British designs meant vehicles were acceptable to public tastes at that time. British skilled resources like panel beaters, die machinists, and clay modelers were also available also partly due their involvement with motorsport industry.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eEurope\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn early radical French Voisin C26\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFrance\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCitroën DS\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eGreat Britain\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e1981 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Sierra\"\u003eFord Sierra\u003c/a\u003e with \"jelly-mould\" or \"aero look\" (low CD) styling was advanced for its time\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003eStill during the 1960s, British manufacturers sought professional help from the Italians, such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Michelotti\"\u003eGiovanni Michelott\u003c/a\u003ei, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ercole_Spada\"\u003eErcole Spad\u003c/a\u003ea, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pininfarina\"\u003ePininfarina\u003c/a\u003e. Notable British contributions to automobile designs were \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morris_Mini\"\u003eMorris Min\u003c/a\u003ei by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alec_Issigonis\"\u003eAlec Issigoni\u003c/a\u003es, several \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaguar_Cars\"\u003eJaguar Cars\u003c/a\u003e by Sir William Lyons and Malcolm Sayer,[12] \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aston_Martin\"\u003eAston Marti\u003c/a\u003en DB Series, and several cars from\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triumph_Motor_Company\"\u003e Triumph\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MG_Cars\"\u003eMG\u003c/a\u003e. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford\"\u003eFord\u003c/a\u003e Europe based in Great Britain, is notable for the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Sierra\"\u003eFord Sierr\u003c/a\u003ea line, a creation of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uwe_Bahnsen\"\u003eUwe Bahnse\u003c/a\u003en, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Lutz_(businessman)\"\u003eRobert Lut\u003c/a\u003ez, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patrick_le_Qu%C3%A9ment\"\u003ePatrick le Quémen\u003c/a\u003et. Other British designers were \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Towns\"\u003eWilliam Towns\u003c/a\u003e for \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aston_Martin\"\u003eAston Martin\u003c/a\u003e cars and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Bache\"\u003eDavid Bach\u003c/a\u003ee for \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_Rover\"\u003eLand Rove\u003c/a\u003er and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Range_Rover\"\u003eRange Rove\u003c/a\u003er vehicles.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGermany is often considered the birthplace of industrial design wit\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bauhaus\"\u003eh Bauhau\u003c/a\u003es School of Design. However, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazi\"\u003eNazi\u003c/a\u003e regime closed down the design school. Ferdinand Porsche and his family played a significant role in German design. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Benz\"\u003eMercedes Benz\n\u003c/a\u003epassenger cars were also in luxury segment and played more importance to aesthetics. After the 1980s, German design evolved into a distinctive Teutonic style often to complement their high engineered cars suited to Autobahns. The early German design clues of present-day owes some part to Italian designers like\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Michelotti\"\u003eGiovanni Michelott\u003c/a\u003ei, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ercole_Spada\"\u003eErcole Spada\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Sacco\"\u003eBruno Sacco\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giorgetto_Giugiaro\"\u003eGiorgetto Giugiar\u003c/a\u003eo. During the mid- and late-20th century one of the most influential coach builder/designer in Germany was Karmann.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGerman designs started gaining popularity after the 1980s, notable after the formation of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi\"\u003eAud\u003c/a\u003ei. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen\"\u003eVolkswage\u003c/a\u003en, which was dependent on\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcello_Gandini\"\u003eMarcello Gandin\u003c/a\u003ei, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giorgetto_Giugiaro\"\u003eGiorgetto Giugiar\u003c/a\u003eo, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karmann\"\u003eKarman\u003c/a\u003en, later formed the contemporary design language along with Audi. BMW entered the automobile design with a sporty-looking everyday sedans using \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Michelotti\"\u003eGiovanni Michelott\u003c/a\u003ei. These models were later enhanced by\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ercole_Spada\"\u003eErcole Spad\u003c/a\u003ea into the 1980s, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dKlaus_Luthe\u0026amp;action\u003dedit\u0026amp;redlink\u003d1\"\u003eKlaus Luth\u003c/a\u003ee until the mid-1990s. The \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States\"\u003eAmerican\u003c/a\u003e born designer \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Bangle\"\u003eChris Bangl\u003c/a\u003ee was hired by BMW in the late-1990s to re-define the brand. Bangle incorporated new single press technology for compound curves to add controversial styling elements to his designs.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche\"\u003ePorsche\u003c/a\u003e family contribution were instrumental in the evolution of Porsche cars, while the Italian designer \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Sacco\"\u003eBruno Sacc\u003c/a\u003eo helped create various Mercedes Models from the 1960s to the 1990s.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Italy, companies like Fiat and Alfa Romeo played a major role in car design. Many coach builders were dependent on these two major manufacturers. Italian manufacturers had a large presence in motorsports leading to several sport car manufacturers like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrari\"\u003eFerrari\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lancia\"\u003eLancia\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lamborghini\"\u003eLamborghini\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maserati\"\u003eMaserati\u003c/a\u003e, etc. During the late-1950s, Italian automobile designs gained global popularity coinciding with the modern fashion and architecture at that time around the world. Various design and technical schools in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turin\"\u003eTurin\u003c/a\u003e turned out designers in large scale. By the late-1960s almost all Italian coach builders transformed into design studios catering to automakers around the world. The trend continued in the 1990s, when the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan\"\u003eJapanes\u003c/a\u003ee and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korea\"\u003eKorean\u003c/a\u003e manufacturers sourced designs from these styling studios. One example i\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pininfarina\"\u003es Pininfarin\u003c/a\u003ea.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eItalian designers whose designs services were sought globally are \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Michelotti\"\u003eGiovanni Michelott\u003c/a\u003ei, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ercole_Spada\"\u003eErcole Spad\u003c/a\u003ea, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Sacco\"\u003eBruno Sacco\u003c/a\u003e, Marcello Gandini, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giorgetto_Giugiaro\"\u003eGiorgetto Giugiar\u003c/a\u003eo, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_de_Silva\"\u003eWalter de Silva\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSweden had Volvo and Saab as domestic automakers, and the nation\u0027s northern location required that cars needed to withstand Nordic climate conditions. The \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scandinavian_design\"\u003eScandinavian design\u003c/a\u003e elements are known for their minimalism and simplicity. One of the early original Scandinavian designs was the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saab_92001\"\u003e Saab 9200\u003c/a\u003e1 by Sixten Sason and Gunnar Ljungström.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eGermany\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Michelotti\"\u003eThe 1972 BMW 2002 by Giovann\u003c/a\u003ei Michelotti\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eItaly\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrari_Testarossa\"\u003eFerrari Testarossa\u003c/a\u003e from Pininfarina Studios by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonardo_Fioravanti_(engineer)\"\u003eLeonardo Fioravant\u003c/a\u003ei\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eScandinavia\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003ePrior to World War II and until the early-1990s, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czechoslovakia\"\u003eCzechoslovaki\u003c/a\u003ea had strong presence in the automotive industry with manufacturers like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%A0koda_Auto\"\u003eSkoda\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawa_Motors\"\u003eJawa\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tatra_(company)\"\u003eTatra\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%8Cesk%C3%A1_zbrojovka_Strakonice\"\u003eCZ\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Praga_(company)\"\u003ePraga\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zetor\"\u003eZetor\u003c/a\u003e. Czech automobiles were generally known for their originality in mechanical simplicity and designs were remarkably \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bohemian\"\u003eBohemia\u003c/a\u003en as evident from Tatra cars and Jawa motorcycles. During the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist\"\u003eCommunis\u003c/a\u003et regime, design started falling back and ultimately the domestic automakers ended up as subsidiaries of EU-based companies.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_aerodynamics\"\u003eAutomotive aerodynamics\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca Engineering\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-aided_industrial_design\"\u003eindustrial desig\u003c/a\u003en\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca layou\u003c/a\u003et\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_design_terminology\"\u003eAutomotive desig\u003c/a\u003en terminology\n\u003ca mode\u003c/a\u003el\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_safety\"\u003eCar safety\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cab_forward\"\u003eCab forwar\u003c/a\u003ed Computer-aided\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concept_vehicle\"\u003eConcept vehicl\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dashtop_mobile\"\u003eDashtop mobil\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automobile_designers\"\u003eList of automotiv\u003c/a\u003ee designers\n\u003ca Retrieved 9 January 2014.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eUrsaab, an early Saab concept illustrating an advanced headlamp treatment\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCzechoslovakia\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe 1934 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czechoslovakian\"\u003eCzechoslovakia\u003c/a\u003en \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tatra_T77\"\u003eTatra T77\n\u003c/a\u003eis the first serial-produced aerodynamically designed\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Ledwinka\"\u003eautomobile designed by Hans Ledwinka and Paul Jaray\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSee also\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eReferences\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eNikolaos Gkikas, ed.
