Wikipedia((R)) is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003e9. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.stanford.edu/dept/anthropology/cgi-bin/web/?q\u003dsystem/files/jain_dangerousinstrumentality.pdf\"\u003eJain, Sarah S. Lochlann (February 2004). \" \u0027Dangerous Instrumentality\u0027: The Bystander as Subject in Automobility\" (http://www.stanford.edu/dep t/anthropology/cgi-bin/web/?q\u003dsystem/files/jain_dangerousinstrumenta\u003c/a\u003elit y.pdf) (PDF). \u003ci\u003eCultural Anthropology\u003c/i\u003e. \u003cb\u003e19\u003c/b\u003e (1): 61-94.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_object_identifier\"\u003edoi\u003c/a\u003e:10.1525/can.2004.19.1.61 (https://doi.org/10.1525%2Fcan.2004.19. 1.61). Retrieved 9 January 2014.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e10. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.autonews.com/article/20110325/BLOG15/303259998/french-car-%E2%80%93-with-italian-ties-%E2%80%93-is-tops-with-6-famous\"\u003ehttp://www.autonews.com/article/20110325/BLOG15/303259998/french\u003c/a\u003e- car-%E2%80%93-with-italian-ties-%E2%80%93-is-tops-with-6-famous 11. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.velocetoday.com/france-vs-italy-coachbuilders/\"\u003ehttp://www.velocetoday.com/france-vs-italy-coachbuilder\u003c/a\u003es/\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e12. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.xj13.eu/XJ13Blog/post/2010/10/22/Designing-the-XJ13.aspx\"\u003eSwales, Neville (21 October 2011). \"Designing the XJ13\" (http://www.xj1 3.eu/XJ13Blog/post/2010/10/22/Designing-the-XJ13.aspx).\n\u003c/a\u003ewww.xj13.eu. Retrieved 9 January 2014.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eFurther reading\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eExternal links\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003c/body\u003e\u003c/html\u003e","id":"b4795a842f58c6f3184601ddf70f4e19","text":"no title\n\nAutomotive design\n\nAutomotive design is a set of typically non-professional[1] vocations or occupations involved in the development of the appearance, and to some extent the ergonomics, of motor vehicles or more specifically road vehicles.\n\nThis most commonly refers to automobiles but also refers to motorcycles, trucks, buses, coaches, and vans. The functional design and development of a modern motor vehicle is typically done by a large team from many different disciplines included within automotive engineering however design roles are not associated with requirements for Professional or Chartered Engineer qualifications. Automotive design in this context is primarily concerned with developing the visual appearance or aesthetics of the vehicle, though it is also involved in the creation of the product concept. Automotive design is practiced by designers who may have an art background and a degree in industrial design or transportation design.\n\n1 Design elements\n\n1.1 Exterior design 1.2 Interior design 1.3 Color and trim design\n\n1.4 Graphic design\n\n1.5 Computer-aided styling and Class-A development\n\n2 Development process\n\n2.1 Styling development cycle 2.2 Development team\n\n3 Components 4 History\n\n4.1 U.S. 4.2 Europe 4.2.1 France 4.2.2 Great Britain 4.2.3 Germany\n\n4.2.4 Italy\n\n4.2.5 Scandinavia\n\n4.2.6 Czechoslovakia\n\n5 See also 6 References\n\n7 Further reading\n\n8 External links\n\nDesigners at work in 1961. Standing by the scale model\u0027s left front fender is Richard Teague, an automobile designer at American Motors Corporation (AMC)\n\nContents\n\nDesign elements\n\nThe task of the design team is usually split into three main aspects: exterior design, interior design, and color and trim design. Graphic design is also an aspect of automotive design; this is generally shared amongst the design team as the lead designer sees fit. Design focuses not only on the isolated outer shape of automobile parts, but concentrates on the combination of form and function, starting from the vehicle package.\n\nThe aesthetic value will need to correspond to ergonomic functionality and utility features as well. In particular, vehicular electronic components and parts will give more challenges to automotive designers who are required to update on the latest information and knowledge associated with emerging vehicular gadgetry, particularly dashtop mobile devices, like GPS navigation, satellite radio, HD radio, mobile TV, MP3 players, video playback, and smartphone interfaces. Though not all the new vehicular gadgets are to be designated as factory standard items, some of them may be integral to determining the future course of any specific vehicular models.\n\nThe stylist responsible for the design of the exterior of the vehicle develops the proportions, shape, and surfaces of the vehicle. Exterior design is first done by a series of digital or manual drawings. Progressively, drawings that are more detailed are executed and approved by appropriate layers of management. Clay (industrial plasticine) and or digital models are developed from, and along with the drawings. The data from these models are then used to create a full sized mock-up of the final design (body in white). With three- and five-axis CNC milling machines, the clay model is first designed in a computer program and then \"carved\" using the machine and large amounts of clay. Even in times of high-class 3d software and virtual models on power walls, the clay model is still the most important tool to evaluate the design of a car and therefore used throughout the industry.\n\nThe stylist responsible for the design of the vehicle interior develops the proportions, shape, placement, and surfaces for the instrument panel, seats, door trim panels, headliner, pillar trims, etc. Here the emphasis is on ergonomics and the comfort of the passengers. The procedure here is the same as with exterior design (sketch, digital model and clay model).\n\nThe color and trim (or color and materials) designer is responsible for the research, design, and development of all interior and exterior colors and materials used on a vehicle. These include paints, plastics, fabric designs, leather, grains, carpet, headliner, wood trim, and so on. Color, contrast, texture, and pattern must be carefully combined to give the vehicle a unique interior environment experience. Designers work closely with the exterior and interior designers.\n\nDesigners draw inspiration from other design disciplines such as: industrial design, fashion, home furnishing, architecture, and sometimes product design. Specific research is done into global trends to design for projects two to three model years in the future. Trend boards are created from this research in order to keep track of design influences as they relate to the automotive industry. The designer then uses this information to develop themes and concepts that are then further refined and tested on the vehicle models.\n\nA Bertone Birusa concept car on display at an International Car Show. In the Background are some concept sketches\n\nDraft of OScar design proposal\n\nA futuristic original sketch for Ferrari Modulo 512-S by Paul Martin in 1967. There are already many features of the final concept, including the reduced height, wheels coved for low drag and the characteristic entry system.\n\nExterior design\n\nInterior design\n\nColor and trim design\n\nThe design team also develops graphics for items such as: badges, decals, dials, switches, kick or tread strips, liveries.\n\nThe sketches and rendering are transformed into 3D Digital surface modelling and rendering for real-time evaluation with Math data in initial stages. During the development process succeeding phases will require the 3D model fully developed to meet the aesthetic requirements of a designer and well as all engineering and manufacturing requirements. The fully developed CAS digital model will be re-developed for manufacturing meeting the Class-A surface standards that involves both technical as well as aesthetics. This data will be further developed by Product Engineering team. These modelers usually have a background in Industrial design or sometimes tooling engineering in case of some Class-A modelers. Autodesk Alias and ICEM Surf are the two most widely used software tools for Class-A development.\n\nSeveral manufacturers have slightly varied development cycles for designing an Automobile, but in practice these are the following.\n\nDesign and User Research Concept Development sketching Class A surfaces\n\nClay modeling\n\nInterior Buck Model\n\nVehicle ergonomics\n\nClass A surfaces\n\nColour and Trim\n\nVehicle Graphics\n\nThe design process occurs concurrently with other product Engineers who will be engineering the styling data for meeting performance, manufacturing and safety regulations. From mid-phase, back and forth interactions between the designers and product engineers culminates into a finished product be manufacturing ready.\n\nApart from this the Engineering team parallelly works in the following areas. Product Engineering (Body In White Sheetmetal Design and Plastic engineering), NVH Development team, Prototype development, Powertrain engineering, Physical Vehicle validation, Tool and Die development and Manufacturing process design.\n\nThe styling team for a specific model consists of a chief designer and an Exterior as well as interior designer. In some cases all three roles are done by one designer. Several junior designers are involved in the development process as well who make specific contributions all overseen by the chief designer. Apart from this the Color and trim designer works closely with other designers. The Clay model team and Digital model team works closely with the styling team all located within the studio. Apart from this there would be studio head, studio managers and prototype engineers who would work across all teams in the studio. The total team size for developing a full sedan usually ranges from 25 to 40 members and the development time lasts for more than 24 months till signed-off for tooling and production. Thereafter a smaller team would be working until vehicle launch.\n\nGraphic design\n\nComputer-aided styling and Class-A development\n\nDevelopment process\n\nA 1986 Ford Taurus clay model on display in Ford Detroit Styling Studio\n\nStyling development cycle\n\nDevelopment team\n\nComponents\n\nIntegration of an automobile involves fitting together separate parts to form a monocoque body or units and mounting these onto a frame, the chassis.\n\nAn automobile chassis basically comprises the following:[2]\n\n1. The body shell, which forms the skeleton of the vehicle.\n\n2. The engine, is the power unit of the vehicle; which in the past has been in large part, the internal combustion engine. 3. Transmission system, which aids in transferring the drive from the engine to the wheels. Its main components are the clutch, gearbox, final drive, and differential.\n\n4. Suspension system, which is used to connect the wheels to the body or chassis frame. 5. Steering\n\n6. Brakes\n\n7. Electrical equipment\n\nThe chassis is complete in itself as a road vehicle. It can drive and control itself just as in case of a complete car and therefore, in many motor works, the chassis is usually tested on the road before the complete body of the vehicle is attached as the chassis alone can behave as the propulsion means.[3]\n\nIn the United States, automotive design reached a turning point in the 1920\u0027s when the American national automobile market began reaching saturation. To maintain unit sales, General Motors head Alfred P. Sloan Jr. suggested annual model-year design changes to convince car owners that they needed to buy a new replacement each year, an idea borrowed from the bicycle industry (though Sloan usually gets the credit, or blame).[4] Critics called his strategy planned obsolescence. Sloan preferred the term \"dynamic obsolescence\". This strategy had far-reaching effects on the auto business, the field of product design, and eventually the American economy.\n\nThe smaller automakers could not maintain the pace and expense of yearly restyling. Henry Ford did not like the model-year change because he clung to an engineer\u0027s notions of simplicity, economics of scale, and design integrity. GM surpassed Ford\u0027s sales in 1931, and became the dominant company in the industry thereafter. The frequent design changes also made it necessary to use a body-on- frame rather than the lighter but less adaptable monocoque design used by most European automakers.\n\nSome U.S. designers include Gordon Buehrig, who was responsible for the Auburn 851, as well as the Cord 810 and 812 (hence also the Hupmobile Skylark and the Graham Hollywood).\n\nIn the 1930s, Chrysler\u0027s innovations with aerodynamics helped launch the Chrysler Airflow in 1934, which was revolutionary and radical compared to the contemporary vehicles. However, inadequate consumer acceptance of the advanced appearance of the cars forced a re-design of succeeding models of the Airflow. This marketing experience made the entire industry take note of the high risks involved in incorporating major design advancements into their production cars.\n\nA major influence on American auto styling and marketing was Harley Earl,[5] who brought the tailfin and other aeronautical design references to auto design starting with the rear fenders of the 1948 Cadillac. Another notable designer was Chrysler group\u0027s designer Virgil Exner, who developed the Forward look design in the mid-1950s. Exner is also\n\nHistory\n\nU.S.\n\nAn early example of Sloan\u0027s work, 1939 LaSalle\n\nAn early example of the Forward look design, 1956 Plymouth Fury\n\nA design that was imitated by other automakers, Jeep Cherokee (XJ)\n\ncredited with using wind tunnel testing to justify incorporating tailfins, thus moving the company away from boxy-looking cars into more aerodynamic and futuristic designs. Raymond Loewy was responsible for a number of Studebaker vehicles, including the Starlight (including the bullet-nose).\n\nStarting in the 1960s, Richard A. Teague, who spent most of his career with American Motors Corporation (AMC), originated the concept of using interchangeable body panels so as to create a wide array of different vehicles using the same stampings, starting with the AMC Cavalier.[6] Teague was responsible for unique automotive designs such as the two-seat AMC AMX muscle car, the subcompact Gremlin, the Pacer, and Matador coupe, as well as the original and market segment-creating, Jeep Cherokee (introduced in 1983, and built to 2001 in the U.S. and through 2005 in China).[7][8]\n\nAdditionally during the 1960s, Ford\u0027s first generation Ford Mustang and Thunderbird marked another era leading into new market segments from Detroit. The Ford Mustang achieved record sales in its first year of production and established the pony car segment.\n\nPersonal injury litigation has had an efect on the design and appearance of the car in the 20th century.[9]\n\nUntil World War I, most of the automakers were concerned with mechanical reliability rather than its external appearance. Later, luxury and aesthetics became a demand and also an effective marketing tool. Designs from each nation with its own strong cultural identity, reflected in their exterior and interior designs. World War II slowed the progress, but after the early-1950s, Italian designers set the trend and remained the driving force until the early part of the 1980s.\n\nIn France notable designs came from Bugatti and Avions Voisin. Of the mass selling cars Citroën, launched their vehicles with innovative designs and engineering and mostly aided by the styling of Flaminio Bertoni as evident from Citroën DS.[10] After World War II, with the disappearance of the coach building industry,[11] French automakers (except Citroën) followed British and other popular trends until they gained financial stability. During the 1980s, manufactures like Renault cultivated their own strong design identities with designers like Patrick Le Quement. Peugeot, which was dependent on Pininfarina since early post-war period, later established its own brand identity from the 1980s onwards. Its other company, Citroën, still retains its distinctive French innovations for its designs.\n\nGreat Britain was Europe\u0027s leading manufacturer of automobiles until the late-1960s. During that era there were more British-based automakers than in the rest of Europe combined. The British automobile industry catered to all segments ranging from compact, budget, sports, utility, and luxury-type cars. Car design in Britain was markedly different from other European designs largely because British designers were not influenced by other European art or design movements, as well as the British clay modelers used a diferent sweep set.\n\nBritish cars until World War II were sold in most of the British colonies. Innovations in vehicle packaging and chassis engineering combined with global familiarity with British designs meant vehicles were acceptable to public tastes at that time. British skilled resources like panel beaters, die machinists, and clay modelers were also available also partly due their involvement with motorsport industry.\n\nEurope\n\nAn early radical French Voisin C26\n\nFrance\n\nCitroën DS\n\nGreat Britain\n\n1981 Ford Sierra with \"jelly-mould\" or \"aero look\" (low CD) styling was advanced for its time\n\nStill during the 1960s, British manufacturers sought professional help from the Italians, such as Giovanni Michelotti, Ercole Spada, and Pininfarina. Notable British contributions to automobile designs were Morris Mini by Alec Issigonis, several Jaguar Cars by Sir William Lyons and Malcolm Sayer,[12] Aston Martin DB Series, and several cars from Triumph and MG. Ford Europe based in Great Britain, is notable for the Ford Sierra line, a creation of Uwe Bahnsen, Robert Lutz, and Patrick le Quément. Other British designers were William Towns for Aston Martin cars and David Bache for Land Rover and Range Rover vehicles.\n\nGermany is often considered the birthplace of industrial design with Bauhaus School of Design. However, the Nazi regime closed down the design school. Ferdinand Porsche and his family played a significant role in German design. Mercedes Benz passenger cars were also in luxury segment and played more importance to aesthetics. After the 1980s, German design evolved into a distinctive Teutonic style often to complement their high engineered cars suited to Autobahns. The early German design clues of present-day owes some part to Italian designers like Giovanni Michelotti, Ercole Spada, Bruno Sacco, and Giorgetto Giugiaro. During the mid- and late-20th century one of the most influential coach builder/designer in Germany was Karmann.\n\nGerman designs started gaining popularity after the 1980s, notable after the formation of Audi. Volkswagen, which was dependent on Marcello Gandini, Giorgetto Giugiaro, and Karmann, later formed the contemporary design language along with Audi. BMW entered the automobile design with a sporty-looking everyday sedans using Giovanni Michelotti. These models were later enhanced by Ercole Spada into the 1980s, and Klaus Luthe until the mid-1990s. The American born designer Chris Bangle was hired by BMW in the late-1990s to re-define the brand. Bangle incorporated new single press technology for compound curves to add controversial styling elements to his designs.\n\nThe Porsche family contribution were instrumental in the evolution of Porsche cars, while the Italian designer Bruno Sacco helped create various Mercedes Models from the 1960s to the 1990s.\n\nIn Italy, companies like Fiat and Alfa Romeo played a major role in car design. Many coach builders were dependent on these two major manufacturers. Italian manufacturers had a large presence in motorsports leading to several sport car manufacturers like Ferrari, Lancia, Lamborghini, Maserati, etc. During the late-1950s, Italian automobile designs gained global popularity coinciding with the modern fashion and architecture at that time around the world. Various design and technical schools in Turin turned out designers in large scale. By the late-1960s almost all Italian coach builders transformed into design studios catering to automakers around the world. The trend continued in the 1990s, when the Japanese and Korean manufacturers sourced designs from these styling studios. One example is Pininfarina.\n\nItalian designers whose designs services were sought globally are Giovanni Michelotti, Ercole Spada, Bruno Sacco, Marcello Gandini, Giorgetto Giugiaro, and Walter de Silva.\n\nSweden had Volvo and Saab as domestic automakers, and the nation\u0027s northern location required that cars needed to withstand Nordic climate conditions. The Scandinavian design elements are known for their minimalism and simplicity. One of the early original Scandinavian designs was the Saab 92001 by Sixten Sason and Gunnar Ljungström.\n\nGermany\n\nThe 1972 BMW 2002 by Giovanni Michelotti\n\nItaly\n\nFerrari Testarossa from Pininfarina Studios by Leonardo Fioravanti\n\nScandinavia\n\nPrior to World War II and until the early-1990s, Czechoslovakia had strong presence in the automotive industry with manufacturers like Skoda, Jawa, Tatra, CZ, Praga, and Zetor. Czech automobiles were generally known for their originality in mechanical simplicity and designs were remarkably Bohemian as evident from Tatra cars and Jawa motorcycles. During the Communist regime, design started falling back and ultimately the domestic automakers ended up as subsidiaries of EU-based companies.\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics Automotive Engineering\n\nAutomotive Engineering industrial design\n\nAlternative propulsion Automobile layout Automotive design terminology Coachbuilder Car body style Car classification Car model\n\nCar safety Cab forward Computer-aided\n\nConcept vehicle Dashtop mobile List of automotive designers Ecodesign Facelift (automobile) Virtual tuning H-point Industrial Design Mass production Packages Platform Ponton styling Pre-production car Prototype\n\nSolid freeform fabrication Three-box design Wind tunnel\n\n1. Stoll J.","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.546311},{"text":"Free body diagram","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.544621},{"text":"Engineering Systems Modelling","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.540875},{"text":"kinematics software","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.524332},{"text":"Roll stiffness","sentiment":{"score":-0.33776,"label":"negative"},"relevance":0.518434},{"text":"loads","sentiment":{"score":-0.554855,"label":"negative"},"relevance":0.517961},{"text":"design load","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.517641},{"text":"vehicle designer","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.514593},{"text":"Roll moment","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.513774},{"text":"automotive engineering","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.511773},{"text":"Caster gain","sentiment":{"score":0.526838,"label":"positive"},"relevance":0.510278},{"text":"Camber gain","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.510181},{"text":"Detailed design","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.508276},{"text":"spring rates","sentiment":{"score":-0.498909,"label":"negative"},"relevance":0.506747},{"text":"Bundorf analysis","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.503823}]},"searchText":["no title\n\nAutomotive suspension design\n\nAutomotive suspension design is an aspect of automotive engineering, concerned with designing the suspension for cars and trucks. Suspension design for other vehicles is similar, though the process may not be as well established.\n\nThe process entails\n\nSelecting appropriate vehicle level targets Selecting a system architecture\n\nChoosing the location of the \u0027hard points\u0027, or theoretical centres of each ball joint or bushing Selecting the rates of the bushings\n\nAnalysing the loads in the suspension Designing the spring rates\n\nDesigning shock absorber characteristics\n\nDesigning the structure of each component so that it is strong, stiff, light, and cheap Analysing the vehicle dynamics of the resulting design\n\nSince the 1990s the use of multibody simulation and finite element software has made this series of tasks more straightforward.\n\n1 Vehicle level targets 2 System architecture 3 Hardpoints\n\n4 Compliance analysis\n\n5 Loads\n\n6 Detailed design of arms\n\n7 References\n\n7.1 Notes 7.2 Sources\n\nA partial list would include:\n\nMaximum steady state lateral acceleration (in understeer mode) Roll stiffness (degrees per g of lateral acceleration)\n\nRide frequencies\n\nLateral load transfer percentage distribution front to rear Roll moment distribution front to rear\n\nRide heights at various states of load Understeer gradient\n\nTurning circle Ackermann Jounce travel Rebound travel\n\nOnce the overall vehicle targets have been identified they can be used to set targets for the two suspensions. For instance, the overall understeer target can be broken down into contributions from each end using a Bundorf analysis.\n\nContents\n\nVehicle level targets\n\nTypically a vehicle designer is operating within a set of constraints. The suspension architecture selected for each end of the vehicle will have to obey those constraints. For both ends of the car this would include the type of spring, location of the spring, and location of the shock absorbers.\n\nFor the front suspension the following need to be considered\n\nThe type of suspension (MacPherson strut or double wishbone suspension) Type of steering actuator (rack and pinion or recirculating ball)\n\nLocation of the steering actuator in front of, or behind, the wheel centre\n\nFor the rear suspension there are many more possible suspension types, in practice.\n\nThe hardpoints control the static settings and the kinematics of the suspension.\n\nThe static settings are\n\nToe Camber Caster\n\nRoll center height at design load Mechanical (or caster) trail Anti-dive and anti-squat Kingpin Inclination\n\nScrub radius\n\nSpring and shock absorber motion ratios\n\nThe kinematics describe how important characteristics change as the suspension moves, typically in roll or steer. They include\n\nBump Steer Roll Steer Tractive Force Steer\n\nBrake Force Steer\n\nCamber gain in roll\n\nCaster gain in roll\n\nRoll centre height gain\n\nAckermann change with steering angle\n\nTrack gain in roll\n\nThe analysis for these parameters can be done graphically, or by CAD, or by the use of kinematics software.\n\nThe compliance of the bushings, the body, and other parts modify the behaviour of the suspension. In general it is difficult to improve the kinematics of a suspension using the bushings, but one example where it does work is the toe control bush used in Twist-beam rear suspensions. More generally, modern cars suspensions include a Noise, vibration, and harshness (NVH) bush. This is designed as the main path for the vibrations and forces that cause road noise and impact noise, and is supposed to be tunable without affecting the kinematics too much.\n\nIn racing cars, bushings tend to be made of harder materials such as brass or delrin.\n\nIn general physical terms, the mass and mechanical hysteresis (damping effect) of solid parts should be accounted for in a dynamic analysis, as well as their elasticity.\n\nSystem architecture\n\nHardpoints\n\nCompliance analysis\n\nOnce the basic geometry is established the loads in each suspension part can be estimated. This can be as simple as deciding what a likely maximum load case is at the contact patch, and then drawing a Free body diagram of each part to work out the forces, or as complex as simulating the behaviour of the suspension over a rough road, and calculating the loads caused. Often loads that have been measured on a similar suspension are used instead - this is the most reliable method.\n\nThe loads and geometry are then used to design the arms and spindle. Inevitably some problems will be found in the course of this that force compromises to be made with the basic geometry of the suspension.\n\nThe Automotive Chassis Engineering Principles - J. Reimpell H. Stoll J. W. Betzler. - ISBN 978-0-7680-0657-5 Race Car Vehicle Dynamics - William F. Milliken and Douglas L. Milliken.\n\nFundamentals of Vehicle Dynamics - Thomas Gillespie.\n\nChassis Design - Principles and Analysis - William F. Milliken and Douglas L. Milliken.\n\nSimulation and direct equations: Abramov, S., Mannan, S., \u0026 Durieux, O. (2009)\u0027Semi-Active Suspension System Simulation Using SIMULINK\u0027. International Journal of Engineering Systems Modelling and Simulation, 1(2/3), 101 - 114 http://collections.crest.ac.uk/232/1/fulltext.pdf\n\nRetrieved from \"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAutomotive_suspension_design\u0026oldid\u003d782585493\"\n\nThis page was last edited on 27 May 2017, at 21:42. This can be as simple as deciding what a likely maximum load case is at the contact patch, and then drawing a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_body_diagram\"\u003eFree body diagram\u003c/a\u003e of each part to work out the forces, or as complex as simulating the behaviour of the suspension over a rough road, and calculating the loads caused. Reimpell H. Stoll J. W. Millike\u003c/a\u003en and Douglas L. Milliken\u003c/a\u003e and Douglas L. Milliken.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSimulation and direct equations: Abramov, S., Mannan, S., \u0026amp; Durieux, O. (2009)\u0027Semi-Active Suspension System Simulation Using SIMULINK\u0027. International Journal of Engineering Systems Modelling and Simulation, 1(2/3), 101 - 114\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://collections.crest.ac.uk/232/1/fulltext.pdf\"\u003ehttp://collections.crest.ac.uk/232/1/fulltext.p\u003c/a\u003edf\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRetrieved from \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAutomotive_suspension_design\u0026amp;oldid\u003d782585493\"\u003ehttps://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAutomotive_suspension_design\u0026amp;oldid\u003d7825854\u003c/a\u003e93\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eThis page was last edited on 27 May 2017, at 21:42.\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eText is available under the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Text_of_Creative_Commons_Attribution-ShareAlike_3.0_Unported_License\"\u003e Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike Licens\u003c/a\u003ee; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Terms_of_Use\"\u003e Terms of Use\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Privacy_policy\"\u003ePrivacy Polic\u003c/a\u003ey. Wikipedia((R)) is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eLoads\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eDetailed design of arms\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eReferences\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eNotes Sources\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003c/body\u003e\u003c/html\u003e","id":"eba85bc4030c4eca0299d66c7ffcfeb7","text":"no title\n\nAutomotive suspension design\n\nAutomotive suspension design is an aspect of automotive engineering, concerned with designing the suspension for cars and trucks. Suspension design for other vehicles is similar, though the process may not be as well established.\n\nThe process entails\n\nSelecting appropriate vehicle level targets Selecting a system architecture\n\nChoosing the location of the \u0027hard points\u0027, or theoretical centres of each ball joint or bushing Selecting the rates of the bushings\n\nAnalysing the loads in the suspension Designing the spring rates\n\nDesigning shock absorber characteristics\n\nDesigning the structure of each component so that it is strong, stiff, light, and cheap Analysing the vehicle dynamics of the resulting design\n\nSince the 1990s the use of multibody simulation and finite element software has made this series of tasks more straightforward.\n\n1 Vehicle level targets 2 System architecture 3 Hardpoints\n\n4 Compliance analysis\n\n5 Loads\n\n6 Detailed design of arms\n\n7 References\n\n7.1 Notes 7.2 Sources\n\nA partial list would include:\n\nMaximum steady state lateral acceleration (in understeer mode) Roll stiffness (degrees per g of lateral acceleration)\n\nRide frequencies\n\nLateral load transfer percentage distribution front to rear Roll moment distribution front to rear\n\nRide heights at various states of load Understeer gradient\n\nTurning circle Ackermann Jounce travel Rebound travel\n\nOnce the overall vehicle targets have been identified they can be used to set targets for the two suspensions. For instance, the overall understeer target can be broken down into contributions from each end using a Bundorf analysis.\n\nContents\n\nVehicle level targets\n\nTypically a vehicle designer is operating within a set of constraints. The suspension architecture selected for each end of the vehicle will have to obey those constraints. For both ends of the car this would include the type of spring, location of the spring, and location of the shock absorbers.\n\nFor the front suspension the following need to be considered\n\nThe type of suspension (MacPherson strut or double wishbone suspension) Type of steering actuator (rack and pinion or recirculating ball)\n\nLocation of the steering actuator in front of, or behind, the wheel centre\n\nFor the rear suspension there are many more possible suspension types, in practice.\n\nThe hardpoints control the static settings and the kinematics of the suspension.\n\nThe static settings are\n\nToe Camber Caster\n\nRoll center height at design load Mechanical (or caster) trail Anti-dive and anti-squat Kingpin Inclination\n\nScrub radius\n\nSpring and shock absorber motion ratios\n\nThe kinematics describe how important characteristics change as the suspension moves, typically in roll or steer. They include\n\nBump Steer Roll Steer Tractive Force Steer\n\nBrake Force Steer\n\nCamber gain in roll\n\nCaster gain in roll\n\nRoll centre height gain\n\nAckermann change with steering angle\n\nTrack gain in roll\n\nThe analysis for these parameters can be done graphically, or by CAD, or by the use of kinematics software.\n\nThe compliance of the bushings, the body, and other parts modify the behaviour of the suspension. In general it is difficult to improve the kinematics of a suspension using the bushings, but one example where it does work is the toe control bush used in Twist-beam rear suspensions. More generally, modern cars suspensions include a Noise, vibration, and harshness (NVH) bush. This is designed as the main path for the vibrations and forces that cause road noise and impact noise, and is supposed to be tunable without affecting the kinematics too much.\n\nIn racing cars, bushings tend to be made of harder materials such as brass or delrin.\n\nIn general physical terms, the mass and mechanical hysteresis (damping effect) of solid parts should be accounted for in a dynamic analysis, as well as their elasticity.\n\nSystem architecture\n\nHardpoints\n\nCompliance analysis\n\nOnce the basic geometry is established the loads in each suspension part can be estimated. This can be as simple as deciding what a likely maximum load case is at the contact patch, and then drawing a Free body diagram of each part to work out the forces, or as complex as simulating the behaviour of the suspension over a rough road, and calculating the loads caused. Often loads that have been measured on a similar suspension are used instead - this is the most reliable method.\n\nThe loads and geometry are then used to design the arms and spindle. Inevitably some problems will be found in the course of this that force compromises to be made with the basic geometry of the suspension.\n\nThe Automotive Chassis Engineering Principles - J. Reimpell H. Stoll J. W. Betzler. - ISBN 978-0-7680-0657-5 Race Car Vehicle Dynamics - William F. Milliken and Douglas L. Milliken.\n\nFundamentals of Vehicle Dynamics - Thomas Gillespie.\n\nChassis Design - Principles and Analysis - William F. Milliken and Douglas L. Milliken.\n\nSimulation and direct equations: Abramov, S., Mannan, S., \u0026 Durieux, O. (2009)\u0027Semi-Active Suspension System Simulation Using SIMULINK\u0027. International Journal of Engineering Systems Modelling and Simulation, 1(2/3), 101 - 114 http://collections.crest.ac.uk/232/1/fulltext.pdf\n\nRetrieved from \"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAutomotive_suspension_design\u0026oldid\u003d782585493\"\n\nThis page was last edited on 27 May 2017, at 21:42. batteries","sentiment":{"score":-0.578035,"label":"negative"},"relevance":0.539293},{"text":"Modern SLI batteries","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.531973},{"text":"Modern car batteries","sentiment":{"score":-0.28025,"label":"negative"},"relevance":0.522381},{"text":"Council International discharge","sentiment":{"score":-0.172342,"label":"negative"},"relevance":0.500554}]},"searchText":["no title\n\nAutomotive battery\n\nAn automotive battery is a rechargeable battery that supplies electrical energy to a motor vehicle. It is also known as an SLI battery (starting-lighting-ignition) [1] and its main purpose is to start the engine. Once the engine is running, power for the car\u0027s electrical systems is supplied by the alternator. Typically, starting discharges less than three per cent of the battery capacity. SLI batteries are designed to release a high burst of current and then be quickly recharged. They are not designed for deep discharge, and a full discharge can reduce the battery\u0027s lifespan.[2]\n\nAs well as starting the engine an SLI battery supplies the extra power necessary when the vehicle\u0027s electrical requirements exceed the supply from the charging system. It is also a stabilizer, evening out potentially damaging voltage spikes.[3] While the engine is running, most of the power is provided by the alternator, which includes a voltage regulator to keep the output between 13.5 and 14.5 V.[4] Modern SLI batteries are lead-acid type, using six series-connected cells to provide a nominal 12 volt system (in most passenger vehicles and light trucks), or twelve cells for a 24 volt system in heavy trucks or earth-moving equipment, for example.[5]\n\nBattery electric vehicles are powered by a high-voltage electric vehicle battery, but they usually have an automotive battery as well, so that they can use standard automotive accessories which are designed to run on 12 V.\n\n1 History 2 Design\n\n3 Use and maintenance\n\n4 Environmental impact\n\n5 See also\n\n6 References\n\n7 External links\n\nEarly cars did not have batteries, as their electrical systems were limited. A bell was used instead of an electric horn, headlights were gas-powered, and the engine was started with a crank. Car batteries became widely used around 1920 as cars became equipped with electric starters. The sealed battery, which did not require refilling, was invented in 1971.[6]\n\nThe first starting and charging systems were designed to be 6-volt and positive-ground systems, with the vehicle\u0027s chassis directly connected to the positive battery terminal.[7] Today, all road vehicles have a negative ground system. The negative battery terminal is connected to the car\u0027s chassis.\n\nA typical 12 V, 40 Ah lead-acid car battery\n\nContents\n\nHistory\n\nThe Hudson Motor Car Company was the first to use a standardized battery in 1918 when they started using Battery Council International batteries. BCI is the organization that sets the dimensional standards for batteries.[8]\n\nCars used a 6 V electrical system, and so had 6 V batteries until the mid-1950s. The changeover from 6 to 12 V happened when bigger engines with higher compression ratios required more electrical power to start.[9] Smaller cars, which required less power to start stayed with 6 V longer, for example the Volkswagen Beetle in the mid-1960s and the Citroën 2CV in 1970.\n\nIn the 1990s a 42V electrical system standard was proposed. It was intended to allow more powerful electrically driven accessories, and lighter automobile wiring harnesses. The availability of higher-efficiency motors, new wiring techniques and digital controls, and a focus on hybrid vehicle systems that use high-voltage starter/generators has largely eliminated the push for switching the main automotive voltages.[10]\n\nLow-maintenance or maintenance-free: In the past, batteries required maintenance in the form of electrolyte refills. Modern batteries retain their fluid for the life of the battery. A weakness of these batteries is that they are very intolerant of a deep discharge, for example when the car battery is completely drained by leaving the lights on. This coats the lead plate electrodes with sulfate deposits and can reduce the battery\u0027s lifespan by a third or more. VRLA: also known as absorbed glass mat (AGM) batteries are more tolerant of deep discharge, but are more expensive.[11]\n\nBatteries are typically made of six galvanic cells in a series circuit. Each cell provides 2.1 volts for a total of 12.6 volts at full charge.[12] Each cell of a lead storage battery consists of alternate plates of lead (cathode) and lead coated with lead dioxide (anode) immersed in an electrolyte of sulfuric acid solution.[13] The actual standard cell potential is obtained from the standard reduction potentials. This causes a chemical reaction that releases electrons, allowing them to flow through conductors to produce electricity. As the battery discharges, the acid of the electrolyte reacts with the materials of the plates, changing their surface to lead sulfate. When the battery is recharged, the chemical reaction is reversed: the lead sulfate reforms into lead dioxide. With the plates restored to their original condition, the process may be repeated.\n\nSome vehicles use other starter batteries. the 2010 Porsche 911 GT3 RS has a lithium-ion battery as an option to save weight.[14] Heavy vehicles may have two batteries in series for a 24 V system or may have series-parallel groups of batteries supplying 24 V.[15]\n\nSpecifications:\n\nPhysical format: batteries are grouped by physical size, type and placement of the terminals, and mounting style.[11] Ampere-hours (A·h) is a unit related to the energy storage capacity of the battery. This rating is required by law in Europe.\n\nCranking amperes (CA): the amount of current a battery can provide at 32 °F (0 °C).\n\nCold cranking amperes (CCA) is the amount of current a battery can provide at 0 °F (−18 °C). Modern cars with computer controlled fuel-injected engines take no more than a few seconds to start and CCA figures are less important than they were in the days of carburetors.[16]\n\nHot cranking amperes (HCA) is the amount of current a battery can provide at 80 °F (26.7 °C). The rating is defined as the current a lead-acid battery at that temperature can deliver for 30 seconds and maintain at least 1.2 volts per cell (7.2 volts for a 12-volt battery).\n\nReserve capacity minutes (RCM) is a battery\u0027s ability to sustain a minimum stated electrical load; it is defined as the time (in minutes) that a lead-acid battery at 80 °F (27 °C) will continuously deliver 25 amperes before its voltage drops below 10.5 volts.\n\nBattery Council International group size (BCI) specifies a battery\u0027s physical dimensions, such as length, width, and height. These groups are determined by the organization.\n\nIn the United States there are codes on batteries to help consumers buy a recently produced one. When batteries are stored, they can start losing their charge. A battery made in October 2015 will have a numeric code of 10-5 or an alphanumeric code of K-5. \"A\" is for January, \"B\" is for February, and so on (the letter \"I\" is skipped).[16]\n\nIn South Africa the code on a battery to indicate production date is part of the casing and cast into the bottom left of the cover. The code is Year and week number. (YYWW) eg. 1336 is for week 36 in the year 2013.\n\nDesign\n\nUse and maintenance\n\nHeat is the primary cause of battery failure as it accelerates corrosion inside the battery.[17]\n\nA vehicle with a flat battery can be jump started by the battery of another vehicle or by a portable battery booster, after which a running engine (but running faster than idle speed) will continue to charge the battery.[18]\n\nCorrosion at the battery terminals can prevent a car from starting due to electrical resistance, which can be prevented by the proper application of dielectric grease.[19]\n\nSulfation occurs when the electrodes become coated with a hard layer of lead sulfate which weakens the battery. It occurs when a battery is not fully charged and remains discharged.[20] Sulfated batteries should be charged slowly to prevent damage.[21]\n\nSLI batteries are not designed for deep discharge, and their life is reduced when subjected to this.[22]\n\nCar batteries using lead-antimony plates require regular topping-up with pure water to replace water lost due to electrolysis and evaporation. By changing the alloying element to calcium, more recent designs have reduced the rate of water loss. Modern car batteries have reduced maintenance requirements, and may not provide caps for addition of water to the cells. Such batteries include extra electrolyte above the plates to allow for losses during the battery life.\n\nSome battery manufacturers include a built-in hydrometer to show the state of charge of the battery.\n\nThe primary wear-out mechanism is the shedding of active material from the battery plates, which accumulates at the bottom of the cells and which may eventually short-circuit the plates. This can be substantially reduced by enclosing one set of plates in plastic separator bags, made from a permeable material. This allows the electrolyte and ions to pass through, but keeps the sludge build up from bridging the plates.\n\nBattery recycling of automotive batteries reduces the need for resources required for manufacture of new batteries, diverts toxic lead from landfills, and prevents risk of improper disposal. Once a lead acid battery ceases to hold a charge, it is deemed a used lead acid battery (ULAB), which is classified as hazardous waste under the Basel Convention. The 12-volt car battery is the most recycled product in the world, according to the United States Environmental Protection Agency. In the U.S. alone, about 100 million auto batteries a year are replaced, and 99 percent of them are turned in for recycling.[23] However the recycling may be done incorrectly in unregulated environments. As part of global waste trade ULABs are shipped from industrialized countries to developing countries for disassembly and recuperation of the contents. About 97 per cent of the lead can be recovered. Pure Earth estimates that over 12 million third world people are affected by lead contamination from ULAB processing.[24]\n\nCar adapter Electric vehicle battery\n\nLead-acid battery Rechargeable battery\n\n1. Negative Ground - Will charger work on positive ground vehicles?\" (http://www.batteryfloatchargers.co m/battery_charging_safety.htm). www.batteryfloatchargers.com. Retrieved 2016-02-18.\n\n8. \"6-Volt Batteries\" (http://www.hemmings.com/magazine/hmn/2006/07/6-Volt-Batteries/1298388.html). www.hemmings.com. Retrieved 2016-02-17.\n\n9. \"6 Volt to 12 Volt Changeover\" (https://www.fillingstation.com/articles/6volt.htm). www.fillingstation.com. Retrieved 2016-02-17.\n\n10. \"Whatever Happened to the 42-Volt Car?\" (http://www.popularmechanics.com/cars/a2198/4226979/). Popular Mechanics. 2009-10-01. Retrieved 2016-02-18.\n\n11. \"How to Get the Right Car Battery\" (http://www.consumerreports.org/cars/how-to-get-the-right-car-battery). Consumer Reports. Retrieved 2016-02-17.\n\n12. \"Basic Battery Care\" (http://www.popularmechanics.com/cars/how-to/a265/1608582/?click\u003dmain_sr). Popular Mechanics. 2006-03-29. Retrieved 2016-02-17.\n\n13. Elert, Glenn. \"Voltage of a Car Battery\" (http://hypertextbook.com/facts/2001/ThiMeaganLe.shtml). hypertextbook.com. Retrieved 2016-02-17.\n\n14. Wert, Ray (2009-08-19). \"2010 Porsche 911 GT3 RS: Track-Ready, Street-Legal And More Power\" (http://jalopnik.co m/5340633/2010-porsche-911-gt3-rs-track+ready-street+legal-and-more-power/gallery/). Jalopnik.com. Archived (htt ps://web.archive.org/web/20091021092447/http://jalopnik.com/5340633/2010-porsche-911-gt3-rs-track%2Bready-str eet%2Blegal-and-more-power/gallery/) from the original on 21 October 2009. Retrieved 2009-09-18.\n\n15. \"Automotive/SLI Batteries - Batteries by Fisher\" (http://batteriesbyfisher.com/automotive-sli-batteries). Batteries by Fisher. Retrieved 24 July 2017.\n\n18. Magliozzi, Tom; Magliozzi, Ray (Apr 1, 2007), \"Is revving the engine a good idea during a jump-start? Find out\" (htt p://www.cartalk.com/content/revving-engine-good-idea-during-jump-start-find-out), Car Talk, Tappet Brothers 19. \"How to Clean Corroded Car Battery Terminals\" (http://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Corroded-Car-Battery-Terminals). wikiHow.\n\n20. \"Description and treatment of sulphated batteries\" (http://www.amperis.com/en/resources/articles/desc-treatment-sul phated-batteries-using-charger-discharger-analyzer/).\n\n21. O. A. Witte (1922). \"The Automotive Storage Battery Its Care and Repair\" (http://www.powerstream.com/1922/batter y_1922_WITTE/batteryfiles/chapter10.htm). PowerStream. Archived (https://web.archive.org/web/20160404141303/ http://www.powerstream.com/1922/battery_1922_WITTE/batteryfiles/chapter10.htm) from the original on April 4, 2016.\n\n22. ChargingChargers, Larry Johnson,. \"Battery Tutorial\" (http://www.chargingchargers.com/tutorials/batteries.html). www.chargingchargers.com. Retrieved 2016-02-15.\n\n23. \"Who Knew? A Car Battery Is the World\u0027s Most Recycled Product\" (http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1044372_ who-knew-a-car-battery-is-the-worlds-most-recycled-product). Green Car Reports. Retrieved 2016-02-18.\n\n24. \"Projects Reports\" (http://www.worstpolluted.org/projects_reports/display/65). www.worstpolluted.org. Retrieved 2016-02-18.\n\nExternal links\n\nRetrieved from \"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAutomotive_battery\u0026oldid\u003d798317914\"\n\nThis page was last edited on 1 September 2017, at 06:05. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Wikipedia((R)) is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization.","no title"],"extracted_metadata":{"publicationdate":"2017-11-06","sha1":"4841668c358ccc5d8b5cdc13aca4d9f468b60925","filename":"Automotive_battery.pdf","file_type":"pdf","title":"no title"},"result_metadata":{"score":0.87811524},"html":"\u003c?xml version\u003d\u00271.0\u0027 encoding\u003d\u0027UTF-8\u0027 standalone\u003d\u0027yes\u0027?\u003e\u003chtml\u003e\n\u003chead\u003e\n    \u003cmeta content\u003d\"text/html; charset\u003dUTF-8\" http-equiv\u003d\"Content-Type\"/\u003e\u003cmeta content\u003d\"2017-11-06\" name\u003d\"publicationdate\"/\u003e\u003ctitle\u003eno title\u003c/title\u003e\u003c/head\u003e\n\u003cbody\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutomotive battery\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn \u003cb\u003eautomotive battery\u003c/b\u003e is a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rechargeable_battery\"\u003erechargeable battery\u003c/a\u003e that supplies electrical energy to a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_vehicle\"\u003emotor vehicl\u003c/a\u003ee. It is also known as an \u003cb\u003eSLI battery\u003c/b\u003e (starting-lighting-ignition) [1] and its main purpose is to start the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine\"\u003eengine\u003c/a\u003e. Once the engine is running, power for the car\u0027s electrical systems is supplied by the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternator\"\u003ealternato\u003c/a\u003er. Typically, starting discharges less than three per cent of the battery capacity. SLI batteries are designed to release a high burst of current and then be quickly recharged. They are not designed for deep discharge, and a full discharge can reduce the battery\u0027s lifespan.[2]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs well as starting the engine an SLI battery supplies the extra power necessary when the vehicle\u0027s electrical requirements exceed the supply from the charging system. It is also a stabilizer, evening out potentially damaging \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltage_spike\"\u003evoltage spike\u003c/a\u003es.[3] While the engine is running, most of the power is provided by the alternator, which includes a\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltage_regulator\"\u003evoltage regulato\u003c/a\u003er to keep the output between 13.5 and 14.5 V.[4] Modern SLI batteries are l\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead%E2%80%93acid_battery\"\u003eead-acid\u003c/a\u003e type, using six series-connected cells to provide a nominal 12 volt system (in most passenger vehicles and light trucks), or twelve cells for a 24 volt system in heavy trucks or earth-moving equipment, for example.[5]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle\"\u003eBattery electric vehicles\u003c/a\u003e are powered by a high-voltage \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_vehicle_battery\"\u003eelectric vehicle battery\u003c/a\u003e, but they usually have an automotive battery as well, so that they can use standard automotive accessories which are designed to run on 12 V.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e1 History 2 Design\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e3 Use and maintenance\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e4 Environmental impact\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e5 See also\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e6 References\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e7 External links\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eEarly cars did not have batteries, as their electrical systems were limited. A bell was used instead of an electric horn, headlights were gas-powered, and the engine was started with a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crank_(mechanism)\"\u003ecrank\u003c/a\u003e. Car batteries became widely used around 1920 as cars became equipped with\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starter_(engine)\"\u003eelectric starter\u003c/a\u003es. The sealed battery, which did not require refilling, was invented in 1971.[6]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe first starting and charging systems were designed to be 6-volt and positive-\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_(electricity)\"\u003eground\u003c/a\u003e systems, with the vehicle\u0027s chassis directly connected to the positive battery terminal.[7] Today, all road vehicles have a negative ground system. The negative battery terminal is connected to the car\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chassis\"\u003echassis\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eA typical 12 V, 40 Ah lead-acid car battery\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eContents\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eHistory\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson_Motor_Car_Company\"\u003eThe Hudson Motor Car Company\u003c/a\u003e was the first to use a standardized battery in 1918 when they started using Battery Council International batteries. BCI is the organization that sets the dimensional standards for batteries.[8]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCars used a 6 V electrical system, and so had 6 V batteries until the mid-1950s. The changeover from 6 to 12 V happened when bigger engines with higher \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compression_ratio\"\u003ecompression rati\u003c/a\u003eos required more electrical power to start.[9] Smaller cars, which required less power to start stayed with 6 V longer, for example the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Beetle\"\u003eVolkswagen Beetl\u003c/a\u003ee in the mid-1960s and the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_2CV\"\u003e Citroën 2C\u003c/a\u003eV in 1970.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the 1990s a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/42-volt_electrical_system\"\u003e42V electrical system\u003c/a\u003e standard was proposed. It was intended to allow more powerful electrically driven accessories, and lighter automobile wiring harnesses. The availability of higher-efficiency motors, new wiring techniques and digital controls, and a focus on hybrid vehicle systems that use high-voltage starter/generators has largely eliminated the push for switching the main automotive voltages.[10]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLow-maintenance or maintenance-free: In the past, batteries required maintenance in the form of electrolyte refills. Modern batteries retain their fluid for the life of the battery. A weakness of these batteries is that they are very intolerant of a deep discharge, for example when the car battery is completely drained by leaving the lights on. This coats the lead plate electrodes with sulfate deposits and can reduce the battery\u0027s lifespan by a third or more.\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VRLA_battery\"\u003eVRLA\u003c/a\u003e: also known as absorbed glass mat (AGM) batteries are more tolerant of deep discharge, but are more expensive.[11]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBatteries are typically made of six \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galvanic_cell\"\u003egalvanic cells\u003c/a\u003e in a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Series_circuits\"\u003eseries circuit\u003c/a\u003e. Each cell provides 2.1 volts for a total of 12.6 volts at full charge.[12] Each cell of a lead storage battery consists of alternate plates of lead (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cathode\"\u003ecathode\u003c/a\u003e) and lead coated with lead dioxide (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anode\"\u003eanode\u003c/a\u003e) immersed in an \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrolyte\"\u003eelectrolyt\u003c/a\u003ee of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sulfuric_acid\"\u003esulfuric acid\u003c/a\u003e solution.[13] The actual standard cell potential is obtained from the standard reduction potentials. This causes a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_reaction\"\u003echemical reactio\u003c/a\u003en that releases \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrons\"\u003eelectron\u003c/a\u003es, allowing them to flow through \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_conductor\"\u003econductor\u003c/a\u003es to produce \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity\"\u003eelectricit\u003c/a\u003ey. As the battery \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_capacity\"\u003edischarges\u003c/a\u003e, the acid of the electrolyte reacts with the materials of the plates, changing their surface to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead(II)_sulfate\"\u003elead sulfat\u003c/a\u003ee. When the battery is\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rechargeable_battery#Charging\"\u003e recharged\u003c/a\u003e, the chemical reaction is reversed: the lead sulfate reforms into lead dioxide. With the plates restored to their original condition, the process may be repeated.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome vehicles use other starter batteries. the 2010 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_911_GT3_RS\"\u003ePorsche 911 GT3 RS\u003c/a\u003e has a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery\"\u003elithium-ion batter\u003c/a\u003ey as an option to save weight.[14] Heavy vehicles may have two batteries in\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Series_and_parallel_circuits\"\u003e serie\u003c/a\u003es for a 24 V system or may have series-parallel groups of batteries supplying 24 V.[15]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpecifications:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003ePhysical format: batteries are grouped by physical size, type and placement of the terminals, and mounting style.[11]\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ampere-hour\"\u003eAmpere-hour\u003c/a\u003es (A·h) is a unit related to the energy storage capacity of the battery. This rating is required by law in Europe.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCranking amperes (CA): the amount of current a battery can provide at 32 °F (0 °C).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCold cranking amperes (CCA) is the amount of current a battery can provide at 0 °F (−18 °C). Modern cars with computer controlled\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_injection\"\u003e fuel-injecte\u003c/a\u003ed engines take no more than a few seconds to start and CCA figures are less important than they were in the days of\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carburetor\"\u003e carburetor\u003c/a\u003es.[16]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eHot cranking amperes (HCA) is the amount of current a battery can provide at 80 °F (26.7 °C). The rating is defined as the current a lead-acid battery at that temperature can deliver for 30 seconds and maintain at least 1.2 volts per cell (7.2 volts for a 12-volt battery).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eReserve capacity minutes (RCM) is a battery\u0027s ability to sustain a minimum stated electrical load; it is defined as the time (in minutes) that a lead-acid battery at 80 °F (27 °C) will continuously deliver 25 amperes before its voltage drops below 10.5 volts.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eBattery Council International group size\u003c/i\u003e (BCI) specifies a battery\u0027s physical dimensions, such as length, width, and height. These groups are determined by the organization.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the United States there are codes on batteries to help consumers buy a recently produced one. When batteries are stored, they can start losing their charge. A battery made in October 2015 will have a numeric code of 10-5 or an alphanumeric code of K-5. \"A\" is for January, \"B\" is for February, and so on (the letter \"I\" is skipped).[16]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn South Africa the code on a battery to indicate production date is part of the casing and cast into the bottom left of the cover. The code is Year and week number. (YYWW) eg. 1336 is for week 36 in the year 2013.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eDesign\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eUse and maintenance\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eHeat is the primary cause of battery failure as it accelerates corrosion inside the battery.[17]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA vehicle with a flat battery can be \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jump_start_(internal_combustion_engine)\"\u003ejump started\u003c/a\u003e by the battery of another vehicle or by a portable battery booster, after which a running engine (but running faster than\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idle_speed\"\u003e idle speed\u003c/a\u003e) will continue to charge the battery.[18]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCorrosion at the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_terminals\"\u003ebattery terminal\u003c/a\u003es can prevent a car from starting due to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_resistance\"\u003eelectrical resistanc\u003c/a\u003ee, which can be prevented by the proper application of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicone_grease#Dielectric_grease\"\u003edielectric greas\u003c/a\u003ee.[19]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSulfation occurs when the electrodes become coated with a hard layer of lead sulfate which weakens the battery. It occurs when a battery is not fully charged and remains discharged.[20] Sulfated batteries should be charged slowly to prevent damage.[21]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSLI batteries are not designed for deep discharge, and their life is reduced when subjected to this.[22]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCar batteries using lead-antimony plates require regular topping-up with pure water to replace water lost due to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrolysis\"\u003eelectrolysi\u003c/a\u003es and evaporation. By changing the alloying element to calcium, more recent designs have reduced the rate of water loss. Modern car batteries have reduced maintenance requirements, and may not provide caps for addition of water to the cells. Such batteries include extra electrolyte above the plates to allow for losses during the battery life.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome battery manufacturers include a built-in\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrometer\"\u003e hydromete\u003c/a\u003er to show the state of charge of the battery.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe primary wear-out mechanism is the shedding of active material from the battery plates, which accumulates at the bottom of the cells and which may eventually short-circuit the plates. This can be substantially reduced by enclosing one set of plates in plastic separator bags, made from a permeable material. This allows the electrolyte and ions to pass through, but keeps the sludge build up from bridging the plates.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_recycling\"\u003eBattery recyclin\u003c/a\u003eg of automotive batteries reduces the need for resources required for manufacture of new batteries, diverts toxic lead from landfills, and prevents risk of improper disposal. Once a lead acid battery ceases to hold a charge, it is deemed a used lead acid battery (ULAB), which is classified as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazardous_waste\"\u003ehazardous waste\u003c/a\u003e under the\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basel_Convention\"\u003eBasel Conventio\u003c/a\u003en. The 12-volt car battery is the most recycled product in the world, according to the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency\"\u003eUnited States Environmental Protection Agency\u003c/a\u003e. In the U.S. alone, about 100 million auto batteries a year are replaced, and 99 percent of them are\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_waste_trade\"\u003eturned in for recycling.[23] However the recycling may be done incorrectly in unregulated environments. As part of global waste trade ULABs are shipped from industrialized countries to developing countries for disassembly and recuperation of the contents\u003c/a\u003e. About 97 per cent of the lead can be recovered. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pure_Earth\"\u003ePure Earth\u003c/a\u003e estimates that over 12 million t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_World\"\u003ehird world\u003c/a\u003e people are affected by lead contamination from ULAB processing.[24]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cigarette_lighter_receptacle\"\u003eCar adapte\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_vehicle_battery\"\u003eElectric vehicle batter\u003c/a\u003ey\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead-acid_battery\"\u003eLead-acid batter\u003c/a\u003ey\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rechargeable_battery\"\u003eRechargeable batter\u003c/a\u003ey\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e1. Joey Jung, Lei Zhang, Jiujun Zhang (ed), \u003ci\u003eLead-Acid Battery Technologies: Fundamentals, Materials, and Applications\u003c/i\u003e, CRC Press, 2015 I\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number\"\u003eSBN\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/1466592230\"\u003e146659223\u003c/a\u003e0, page 39\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e2. Johnson, Larry. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.chargingchargers.com/tutorials/batteries.html\"\u003e\"Battery Tutorial\" (http://www.chargingchargers.com/tutorials/batteries.html\u003c/a\u003e). \u003ci\u003echargingchargers.com\u003c/i\u003e. Charging Chargers. Retrieved 2016-02-15.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e3. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://aboutbatteries.batterycouncil.org/What-is-a-lead-battery\"\u003e\"What is a lead battery?\" (http://aboutbatteries.batterycouncil.org/What-is-a-lead-batter\u003c/a\u003ey). \u003ci\u003ebatterycouncil.org\u003c/i\u003e. Retrieved 2016-02-17.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eA positive (red) jumper cable connected to battery post. An optional hydrometer window is visible by the single jumper clamp. Find out\" (htt p://www.cartalk.com/content/revving-engine-good-idea-during-jump-start-find-out), \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_Talk\"\u003e\u003ci\u003eCar Talk\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, Tappet Brothers 19. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Corroded-Car-Battery-Terminals\"\u003e\"How to Clean Corroded Car Battery Terminals\" (http://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Corroded-Car-Battery-Terminals\u003c/a\u003e).\n\u003ci\u003ewikiHow\u003c/i\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e20. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.amperis.com/en/resources/articles/desc-treatment-sulphated-batteries-using-charger-discharger-analyzer/\"\u003e\"Description and treatment of sulphated batteries\" (http://www.amperis.com/en/resources/articles/desc-treatment-su\u003c/a\u003el phated-batteries-using-charger-discharger-analyzer/).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e21. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.powerstream.com/1922/battery_1922_WITTE/batteryfiles/chapter10.htm\"\u003eO. Retrieved 2016-02-15.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e23. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1044372_who-knew-a-car-battery-is-the-worlds-most-recycled-product\"\u003e\"Who Knew?
