Benz\u003c/a\u003e[1]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eCar\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u003cb\u003ecar\u003c/b\u003e (or \u003cb\u003eautomobile\u003c/b\u003e) is a wheeled \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_vehicle\"\u003emotor vehicle\u003c/a\u003e used for\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transportation\"\u003etransportatio\u003c/a\u003en. Most definitions of \u003ci\u003ecar\u003c/i\u003e say they run primarily on roads, seat one to eight people, have four \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyre_(wheel)\"\u003etire\u003c/a\u003es, and mainly transport people rather than goods.[2][3] Cars came into global use during the 20th century, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developed_country\"\u003edeveloped economie\u003c/a\u003es depend on them. The year 1886 is regarded as the birth year of the modern car, when German inventor\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Benz\"\u003eKarl Benz\u003c/a\u003e built his \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benz_Patent-Motorwagen\"\u003eBenz Patent-Motorwage\u003c/a\u003en. Cars did not become widely available until the early 20th century. One of the first cars that was accessible to the masses was the 1908 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Model_T\"\u003eModel T\u003c/a\u003e, an American car manufactured by the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company\"\u003eFord Motor Compan\u003c/a\u003ey. Cars were rapidly adopted in the US, where they replaced \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_animal\"\u003eanimal-drawn\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carriage\"\u003ecarriage\u003c/a\u003es and carts, but took much longer to be accepted in Western Europe and other parts of the world.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCars have controls for driving, parking, passenger comfort and safety, and controlling a variety of lights. Over the decades, additional features and controls have been added to vehicles, making them progressively more complex. Examples include rear reversing cameras, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile_air_conditioning\"\u003eair conditioning\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_navigation_system\"\u003enavigation systems\u003c/a\u003e, and in car entertainment. Most cars in use in the 2010s are propelled by an\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine\"\u003einternal combustion engine\u003c/a\u003e, fueled by the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combustion\"\u003ecombustio\u003c/a\u003en of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fossil_fuel\"\u003efossil fuels\u003c/a\u003e. This causes \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_pollution\"\u003eair pollutio\u003c/a\u003en and is also blamed for contributing to climate change and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_warming\"\u003eglobal warmin\u003c/a\u003eg.[4] Vehicles using \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_fuel\"\u003ealternative fuel\u003c/a\u003es such as\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethanol_fuel\"\u003eethano\u003c/a\u003el \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flexible-fuel_vehicle\"\u003eflexible-fuel vehicle\u003c/a\u003es and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_gas_vehicle\"\u003enatural gas vehicle\u003c/a\u003es are also gaining popularity in some countries. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_car\"\u003eElectric car\u003c/a\u003es, which were invented early in the history of the car, began to become commercially available in 2008.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThere are costs and benefits to car use. The costs include acquiring the vehicle, interest payments (if the car is financed), repairs and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auto_maintenance\"\u003emaintenanc\u003c/a\u003ee, fuel, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Depreciation\"\u003edepreciation\u003c/a\u003e, driving time, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parking_fee\"\u003eparking fees\u003c/a\u003e, taxes, and insurance.[5] The costs to society include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maintaining_road\"\u003emaintaining road\u003c/a\u003es, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_use\"\u003eland use\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road_congestion\"\u003eroad congestion\u003c/a\u003e, air pollution, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_health\"\u003epublic health\u003c/a\u003e, health care, and disposing of the vehicle at the end of its life. Road traffic accidents are the largest cause of injury-related deaths worldwide.[6]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe benefits include on-demand transportation, mobility, independence, and convenience.[7] The societal benefits include economic benefits, such as job and wealth creation from the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry\"\u003eautomotive industr\u003c/a\u003ey, transportation provision, societal well-being from leisure and travel opportunities, and revenue generation from the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Vehicle_taxes\"\u003etaxes\u003c/a\u003e. The ability for people to move flexibly from place to place has far-reaching implications for the nature of societies.[8] It was estimated in 2014 that the number of cars was over 1.25 billion vehicles,[9] up from the 500 million of 1986.[10] The numbers are increasing rapidly, especially in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_China\"\u003eChina\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_India\"\u003eIndia\u003c/a\u003e and other newly industrialized countries.[11]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e1 Etymology 2 History\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eContents\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e3 Mass production\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e4 Fuel and propulsion technologies\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e5 User interface\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e6 Lighting\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e7 Weight\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e8 Seating and body style\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e9 Safety\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e10 Costs and benefits\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e11 Environmental impact\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e12 Emerging car technologies\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e12.1 Autonomous car 12.2 Open source development\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e13 Industry 14 Alternatives 15 Other meanings\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e16 See also\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e17 References\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e18 Further reading\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e19 External links\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe word \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003ecar\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e is believed to originate from the Latin word \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003ecarrus\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e or \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003ecarrum\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e (\"wheeled vehicle\"), or the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_English\"\u003eMiddle English\u003c/a\u003e word \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003ecarre\n\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e(meaning \"two-wheel \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cart\"\u003ecart\u003c/a\u003e\", from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language\"\u003eOld North Frenc\u003c/a\u003eh). In turn, these originated from the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaulish_language\"\u003eGaulish\u003c/a\u003e word \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003ekarros\u003c/i\u003e (a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauls\"\u003eGallic\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chariot\"\u003echario\u003c/a\u003et).[12][13] It originally referred to any wheeled \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse-drawn_vehicle\"\u003ehorse-drawn vehicle\u003c/a\u003e, such as a cart, carriage, or wagon.[14][15] \"Motor car\" is attested from 1895, and is the usual formal name for cars in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_English\"\u003eBritish Englis\u003c/a\u003eh.[3] \"Autocar\" is a variant that is also attested from 1895, but that is now considered archaic. It literally means \"self-propelled car\".[16] The term \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horseless_carriage\"\u003ehorseless carriag\u003c/a\u003ee\" was used by some to refer to the first cars at the time that they were being built, and is attested from 1895.[17]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe word \"automobile\" is a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_compound\"\u003eclassical compoun\u003c/a\u003ed derived from the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek\"\u003eAncient Gree\u003c/a\u003ek word \u003ci\u003eautós\u003c/i\u003e (αὐτός), meaning \"self\", and the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_language\"\u003eLatin\n\u003c/a\u003eword \u003ci\u003emobilis\u003c/i\u003e, meaning \"movable\". It entered the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language\"\u003eEnglish languag\u003c/a\u003ee from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language\"\u003eFrenc\u003c/a\u003eh, and was first adopted by the Automobile Club of Great Britain in 1897.[18] Over time, the word \"automobile\" fell out of favour in Britain, and was replaced by \"motor car\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\"Automobile\" remains chiefly North American, particularly as a formal or commercial term.[19] An abbreviated form, \"auto\", was formerly a common way to refer to cars in English, but is now considered old-fashioned. The word is still very common as an adjective in American English, usually in compound formations like \"auto industry\" and \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auto_mechanic\"\u003eauto mechani\u003c/a\u003ec\".[20][21] The abbreviated form is also used in\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_language\"\u003e Dutch\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language\"\u003eGerman\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe first working steam-powered vehicle was designed-and most likely built-by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_Verbiest\"\u003eFerdinand Verbies\u003c/a\u003et, a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flemish_people\"\u003eFlemish\u003c/a\u003e member of a Jesuit mission in China around 1672. It was a 65-cm-long scale-model toy for the Chinese Emperor that was unable to carry a driver or a passenger.[7][22][23] It is not known if Verbiest\u0027s model was ever built.[23]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolas-Joseph_Cugnot\"\u003eNicolas-Joseph Cugno\u003c/a\u003et is widely credited with building the first full-scale, self-propelled mechanical vehicle or car in about 1769; he created a steam-powered tricycle.[24] He also constructed two steam tractors for the French Army, one of which is preserved in the\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservatoire_National_des_Arts_et_M%C3%A9tiers\"\u003eFrench National Conservatory of Arts and Crafts\u003c/a\u003e.[25] His inventions were, however, handicapped by problems with water supply and\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e[25]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eEtymology\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eHistory\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003emaintaining steam pressure.[25] In 1801, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Trevithick\"\u003eRichard Trevithic\u003c/a\u003ek built and demonstrated his \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Puffing_Devil\"\u003ePuffing Devi\u003c/a\u003el road locomotive, believed by many to be the first demonstration of a steam-powered road vehicle. It was unable to maintain sufficient steam pressure for long periods, and was of little practical use.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_car\"\u003eThe development of external combustion engines is detailed as part of the history o\u003c/a\u003ef the car, but often treated separately from the development of true cars. A variety of steam-powered road vehicles were used during the first part of the 19th century, including \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steam_car\"\u003esteam cars\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steam_bus\"\u003esteam buses\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phaeton_(carriage)\"\u003ephaetons\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steam_roller\"\u003esteam rollers\u003c/a\u003e. Sentiment against them led to the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locomotive_Acts\"\u003eLocomotive Act\u003c/a\u003es of 1865.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1807, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nic%C3%A9phore_Ni%C3%A9pce\"\u003eNicéphore Niépce\u003c/a\u003e and his brother Claude created what was probably the world\u0027s first \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine\"\u003einternal combustion engin\u003c/a\u003ee (which they called a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyr%C3%A9olophore\"\u003ePyréolophor\u003c/a\u003ee), but they chose to install it in a boat on the river \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saone\"\u003eSaone\u003c/a\u003e in France.[26] Coincidentally, in 1807 the Swiss inventor \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Isaac_de_Rivaz\"\u003eFrançois Isaac de Riva\u003c/a\u003ez designed his own \u0027de Rivaz internal combustion engine\u0027 and used it to develop the world\u0027s first vehicle to be powered by such an engine. The Niépces\u0027 Pyréolophore was fuelled by a mixture of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lycopodium_powder\"\u003eLycopodium powde\u003c/a\u003er (dried spores of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lycopodium\"\u003eLycopodium\u003c/a\u003e plant), finely crushed coal dust and resin that were mixed with oil, whereas de Rivaz used a mixture of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen\"\u003ehydroge\u003c/a\u003en and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxygen\"\u003eoxyge\u003c/a\u003en.[26] Neither design was very successful, as was the case with others, such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Brown_(engineer)\"\u003eSamuel Brown\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Morey\"\u003eSamuel More\u003c/a\u003ey, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etienne_Lenoir\"\u003eEtienne Lenoi\u003c/a\u003er with his \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hippomobile_(car)\"\u003ehippomobil\u003c/a\u003ee, who each produced vehicles (usually adapted carriages or carts) powered by internal combustion engines.[1]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustave_Trouv%C3%A9\"\u003eIn November 1881, French inventor Gustave Trouvé demonstrated the first working (three\u003c/a\u003e- wheeled) car powered by electricity at the\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Exposition_of_Electricity,_Paris\"\u003eInternational Exposition of Electricity, Paris.[27] Although several other Germa\u003c/a\u003en engineers (including \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottlieb_Daimler\"\u003eGottlieb Daimler\u003c/a\u003e,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Maybach\"\u003eWilhelm Maybac\u003c/a\u003eh, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siegfried_Marcus\"\u003eSiegfried Marcu\u003c/a\u003es) were working on the problem at about the same time, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Benz\"\u003eKarl Ben\u003c/a\u003ez generally is acknowledged as the inventor of the modern car.[1]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1879, Benz was granted a patent for his first engine, which had been designed in 1878. Many of his other inventions made the use of the internal combustion engine feasible for powering a vehicle. His first \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benz_Patent_Motorwagen\"\u003e\u003ci\u003eMotorwage\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003ci\u003en\u003c/i\u003e was built in 1885 in\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mannheim\"\u003eMannheim\u003c/a\u003e, Germany. He was awarded the patent for its invention as of his\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benz_%26_Cie.\"\u003eapplication on 29 January 1886 (under the auspices of his major company, Benz \u0026amp; Cie., which was founded in 1883). Benz began promotion of the vehicle on 3 July\n\u003c/a\u003e1886, and about 25 Benz vehicles were sold between 1888 and 1893, when his first four-wheeler was introduced along with a model intended for affordability. They also were powered with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-stroke_cycle\"\u003efour-stroke\u003c/a\u003e engines of his own design. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dEmile_Roger\u0026amp;action\u003dedit\u0026amp;redlink\u003d1\"\u003eEmile Roge\u003c/a\u003er of France, already producing Benz engines under license, now added the Benz car to his line of products. Because France was more open to the early cars, initially more were built and sold in France through Roger than Benz sold in Germany. In August 1888 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertha_Benz\"\u003eBertha Benz\u003c/a\u003e, the wife of Karl Benz, undertook the first \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road_trip\"\u003eroad trip\u003c/a\u003e by car, to prove the road-worthiness of her husband\u0027s invention.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eCugnot\u0027s 1771 \u003ci\u003efardier à vapeur\u003c/i\u003e, as\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_des_Arts_et_M%C3%A9tiers\"\u003epreserved at the Musée des Arts e\u003c/a\u003et Métiers, Paris\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustave_Trouv%C3%A9\"\u003eGustave Trouvé\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s tricycle, the first ever electric automobile to be shown in public\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Benz\"\u003eKarl Benz\u003c/a\u003e, the inventor of the modern car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benz_Patent-Motorwagen\"\u003eThe original Benz Patent\u003c/a\u003e- Motorwagen, first built in 1885 and awarded the patent for the concept\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1896, Benz designed and patented the first internal-combustion \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flat_engine\"\u003eflat engin\u003c/a\u003ee, called\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eboxermotor\u003c/i\u003e. During the last years of the nineteenth century, Benz was the largest car company in the world with 572 units produced in 1899 and, because of its size, Benz \u0026amp; Cie., became a\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint-stock_company\"\u003ejoint-stock company\u003c/a\u003e. The first motor car in central Europe and one of the first factory-made cars in the world, was produced by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czech_lands\"\u003eCzech\u003c/a\u003e company Nesselsdorfer Wagenbau (later renamed to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tatra_(company)\"\u003eTatra\u003c/a\u003e) in 1897, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pr%C3%A4sident\"\u003ePräsiden\u003c/a\u003et automobil.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDaimler and Maybach founded \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daimler_Motoren_Gesellschaft\"\u003eDaimler Motoren Gesellschaf\u003c/a\u003et (DMG) in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannstatt\"\u003eCannstatt\u003c/a\u003e in 1890, and sold their first car in 1892 under the brand name \u003ci\u003eDaimler\u003c/i\u003e. It was a horse-drawn stagecoach built by another manufacturer, which they retrofitted with an engine of their design. By 1895 about 30 vehicles had been built by Daimler and Maybach, either at the Daimler works or in the Hotel Hermann, where they set up shop after disputes with their backers. Benz, Maybach and the Daimler team seem to have been unaware of each other\u0027s early work. They never worked together; by the time of the merger of the two companies, Daimler and Maybach were no longer part of DMG. Daimler died in 1900 and later that year, Maybach designed an engine named \u003ci\u003eDaimler-Mercedes\u003c/i\u003e that was placed in a specially ordered model built to specifications set by\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emil_Jellinek\"\u003eEmil Jelline\u003c/a\u003ek. This was a production of a small number of vehicles for Jellinek to race and market in his country. Two years later, in 1902, a new model DMG car was produced and the model was named Mercedes after the Maybach engine, which generated 35 hp. Maybach quit DMG shortly thereafter and opened a business of his own. Rights to the \u003ci\u003eDaimler\u003c/i\u003e brand name were sold to other manufacturers.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eKarl Benz proposed co-operation between DMG and Benz \u0026amp; Cie. when economic conditions began to deteriorate in Germany following the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_World_War\"\u003eFirst World War\u003c/a\u003e, but the directors of DMG refused to consider it initially. Negotiations between the two companies resumed several years later when these conditions worsened and, in 1924 they signed an Agreement of Mutual Interest, valid until the year 2000. Both enterprises standardized design, production, purchasing, and sales and they advertised or marketed their car models jointly, although keeping their respective brands. On 28 June 1926, Benz \u0026amp; Cie. and DMG finally merged as the Daimler-Benz company, baptizing all of its cars Mercedes Benz, as a brand honoring the most important model of the DMG cars, the Maybach design later referred to as the 1902 Mercedes-35 hp, along with the Benz name. Karl Benz remained a member of the board of directors of Daimler-Benz until his death in 1929, and at times his two sons also participated in the management of the company.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1890, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89mile_Levassor\"\u003eÉmile Levasso\u003c/a\u003er and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armand_Peugeot\"\u003eArmand Peugeot\u003c/a\u003e of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France\"\u003eFranc\u003c/a\u003ee began producing vehicles with Daimler engines, and so laid the foundation of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_France#1900_to_1950\"\u003eautomotive industry in France\u003c/a\u003e. In 1891,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auguste_Doriot\"\u003eAuguste Doriot\u003c/a\u003e and his Peugeot colleague Louis Rigoulot completed the longest trip by a gasoline-powered vehicle when their self-designed and built Daimler powered \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot_Type_3\"\u003ePeugeot Type 3\n\u003c/a\u003ecompleted 2,100 km (1,300 miles) from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valentigney\"\u003eValentigne\u003c/a\u003ey to Paris and Brest and back again. They were attached to the first \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris%E2%80%93Brest%E2%80%93Paris\"\u003eParis-Brest-Pari\u003c/a\u003es bicycle race, but finished 6 days after the winning cyclist, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Terront\"\u003eCharles Terron\u003c/a\u003et.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe first design for an American car with a gasoline internal combustion engine was made in 1877 by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Baldwin_Selden\"\u003eGeorge Selde\u003c/a\u003en of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rochester,_New_York\"\u003eRochester, New York\u003c/a\u003e. Selden applied for a patent for a car in 1879, but the patent application expired because the vehicle was never built. After a delay of sixteen years and a series of attachments to his application, on 5 November 1895, Selden was granted a United States patent (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.google.com/patents/US549160\"\u003eU.S. Patent 549,160\u003c/a\u003e) for a t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-stroke_cycle\"\u003ewo-strok\u003c/a\u003ee car engine, which hindered, more than encouraged, development of cars in the United States. His patent was challenged by\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Ford\"\u003eHenry Ford\u003c/a\u003e and others, and overturned in 19\u003cb\u003e1 \u003c/b\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1893, the first running, gasoline-powered \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_the_United_States\"\u003eAmerican car\u003c/a\u003e was built and road-tested by the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duryea_brothers\"\u003eDuryea brother\u003c/a\u003es of Springfield, Massachusetts. The first public run of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duryea_Motor_Wagon\"\u003eDuryea Motor Wagon\u003c/a\u003e took place on 21 September 1893, on Taylor Street in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metro_Center,_Springfield,_Massachusetts\"\u003eMetro Cente\u003c/a\u003er Springfield.[28][29] \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Studebaker\"\u003eThe Studebaker Automobile Compan\u003c/a\u003ey, subsidiary of a long-established wagon and coach manufacturer, started to build cars in 1897[30]:p.66 and commenced sales of electric vehicles in 1902 and gasoline vehicles in 1904.[31]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertha_Benz\"\u003eBertha Benz\u003c/a\u003e, the first long distance driver\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eÉmile Levassor\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Britain, there had been several attempts to build steam cars with varying degrees of success, with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rickett_(car)\"\u003eThomas Ricket\u003c/a\u003et even attempting a production run in 1860.[32] \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santler_(car)\"\u003eSantle\u003c/a\u003er from Malvern is recognized by the Veteran Car Club of Great Britain as having made the first gasoline-powered car in the country in 1894,[33] followed by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_William_Lanchester\"\u003eFrederick William Lanchester\u003c/a\u003e in 1895, but these were both one-offs.[33] The first production vehicles in Great Britain came from the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daimler_Company\"\u003eDaimler Compan\u003c/a\u003ey, a company founded by\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_J._Lawson\"\u003e Harry J. Lawso\u003c/a\u003en in 1896, after purchasing the right to use the name of the engines. Lawson\u0027s company made its first car in 1897, and they bore the name \u003ci\u003eDaimler\u003c/i\u003e.[33]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1892, German engineer \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolf_Diesel\"\u003eRudolf Diese\u003c/a\u003el was granted a patent for a \"New Rational Combustion Engine\". In 1897, he built the first \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diesel_engine\"\u003ediesel engin\u003c/a\u003ee.[1] Steam-, electric-, and gasoline-powered vehicles competed for decades, with gasoline internal combustion engines achieving dominance in the 1910s. Although various \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pistonless_rotary_engine\"\u003epistonless rotary engin\u003c/a\u003ee designs have attempted to compete with the conventional \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piston\"\u003episton\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crankshaft\"\u003ecrankshaf\u003c/a\u003et design, only \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazda_Wankel_engine\"\u003eMazda\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s version of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wankel_engine\"\u003eWankel engine\u003c/a\u003e has had more than very limited success.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLarge-scale, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Production-line\"\u003eproduction-lin\u003c/a\u003ee manufacturing of affordable cars was started by\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ransom_Olds\"\u003eRansom Olds\u003c/a\u003e in 1901 at his \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oldsmobile\"\u003eOldsmobile\u003c/a\u003e factory in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lansing,_Michigan\"\u003eLansing, Michigan\u003c/a\u003e and based upon stationary \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assembly_line\"\u003eassembly lin\u003c/a\u003ee techniques pioneered by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Isambard_Brunel\"\u003eMarc Isambard Brune\u003c/a\u003el at the\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portsmouth_Block_Mills\"\u003ePortsmouth Block Mills\u003c/a\u003e, England, in 1802. The assembly line style of mass\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Blanchard_(inventor)\"\u003eproduction and interchangeable parts had been pioneered in the U.S. by Thoma\u003c/a\u003es Blanchard in 1821, at the Springfield Armory in Springfield, Massachusetts.[34] This concept was greatly expanded by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Ford\"\u003eHenry Ford\u003c/a\u003e, beginning in 1913 with the world\u0027s first \u003ci\u003emoving\u003c/i\u003e assembly line for cars at the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Highland_Park_Ford_Plant\"\u003e Highland Park Ford Plan\u003c/a\u003et.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs a result, Ford\u0027s cars came off the line in fifteen-minute intervals, much faster than previous methods, increasing productivity eightfold, while using less manpower (from 12.5-man-hours to 1 hour 33 minutes).[35] It was so successful, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paint\"\u003epain\u003c/a\u003et became a bottleneck. Only \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan_Black\"\u003eJapan Blac\u003c/a\u003ek would dry fast enough, forcing the company to drop the variety of colors available before 1913, until fast-drying \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duco\"\u003eDuc\u003c/a\u003eo \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lacquer\"\u003elacquer\u003c/a\u003e was developed in 1926. This is the source of Ford\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apocryphal\"\u003eapocrypha\u003c/a\u003el remark, \"any color as long as it\u0027s black\".[35] In 1914, an assembly line worker could buy a Model T with four months\u0027 pay.[35]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFord\u0027s complex safety procedures- especially assigning each worker to a specific location instead of allowing them to roam about-dramatically reduced the rate of injury. The combination of high wages and high efficiency is called \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fordism\"\u003eFordism\u003c/a\u003e,\" and was copied by most major industries. The efficiency gains from the assembly line also coincided with the economic rise of the United States. The assembly line forced workers to work at a certain pace with very repetitive motions which led to more output per worker while other countries were using less productive methods.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eArmand Peugeot\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eMass production\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ransom_E._Olds\"\u003eRansom E. Old\u003c/a\u003es founded Olds Motor Vehicle Company (Oldsmobile) in 1897\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Ford\"\u003eHenry Ford\u003c/a\u003e founded Ford Motor Company in 1903\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e1927 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Model_T\"\u003eFord Model \u003c/a\u003eT\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the automotive industry, its success was dominating, and quickly spread worldwide seeing the founding of Ford France and Ford Britain in 1911, Ford Denmark 1923, Ford Germany 1925; in 1921, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citroen\"\u003eCitroen\u003c/a\u003e was the first native European manufacturer to adopt the production method. Soon, companies had to have assembly lines, or risk going broke; by 1930, 250 companies which did not, had disappeared.[35]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDevelopment of automotive technology was rapid, due in part to the hundreds of small manufacturers competing to gain the world\u0027s attention. Key developments included electric \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ignition_system\"\u003eignition\u003c/a\u003e and the electric self-starter (both by\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Kettering\"\u003eCharles Ketterin\u003c/a\u003eg, for the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadillac\"\u003eCadilla\u003c/a\u003ec Motor Company in 1910-1911), independent \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suspension_(vehicle)\"\u003esuspensio\u003c/a\u003en, and four-wheel brakes.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSince the 1920s, nearly all cars have been mass-produced to meet market needs, so marketing plans often have heavily influenced car design. It was \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_P._Sloan\"\u003eAlfred P. Sloan\u003c/a\u003e who established the idea of different makes of cars produced by one company, called the General Motors Companion Make Program, so that buyers could \"move up\" as their fortunes improved.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eReflecting the rapid pace of change, makes shared parts with one another so larger production volume resulted in lower costs for each price range. For example, in the 1930s, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle_(automobile)\"\u003eLaSalles\u003c/a\u003e, sold by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadillac\"\u003eCadillac\u003c/a\u003e, used cheaper mechanical parts made by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oldsmobile\"\u003eOldsmobil\u003c/a\u003ee; in the 1950s,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet\"\u003eChevrole\u003c/a\u003et shared hood, doors, roof, and windows with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontiac\"\u003ePontia\u003c/a\u003ec; by the 1990s, corporate \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powertrain\"\u003epowertrain\u003c/a\u003es and shared \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile_platform\"\u003eplatform\u003c/a\u003es (with interchangeable \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brake\"\u003ebrakes\u003c/a\u003e, suspension, and other parts) were common. Even so, only major makers could afford high costs, and even companies with decades of production, such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apperson\"\u003eApperson\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cole_Motor_Car_Company\"\u003eCole\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorris_Motors_Corporation\"\u003eDorris\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haynes_Automobile_Company\"\u003eHayne\u003c/a\u003es, or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dPremier_(U.S._car)\u0026amp;action\u003dedit\u0026amp;redlink\u003d1\"\u003ePremie\u003c/a\u003er, could not manage: of some two hundred American car makers in existence in 1920, only 43 survived in 1930, and with the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression\"\u003eGreat Depressio\u003c/a\u003en, by 1940, only 17 of those were left.[35]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Europe, much the same would happen. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morris_Motors\"\u003eMorris\u003c/a\u003e set up its production line at \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cowley,_Oxford\"\u003eCowley\u003c/a\u003e in 1924, and soon outsold Ford, while beginning in 1923 to follow Ford\u0027s practice of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_integration\"\u003evertical integration\u003c/a\u003e, buying \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotchkiss_(car)\"\u003eHotchkis\u003c/a\u003es (engines), \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EG_Wrigley_and_Company\"\u003eWrigley\u003c/a\u003e (gearboxes), and Osberton (radiators), for instance, as well as competitors, such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolseley_Motors\"\u003eWolseley\u003c/a\u003e: in 1925, Morris had 41% of total British car production. Most British small-car assemblers, from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbey_(1922_automobile)\"\u003eAbbey\u003c/a\u003e to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xtra_(automobile)\"\u003eXtra\u003c/a\u003e, had gone under. Citroen did the same in France, coming to cars in 1919; between them and other cheap cars in reply such as\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault\"\u003e Renault\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dRenault_10CV\u0026amp;action\u003dedit\u0026amp;redlink\u003d1\"\u003e10CV\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot\"\u003ePeugeo\u003c/a\u003et\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot_5CV\"\u003e5CV\u003c/a\u003e, they produced 550,000 cars in 1925, and\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mors_(automobile)\"\u003e Mors\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurtu\"\u003eHurt\u003c/a\u003eu, and others could not compete.[35] Germany\u0027s first mass-manufactured car, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opel\"\u003eOpel\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opel_Laubfrosch\"\u003e4PS \u003ci\u003eLaubfrosch\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e (Tree Frog), came off the line at\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russelsheim\"\u003eRusselsheim\u003c/a\u003e in 1924, soon making Opel the top car builder in Germany, with 37.5% of the market.[35]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Japan, car production was very limited before World War II. Only a handful of companines were producing vehicles in limited numbers, and these were small, three-wheeled for commercial uses, like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daihatsu\"\u003eDaihats\u003c/a\u003eu, or were the result of partnering with European companies, like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isuzu_Motors\"\u003eIsuzu\u003c/a\u003e building the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolseley_Motors\"\u003eWolseley A-\u003c/a\u003e9 in 1922. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi\"\u003eMitsubish\u003c/a\u003ei was also partnered with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiat_S.p.A.\"\u003eFiat\u003c/a\u003e and built the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_Model_A\"\u003eMitsubishi Model A\n\u003c/a\u003ebased on a Fiat vehicle. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota\"\u003eToyota\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan\"\u003eNissa\u003c/a\u003en, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suzuki\"\u003eSuzuk\u003c/a\u003ei, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazda\"\u003eMazda\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honda\"\u003eHonda\u003c/a\u003e began as companies producing non-automotive products before the war, switching to car production during the 1950s. Kiichiro Toyoda\u0027s decision to take \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyoda_Loom_Works\"\u003eToyoda Loom Works\u003c/a\u003e into automobile manufacturing would create what would eventually become \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Motor_Corporation\"\u003eToyota Motor Corporatio\u003c/a\u003en, the largest automobile manufacturer in the world. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subaru\"\u003eSubaru\u003c/a\u003e, meanwhile, was formed from a conglomerate of six companies who banded together as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuji_Heavy_Industries\"\u003eFuji Heavy Industries\u003c/a\u003e, as a result of having been broken up under\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keiretsu\"\u003e \u003ci\u003ekeiretsu\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e legislation.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMost cars in use in the 2010s are propelled by an internal combustion engine, fueled by the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deflagration\"\u003edeflagratio\u003c/a\u003en (rather than \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detonation\"\u003edetonation\u003c/a\u003e) combustion of hydrocarbon fossil fuels, mostly \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gasoline\"\u003egasolin\u003c/a\u003ee (petrol) and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diesel_fuel\"\u003ediese\u003c/a\u003el, as well as some \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autogas\"\u003eAutogas\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressed_natural_gas\"\u003eCNG\u003c/a\u003e. Hydrocarbon fuels cause air pollution and contribute to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change\"\u003eclimate change\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_warming\"\u003eglobal warmin\u003c/a\u003eg.[4] Rapidly increasing \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000s_energy_crisis\"\u003eoil prices\u003c/a\u003e, concerns about oil\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiichiro_Toyoda\"\u003eKiichiro Toyoda\u003c/a\u003e, president of\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Motor_Corporation\"\u003ethe Toyota Moto\u003c/a\u003er Corporation 1941-1950\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eMass production at a Toyota plant in the 1950s\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eFuel and propulsion technologies\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_security\"\u003edependence, tightening environmental laws and restrictions on greenhouse gas\n\u003c/a\u003eemissions are propelling work on alternative power systems for cars. Efforts to\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle\"\u003eimprove or replace existing technologies include the development of hybrid vehicles, plug-in electric vehicles and hydrogen vehicles. Vehicles using alternativ\u003c/a\u003ee fuels such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethanol_fuel\"\u003eethano\u003c/a\u003el \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flexible-fuel_vehicle\"\u003eflexible-fuel vehicle\u003c/a\u003es and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_gas_vehicle\"\u003enatural gas vehicle\u003c/a\u003es are also gaining popularity in some countries. Cars for racing or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_speed_record\"\u003espeed record\u003c/a\u003es have sometimes employed j\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jet_car\"\u003eet\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocket_car\"\u003erocke\u003c/a\u003et engines, but these are impractical for common use.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oil_consumption\"\u003eOil consumptio\u003c/a\u003en in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries has been abundantly pushed by car growth; the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980s_oil_glut\"\u003e 1985-2003 oil glu\u003c/a\u003et even fuelled the sales of low-economy vehicles in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD\"\u003eOECD\u003c/a\u003e countries. The \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BRIC\"\u003eBRIC\u003c/a\u003e countries are adding to this consumption; in December 2009 China was briefly the largest car market.[36]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCars are equipped with controls used for driving, passenger comfort and safety, normally operated by a combination of the use of feet and hands, and occasionally by voice on 2000s-era cars. These controls include a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steering_wheel\"\u003esteering whee\u003c/a\u003el, pedals for operating the brakes and controlling the car\u0027s speed (and, in a manual transmission car, a clutch pedal), a shift lever or stick for changing gears, and a number of buttons and dials for turning on lights, ventilation and other functions. Modern cars\u0027 controls are now standardised, such as the location for the accelerator and brake, but this was not always the case. Controls are evolving in response to new technologies, for example the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_car\"\u003eelectric car\u003c/a\u003e and the integration of mobile communications.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSince the car was first invented, its controls have become fewer and simpler through automation. For example, all cars once had a manual controls for the choke valve, clutch, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ignition_timing\"\u003eignition timing\u003c/a\u003e, and a crank instead of an electric \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starter_(engine)\"\u003estarte\u003c/a\u003er. However new controls have also been added to vehicles, making them more complex. Examples include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile_air_conditioning\"\u003eair conditionin\u003c/a\u003eg, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_navigation_system\"\u003enavigation system\u003c/a\u003es, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_car_entertainment\"\u003ein car entertainmen\u003c/a\u003et. Another trend is the replacement of physical knob and switches for secondary controls with touchscreen controls such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMW\"\u003eBMW\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IDrive\"\u003eiDrive\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford\"\u003eFord\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MyFord_Touch\"\u003eMyFord Touch\u003c/a\u003e. Another change is that while early cars\u0027 pedals were physically linked to the brake mechanism and throttle, in the 2010s, cars have increasingly replaced these physical linkages with electronic controls.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCars are typically fitted with multiple types of lights. These include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Headlight\"\u003eheadlight\u003c/a\u003es, which are used to illuminate the way ahead and make the car visible to other users,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytime_running_lights\"\u003eso that the vehicle can be used at night; in some jurisdictions, daytime running lights; red brake lights to indicate when the brakes are applied; amber turn signa\u003c/a\u003el lights to indicate the turn intentions of the driver; white-coloured reverse lights to illuminate the area behind the car (and indicate that the driver will be or is reversing); and on some vehicles, additional lights (e.g., side marker lights) to increase the visibility of the car. Interior lights on the ceiling of the car are usually fitted for the driver and passengers. Some vehicles also have a trunk light and, more rarely, an engine compartment light.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan_Leaf\"\u003eNissan Lea\u003c/a\u003ef is an all-\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_car\"\u003eelectric ca\u003c/a\u003er launched in December 2010\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eUser interface\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Model_T\"\u003eFord Model \u003c/a\u003eT the left-side hand lever sets the rear wheel parking brakes and puts the transmission in neutral. The lever to the right controls the throttle. The lever on the left of the steering column is for ignition timing. The left foot pedal changes the two forward gears while the centre pedal controls reverse. The right pedal is the brake.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eLighting\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eLED \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytime_running_lights\"\u003edaytime running light\u003c/a\u003es on an\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi_A4\"\u003eAudi A4\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eWeight\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the United States, \"from 1975 to 1980, average [car] weight dropped from 1,842 to\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_efficiency\"\u003e1,464 kg (4,060 to 3,228 lb), likely in response to rising gasoline prices\" and new fuel efficiency standards.[38] The average new car weighed 1,461 kg (3,221 lb) in 1987 but\n\u003c/a\u003e1,818 kg (4,009 lb) in 2010, due to modern steel safety cages, anti-lock brakes, airbags, and \"more-powerful-if more-efficient-engines.\"[39] Heavier cars are safer for the driver, from an accident perspective, but more dangerous for other vehicles and road users.[39] The weight of a car influences fuel consumption and performance, with more weight resulting in increased fuel consumption and decreased performance. The\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SmartFortwo\"\u003eSmartFortw\u003c/a\u003eo, a small \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_car\"\u003ecity car\u003c/a\u003e, weighs 750-795 kg (1,655-1,755 lb). Heavier cars include full-size cars, SUVs and extended-length SUVs like th\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet_Suburban\"\u003ee Suburban\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to research conducted by Julian Allwood of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Cambridge\"\u003eUniversity of Cambridg\u003c/a\u003ee, global energy use could be heavily reduced by using lighter cars, and an average weight of 500 kg (1,100 lb) has been said to be well achievable.[40] In some competitions such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eco-marathon\"\u003eShell Eco Marathon\u003c/a\u003e, average car weights of 45 kg (99 lb) have also been achieved.[41][42] These cars are only single-seaters (still falling within the definition of a car, although 4-seater cars are more common), but they nevertheless demonstrate the amount by which car weights could still be reduced, and the subsequent lower fuel use (i.e. up to a fuel use of 2560 km/l).[43]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMost cars are designed to carry multiple occupants, often with four or five seats.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCars with five seats typically seat two passengers in the front and three in the rear. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full-size_car\"\u003eFull-size car\u003c/a\u003es and large \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_utility_vehicle\"\u003esport utility vehicles\u003c/a\u003e can often carry six, seven, or more occupants depending on the arrangement of the seats. On the other hand, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_car\"\u003esports cars\u003c/a\u003e are most often designed with only two seats. The differing needs for passenger capacity and their luggage or cargo space has resulted in the availability of a large variety of body styles to meet individual consumer requirements that include, among others, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(automobile)\"\u003esedan/saloo\u003c/a\u003en,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hatchback\"\u003ehatchbac\u003c/a\u003ek, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003estation wagon\u003c/a\u003e/estate, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minivan\"\u003eminivan\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRoad traffic accidents are the largest cause of injury-related deaths worldwide.[6]\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Ward_(scientist)\"\u003eMary Ward\u003c/a\u003e became one of the first documented car fatalities in 1869 in\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birr,_County_Offaly\"\u003eParsonstow\u003c/a\u003en, Ireland,[44] and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Bliss_(road_accident_victim)\"\u003eHenry Blis\u003c/a\u003es one of the United States\u0027 first pedestrian car casualties in 1899 in New York City.[45] There are now standard tests for safety in new cars, such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EuroNCAP\"\u003eEuroNCAP\u003c/a\u003e and the US NCAP tests,[46] and insurance-industry-backed tests by the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insurance_Institute_for_Highway_Safety\"\u003e Insurance Institute for Highway Safet\u003c/a\u003ey (IIHS).[47]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWorldwide, road traffic \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile_safety\"\u003eis becoming ever safe\u003c/a\u003er, in part due to efforts by the government to implement safety features in cars (e.g., \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seat_belts\"\u003eseat belt\u003c/a\u003es, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_bags\"\u003eair bags\u003c/a\u003e, etc.), reduce unsafe driving practices (e.g., \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speeding\"\u003espeeding\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drinking_and_driving\"\u003edrinking and drivin\u003c/a\u003eg and texting and driving) and make road design more safe by adding features such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speed_bump\"\u003espeed bumps\u003c/a\u003e, which reduce vehicle speed, and\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roundabout\"\u003e roundabout\u003c/a\u003es, which reduce the likelihood of a head-on-collision (as compared with an\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersection_(road)\"\u003e intersectio\u003c/a\u003en).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe costs of car usage, which may include the cost of: acquiring the vehicle, repairs and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auto_maintenance\"\u003eauto maintenanc\u003c/a\u003ee, fuel, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Depreciation\"\u003edepreciatio\u003c/a\u003en, driving time, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parking_fee\"\u003eparking fee\u003c/a\u003es, taxes, and insurance,[5] are weighed against the cost of the alternatives, and the value of the benefits - perceived and real - of vehicle usage. The benefits may include on-demand transportation, mobility, independence and convenience.[7] During\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_Fortwo\"\u003eSmart Fortw\u003c/a\u003eo car from 1998-2002, weighing 730 kg (1,610 lb)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet_Suburban\"\u003eChevrolet Suburba\u003c/a\u003en extended-length SUV weighs 3,300 kg (7,200 lb) (gross weight)[37]\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSeating and body style\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSafety\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eResult of a serious car accident\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eCosts and benefits\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003ethe 1920s, cars had another benefit: \"[c]ouples finally had a way to head off on unchaperoned dates, plus they had a private space to snuggle up close at the end of the night.\"[49]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSimilarly the costs to society of encompassing car use, which may include those of:\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maintaining_road\"\u003emaintaining roads\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_use\"\u003eland use\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_pollution\"\u003eair pollutio\u003c/a\u003en, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road_congestion\"\u003eroad congestio\u003c/a\u003en, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_health\"\u003epublic health\u003c/a\u003e, health care, and of disposing of the vehicle at the end of its life, can be balanced against the value of the benefits to society that car use generates. The societal benefits may include: economy benefits, such as job and wealth creation, of car production and maintenance, transportation provision, society wellbeing derived from leisure and travel opportunities, and revenue generation from the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Vehicle_taxes\"\u003etax\u003c/a\u003e opportunities. The ability for humans to move flexibly from place to place has far-reaching implications for the nature of societies.[8]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile there are different types of fuel that may power cars, most rely\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency\"\u003eon gasoline or diesel. The United States Environmental Protection Agency states that the average vehicle emits 8,887 grams of carbon\n\u003c/a\u003edioxide per gallon of gasoline. The average vehicle running on diesel fuel will emit 10,180 grams of carbon dioxide.[50] Many governments are using fiscal policies (such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road_tax\"\u003eroad tax\u003c/a\u003e or the US \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gas_guzzler_tax\"\u003egas guzzler tax\u003c/a\u003e) to influence vehicle purchase decisions, with a low CO2 figure often resulting in reduced taxation.[51] \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_tax\"\u003eFuel taxe\u003c/a\u003es may act as an incentive for the production of more efficient, hence less polluting, car designs (e.g.\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_vehicles\"\u003ehybrid vehicles\u003c/a\u003e) and the development of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_fuel\"\u003ealternative fuels\u003c/a\u003e. High fuel taxes may provide a strong incentive for consumers to purchase lighter, smaller, more fuel-efficient cars, or to not drive. On average, today\u0027s cars are about 75 percent recyclable, and using recycled steel helps reduce energy use and pollution.[52] In the United States Congress, federally mandated fuel efficiency standards have been debated regularly, passenger car standards have not risen above the 27.5 miles per US gallon (8.6 L/100 km; 33.0 mpg‑imp) standard set in 1985.\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light_truck\"\u003eLight truck\u003c/a\u003e standards have changed more frequently, and were set at 22.2 miles per US gallon (10.6 L/100 km; 26.7 mpg‑imp) in 2007.[53]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe manufacture of vehicles is resource intensive, and many manufacturers now report on the environmental performance of their factories, including energy usage, waste and water consumption.[54]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe growth in popularity of the car allowed cities to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_sprawl\"\u003espraw\u003c/a\u003el, therefore encouraging more travel by car resulting in inactivity and\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obesity\"\u003eobesity\u003c/a\u003e, which in turn can lead to increased risk of a variety of diseases.[55]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTransportation (of all types including \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truck\"\u003etrucks\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus\"\u003ebuses\u003c/a\u003e and cars) is a major contributor to air pollution in most industrialised nations. According to the American Surface Transportation Policy Project nearly half of all Americans are breathing unhealthy air. Their study showed air quality in dozens of metropolitan areas has worsened over the last decade.[56]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAnimals and plants are often negatively impacted by cars via \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habitat_destruction\"\u003ehabitat destructio\u003c/a\u003en and pollution. Over the lifetime of the average car the \"loss of habitat potential\" may be over 50,000 m2 (540,000 sq ft) based on \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_production\"\u003eprimary productio\u003c/a\u003en correlations.[57] Animals are also killed every year on roads by cars, referred to as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roadkill\"\u003eroadkil\u003c/a\u003el. More recent road developments are including significant environmental mitigations in their designs such as green bridges to allow\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildlife_crossing\"\u003e wildlife crossing\u003c/a\u003es, and creating \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildlife_corridor\"\u003ewildlife corridor\u003c/a\u003es.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road_congestion\"\u003eRoad congestio\u003c/a\u003en is an issue in many major cities. (pictured is Chang\u0027an Avenue in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing\"\u003eBeijin\u003c/a\u003eg)[48]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eEnvironmental impact\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eVehicles in use per country from 2001 to 2007. It shows the significant growth in\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BRIC\"\u003e BRIC\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eWorld map of passenger cars per 1000 people\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eGrowth in the popularity of vehicles and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commuting\"\u003ecommutin\u003c/a\u003eg has led to t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_congestion\"\u003eraffic congestio\u003c/a\u003en. Brussels was considered Europe\u0027s most congested city in 2011 according to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TomTom\"\u003eTomTom\u003c/a\u003e.[58]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCar \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propulsion\"\u003epropulsion\u003c/a\u003e technologies that are under development include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_car\"\u003egasoline/electri\u003c/a\u003ec and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plug-in_hybrid\"\u003eplug-in hybrids\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle\"\u003ebattery electric vehicles\u003c/a\u003e,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_car\"\u003ehydrogen cars\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biofuel\"\u003ebiofuels\u003c/a\u003e, and various \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_fuel\"\u003ealternative fuels\u003c/a\u003e. Research into future alternative forms of power include the development of\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_cell\"\u003efuel cell\u003c/a\u003es, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homogeneous_charge_compression_ignition\"\u003eHomogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI)\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stirling_engine\"\u003estirling engine\u003c/a\u003es,[59] and even using the stored energy of compressed air or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquid_nitrogen_economy\"\u003eliquid nitrogen\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eNew materials which may replace steel car bodies include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duralumin\"\u003eduralumi\u003c/a\u003en, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiberglass\"\u003efiberglass\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_fiber\"\u003ecarbon fibe\u003c/a\u003er, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biocomposite\"\u003ebiocomposite\u003c/a\u003es, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_nanotube\"\u003ecarbon nanotube\u003c/a\u003es.\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telematics\"\u003eTelematics\u003c/a\u003e technology is allowing more and more people to share cars, on a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Car_Club\"\u003epay-as-you-go\u003c/a\u003e basis, through \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_share\"\u003ecar share\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpool\"\u003ecarpoo\u003c/a\u003el schemes. Communication is also evolving due to\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connected_car\"\u003e connected ca\u003c/a\u003er systems.[60]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFully autonomous vehicles, also known as driverless cars, already exist in prototype (such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_driverless_car\"\u003eGoogle driverless car\u003c/a\u003e), and are expected to be commercially available around 2020. According to urban designer and futurist \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_E._Arth\"\u003eMichael E. Arth\u003c/a\u003e, driverless electric vehicles-in conjunction with the increased use of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_reality\"\u003evirtual reality\u003c/a\u003e for work, travel, and pleasure-could reduce the world\u0027s 800 million vehicles to a fraction of that number within a few decades.[61] This would be possible if almost all private cars requiring drivers, which are not in use and parked 90% of the time, would be traded for public self-driving taxis that would be in near constant use. This would also allow for getting the appropriate vehicle for the particular need-a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus\"\u003ebus\u003c/a\u003e could come for a group of people, a limousine could come for a special night out, and a Segway could come for a short trip down the street for one person. Children could be chauffeured in supervised safety, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driving_under_the_influence\"\u003eDUIs\u003c/a\u003e would no longer exist, and 41,000 lives could be saved each year in the US alone.[62][63]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThere have been several projects aiming to develop a car on the principles of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_design\"\u003eopen design\u003c/a\u003e, an approach to designing in which the plans for the machinery and systems are publicly shared, often without monetary compensation. The projects include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OScar_(open_source_car)\"\u003eOSca\u003c/a\u003er,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riversimple\"\u003eRiversimple\u003c/a\u003e (through 40fires.org)[64] and c,mm,n.[65] None of the projects have reached significant success in terms of developing a car as a whole both from hardware and software perspective and no mass production ready open-source based design have been introduced as of late 2009. Some car\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hacker_(programmer_subculture)\"\u003e hacking\u003c/a\u003e through \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On-board_diagnostics\"\u003eon-board diagnostic\u003c/a\u003es (OBD) has been done so far.[66]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe automotive industry designs, develops, manufactures, markets, and sells the world\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_vehicle\"\u003emotor vehicles\u003c/a\u003e. In 2008, more than 70 million motor vehicles, including cars and\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_vehicle\"\u003e commercial vehicle\u003c/a\u003es were produced worldwide.[67]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 2007, a total of 71.9 million new cars were sold worldwide: 22.9 million in Europe, 21.4 million in the Asia-Pacific Region, 19.4 million in the USA and Canada, 4.4 million in Latin America, 2.4 million in the Middle East and 1.4 million in Africa.[68] The markets in North America and Japan were stagnant, while those in South America and other parts of Asia grew strongly. Of the major markets, China, Russia, Brazil and India saw the most rapid growth.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAbout 250 million vehicles are in use in the United States. Around the world, there were about 806 million cars and light trucks on the road in 2007; they burn over 260 billion US gallons (980,000,000 m3) of gasoline and diesel fuel yearly. The numbers are increasing rapidly, especially in China and India.[11] In the opinion of some, urban transport systems based around the car have\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eEmerging car technologies\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutonomous car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eA robotic \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Passat\"\u003eVolkswagen Passa\u003c/a\u003et shown at \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_University\"\u003eStanford Universit\u003c/a\u003ey is a driverless car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eOpen source development\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eIndustry\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eproved unsustainable, consuming excessive energy, affecting the health of populations, and delivering a declining level of service despite increasing investments. Many of these negative impacts fall disproportionately on those social\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sustainable_transport\"\u003egroups who are also least likely to own and drive cars.[69][70][71] The sustainabl\u003c/a\u003ee transport movement focuses on solutions to these problems.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 2008, with rapidly rising oil prices, industries such as the automotive industry, are experiencing a combination of pricing pressures from raw material costs and changes in consumer buying habits. The industry is also facing increasing external competition from the public transport sector, as consumers re-evaluate their private vehicle usage.[72] Roughly half of the US\u0027s fifty-one light vehicle plants are projected to permanently close in the coming years, with the loss of another 200,000 jobs in the sector, on top of the 560,000 jobs lost this decade.[73] Combined with robust growth in China, in 2009, this resulted in China becoming the largest car producer and market in the world. China 2009 sales had increased to 13.6 million, a significant increase from one million of domestic car sales in 2000.[74] Since then however, even in China and other BRIC countries, the automotive production is again falling.[75]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eEstablished alternatives for some aspects of car use include \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_transit\"\u003epublic transi\u003c/a\u003et such as buses, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trolleybus\"\u003etrolleybuse\u003c/a\u003es, trains, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapid_transit\"\u003esubway\u003c/a\u003es, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tram_system\"\u003etramways\u003c/a\u003e light rail, cycling, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walking\"\u003ewalking\u003c/a\u003e. Car-share arrangements and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpool\"\u003ecarpooling\u003c/a\u003e are also increasingly popular, in the US and Europe.[77] For example, in the US, some car-sharing services have experienced double-digit growth in revenue and membership growth between 2006 and 2007. Services like car sharing offering a residents to \"share\" a vehicle rather than own a car in already congested neighborhoods.[78] \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system\"\u003eBike-shar\u003c/a\u003ee systems have been tried in some European cities, including \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copenhagen\"\u003eCopenhage\u003c/a\u003en and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam\"\u003eAmsterdam\u003c/a\u003e. Similar programs have been experimented with in a number of US Cities.[79] Additional individual modes of transport, such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_rapid_transit\"\u003epersonal rapid transit\u003c/a\u003e could serve as an alternative to cars if they prove to be socially accepted.[80]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe term \u003ci\u003emotorcar\u003c/i\u003e has formerly also been used in the context of electrified rail systems to denote a car which functions as a small locomotive but also provides space for passengers and baggage. These locomotive cars were often used on suburban routes by both interurban and intercity railroad systems.[81]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_costs\"\u003eCar costs\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_classification\"\u003eCar classificatio\u003c/a\u003en\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carfree_city\"\u003eCarfree city\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca
