Detnews.com | This article is no longer available online (http://www.detnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID\u003d/200803 24/AUTO01/803240338/1148)","no title"],"extracted_metadata":{"publicationdate":"2017-11-06","sha1":"8e2e2791c170c60a43b1917fe82b843fb49c8200","filename":"Automobile_layout.pdf","file_type":"pdf","title":"no title"},"result_metadata":{"score":0.874857},"html":"\u003c?xml version\u003d\u00271.0\u0027 encoding\u003d\u0027UTF-8\u0027 standalone\u003d\u0027yes\u0027?\u003e\u003chtml\u003e\n\u003chead\u003e\n    \u003cmeta content\u003d\"text/html; charset\u003dUTF-8\" http-equiv\u003d\"Content-Type\"/\u003e\u003cmeta content\u003d\"2017-11-06\" name\u003d\"publicationdate\"/\u003e\u003ctitle\u003eno title\u003c/title\u003e\u003c/head\u003e\n\u003cbody\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutomobile layout\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_design\"\u003eautomotive desig\u003c/a\u003en, the \u003cb\u003eautomobile layout\u003c/b\u003e describes where on the vehicle the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engine\"\u003eengin\u003c/a\u003ee and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drive_wheel\"\u003edrive wheels\u003c/a\u003e are found. Many different combinations of engine location and driven wheels are found in practice, and the location of each is dependent on the application for which the vehicle will be used. Factors influencing the design choice include cost, complexity, reliability, packaging (location and size of the passenger compartment and\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trunk_(automobile)\"\u003e boot\u003c/a\u003e), \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weight_distribution\"\u003eweight distributio\u003c/a\u003en, and the vehicle\u0027s intended\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_handling\"\u003e handling characteristic\u003c/a\u003es.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLayouts can roughly be divided into two categories: front- or rear-wheel drive. Four-wheel-drive vehicles may take on the characteristics of either, depending on how power is distributed to the wheels.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e1 Front-wheel-drive layouts\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e1.1 Characteristics 1.2 Advantages 1.3 Disadvantages\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e2 Rear-wheel-drive layouts\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e2.1 Characteristics 2.2 Advantages 2.3 Disadvantages\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e3 Four-wheel-drive layouts\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e3.1 Advantages 3.2 Disadvantages 3.3 Unusual 4WD layouts\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e4 History and current use 5 See also 6 References\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFront-wheel-drive layouts are those in which the front wheels of the vehicle are driven. The most popular layout used in cars today is the front-engine, front-wheel drive, with the engine in front of the front axle, driving the front wheels. This layout is typically chosen for its compact packaging; since the engine and driven wheels are on the same side of the vehicle, there is no need for a central tunnel through the passenger compartment to accommodate a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prop-shaft\"\u003eprop-shaf\u003c/a\u003et between the engine and the driven wheels.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs the steered wheels are also the driven wheels, FF (front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout) cars are generally considered superior to FR (front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout) cars in conditions such as snow, mud, or wet tarmac. The weight of the engine over the driven wheels also improves grip in such conditions. However, powerful cars rarely\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eContents\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eFront-wheel-drive layouts\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eFF layout\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003euse the FF layout because weight transference under acceleration reduces the weight on the front wheels and reduces their \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_(engineering)\"\u003etraction\u003c/a\u003e, limiting the torque which can be utilized. Electronic \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_control_system\"\u003etraction control\u003c/a\u003e can avoid wheelspin but largely negates the benefit of extra torque/power.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse_engine\"\u003etransverse engin\u003c/a\u003ee (also known as \"east-west\") is commonly used in FF designs, in contrast to FR which uses a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitudinal_engine\"\u003elongitudinal engin\u003c/a\u003ee. The FF layout also restricts the size of the engine that can be placed in modern engine compartments, as FF configurations usually have i\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inline-four_engine\"\u003enline-4\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V6\"\u003eV6\u003c/a\u003e engines, while longer engines such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straight-six_engine\"\u003einline-6\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V8_engine#V_angles\"\u003e90° V8\u003c/a\u003e will rarely fit. This is another reason luxury/sports cars avoid the FF layout. Exceptions do exist, such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volvo_S80\"\u003eVolvo S80\u003c/a\u003e (FWD/4WD) which uses transversely mounted inline-6 and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V8_engine\"\u003eV8\n\u003c/a\u003eengines, and the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Taurus_SHO\"\u003eFord Taurus SHO\u003c/a\u003e, available with a 60° V8 and front-wheel drive.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFront-wheel drive gives more interior space since the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powertrain\"\u003epowertrai\u003c/a\u003en is a single unit contained in the engine compartment of the vehicle and there is no need to devote interior space for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driveshaft\"\u003edriveshaf\u003c/a\u003et tunnel or rear \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_(mechanical_device)\"\u003edifferential\u003c/a\u003e, increasing the volume available for passengers and cargo.[1] There are some exceptions to this as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rear_engine\"\u003erear engine\u003c/a\u003e designs do not take away interior space (see \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_911\"\u003ePorsche 911\u003c/a\u003e, and\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Beetle\"\u003eVolkswagen Beetle\u003c/a\u003e). It also has fewer components overall and thus lower weight.[1] The direct connection between engine and transaxle reduces the mass and mechanical \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inertia\"\u003einerti\u003c/a\u003ea of the drivetrain compared to a rear-wheel-drive vehicle with a similar engine and transmission, allowing greater \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles\"\u003efuel econom\u003c/a\u003ey.[1] In front-wheel-drive cars the mass of the drivetrain is placed over the driven wheels and thus moves the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_of_gravity\"\u003ecentre of gravity\u003c/a\u003e farther forward than a comparable rear-wheel-drive layout, improving \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_(engineering)\"\u003etraction\u003c/a\u003e and directional stability on wet, snowy, or icy surfaces.[1][2][3] Front-wheel-drive cars, with a front weight bias, tend to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Understeer\"\u003eunderstee\u003c/a\u003er at the limit which, according to Saab engineer Gunnar Larsson, is easier since it makes instinct correct in avoiding terminal \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oversteer\"\u003eoverstee\u003c/a\u003er, and less prone to result in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fishtailing\"\u003efishtailin\u003c/a\u003eg or a spin.[3][4]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccording to a sales brochure for the 1989 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Elan\"\u003eLotus Elan\u003c/a\u003e, the ride and handling engineers at \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Cars\"\u003eLotus\u003c/a\u003e found that \"for a given vehicle weight, power and tyre size, a front-wheel-drive car was always faster over a given section of road.\"[5] However, this may only apply for cars with moderate power-to-weight ratio.[2][6][7] According to road test with two \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodge_Daytona\"\u003eDodge Daytona\u003c/a\u003es, one FWD and one RWD, the road layout is also important for what configuration is the fastest.[3]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWeight shifting limits the acceleration of a front-wheel-drive vehicle. During heavy acceleration, weight is shifted to the back, improving \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_(engineering)\"\u003etractio\u003c/a\u003en at the rear wheels at the expense of the front driving wheels; consequently, most racing cars are rear-wheel drive for acceleration. However, since front-wheel-drive cars have the weight of the engine over the driving wheels, the problem only applies in extreme conditions in which case the car understeers. On snow, ice, and sand, rear-wheel drive loses its traction advantage to front or all-wheel-drive vehicles which have greater weight over the driven wheels. Rear-wheel-drive cars with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rear_engine\"\u003erear engin\u003c/a\u003ee or mid engine configuration retain traction over the driven wheels, although fishtailing remains an issue on hard acceleration while in a turn. Some rear engine cars (e.g., \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_911\"\u003ePorsche 911\u003c/a\u003e) can suffer from reduced steering ability under heavy acceleration, since the engine is outside the wheelbase and at the opposite end of the car from the wheels doing the steering. A rear-wheel-drive car\u0027s centre of gravity is shifted rearward when heavily loaded with passengers or cargo, which may cause unpredictable handling behavior.[4]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOn front-wheel-drive cars, the short driveshaft may reduce drivetrain elasticity, improving responsiveness.[4]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eInterior space: Since the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powertrain\"\u003e powertrai\u003c/a\u003en is a single unit contained in the engine compartment of the vehicle, there is no need to devote interior space for a driveshaft tunnel or rear \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_(mechanical_device)\"\u003edifferentia\u003c/a\u003el, increasing the volume available for passengers and cargo.[1]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eInstead, the tunnel may be used to route the exhaust system pipes. Weight: Fewer components usually means lower weight. Improved \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_efficiency\"\u003efuel efficiency\u003c/a\u003e due to less weight.[8]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCost: Fewer material components and less installation complexity overall. However, the considerable \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suggested_retail_price\"\u003eMSRP\n\u003c/a\u003edifferential between a FF and FR car cannot be attributed to layout alone. The difference is more probably explained by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_scale\"\u003eproduction volume\u003c/a\u003es as most rear-wheel cars are usually in the sports/performance/luxury categories (which tend to be more upscale and/or have more powerful engines), while the FF configuration is typically in mass-produced\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCharacteristics\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAdvantages\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003emainstream cars. Few modern \"family\" cars have rear-wheel drive as of 2009, so a direct cost comparison is not necessarily possible. A contrast could be somewhat drawn between th\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi_A4\"\u003ee Audi A4\u003c/a\u003e FrontTrak (which has an FF layout and front-wheel drive) and a rear-wheel-drive\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMW_3_Series\"\u003e BMW 3 Series\u003c/a\u003e (which is FR), both which are in the compact executive car classification and use longitudinally mounted engines.[1]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eImproved drivetrain e\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eiciency: the direct connection between engine and transaxle reduce the mass and mechanical\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inertia\"\u003einertia\u003c/a\u003e of the drivetrain compared to a rear-wheel-drive vehicle with a similar engine and transmission, allowing greater \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles\"\u003efuel economy\u003c/a\u003e.[1]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAssembly efficiency: the powertrain can often be assembled and installed as a unit, which allows more efficient production.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003ePlacing the mass of the drivetrain over the driven wheels moves the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_of_gravity\"\u003e centre of gravit\u003c/a\u003ey farther forward than a comparable rear-wheel-drive layout, improving\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_(engineering)\"\u003e traction\u003c/a\u003e and directional stability on wet, snowy, or icy surfaces.[1][2][3] Predictable handling characteristics: front-wheel-drive cars, with a front weight bias, tend t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Understeer\"\u003eo understee\u003c/a\u003er at the limit, which (according to SAAB engineer Gunnar Larsson) is easier since it makes instinct correct in avoiding terminal\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oversteer\"\u003eoversteer\u003c/a\u003e, and less prone to result in\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fishtailing\"\u003e fishtailing\u003c/a\u003e or a spin.[3][4]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u003cb\u003eskilled driver\u003c/b\u003e can control the movement of the car even while skidding by steering, throttling and pulling the hand brake (given that the hand brake operates the rear wheels as in most cases, with som\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citroen\"\u003ee Citroen\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saab_Automobile\"\u003eSaab\u003c/a\u003e models being notable exceptions).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIt is easier to correct\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lift-off_oversteer\"\u003e trailing-throttle or trailing-brake overstee\u003c/a\u003er.[3]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe wheelbase can be extended without building a longer driveshaft (as with rear-wheel-driven cars).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eFront-engine front-wheel-drive layouts are \"nose heavy\" with more weight distribution forward, which makes them prone to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Understeer\"\u003eunderstee\u003c/a\u003er, especially in high horsepower applications.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIf a front-engine front-wheel-drive layout is fitted with a\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-wheel-drive\"\u003e four-wheel-driv\u003c/a\u003ee, plus enthusiast driver aids, such as active front differential, active steering, and ultra-quick electrically adjustable shocks, this somewhat negate the understeer problem and allow the car to perform as well as a front-engine rear-wheel-drive car. These trick differentials, which are found on the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acura_TL\"\u003e Acura TL\u003c/a\u003e SH-AWD and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi_S4\"\u003eAudi S4\u003c/a\u003e 3.0 TFSI quattro, and\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi_RS5\"\u003e Audi RS5\u003c/a\u003e 4.2 FSI quattro, are heavy, complex, and expensive.[9][10] While these aids do tame front end plow, cars fitted with these systems are still at a disadvantage when track tested against rear-wheel drive vehicles (including those with added four-wheel drive[11]).[12]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torque_steer\"\u003eTorque stee\u003c/a\u003er is the tendency for some front-wheel-drive cars to pull to the left or right under hard acceleration. It is a result of the offset between the point about which the wheel steers (it is aligned with the points where the wheel is connected to the steering mechanisms) and the centroid of its\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_patch\"\u003e contact patc\u003c/a\u003eh. The tractive force acts through the centroid of the contact patch, and the offset of the steering point means that a turning moment about the axis of steering is generated. In an ideal situation, the left and right wheels would generate equal and opposite moments, canceling each other out; however, in reality, this is less likely to happen. Torque steer can be addressed by using a longitudinal layout, equal length drive shafts, half shafts, a multilink suspension or centre-point steering geometry.[13][14][15][16][17][18][19]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn a vehicle, the weight shifts back during acceleration, giving more traction to the rear wheels. This is one of the main reasons nearly all racing cars are rear-wheel drive. However, since front-wheel-drive cars have the weight of the engine over the driving wheels, the problem only applies in extreme conditions such as attempting to accelerate up a wet hill or attempting to beat another RWD car off the line.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn some towing situations, front-wheel-drive cars can be at a traction disadvantage since there will be less weight on the driving wheels. Because of this, the weight that the vehicle is rated to safely tow is likely to be less than that of a rear-wheel-drive or four-wheel-drive vehicle of the same size and power.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDue to geometry and packaging constraints, the CV joints\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constant-velocity_joint\"\u003e (constant-velocity joint\u003c/a\u003es) attached to the wheel hub have a tendency to wear out much earlier than the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_joint\"\u003e universal joint\u003c/a\u003es typically used in their rear-wheel-drive counterparts (although rear-wheel-drive vehicles with\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_rear_suspension\"\u003e independent rear suspensio\u003c/a\u003en also employ CV joints and half-shafts). The significantly shorter drive axles on a front-wheel-drive car causes the joint to flex through a much wider degree of motion, compounded by additional stress and angles of steering, while the CV joints of a rear-wheel-drive car regularly see angles and wear of less than half that of front-wheel-drive vehicles.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTurning circle - FF layouts almost always use a\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse_engine\"\u003e transverse engin\u003c/a\u003ee (\"east-west\") installation, which limits the amount by which the front wheels can turn, thus increasing the turning circle of a front-wheel-drive car compared to a rear-wheel-drive one with the same wheelbase. A notable example is the origina\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mini\"\u003el Mini\u003c/a\u003e. It is widely misconceived that this limitation is due to a limit on the angle at which a\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CV_joint\"\u003e CV join\u003c/a\u003et can be operated, but this is easily disproved by considering the turning circle of car models that use a \u003ci\u003elongitudinal\u003c/i\u003e FF or F4 layout from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi\"\u003eAud\u003c/a\u003ei and (prior to 1992)\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saab_Automobile\"\u003eSaab\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe FF \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse_engine\"\u003etransverse engin\u003c/a\u003ee layout (also known as \"east-west\") restricts the size of the engine that can be placed in modern engine compartments, so it is rarely adopted by powerful luxury and sports cars. FF configurations can usually only accommodate\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inline-4\"\u003e inline-4\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V6\"\u003eV6\u003c/a\u003e engines, while longer engines such as\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inline-6\"\u003e inline-6\u003c/a\u003e and 90° big-bore\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V8_engine\"\u003e V8\u003c/a\u003e will rarely fit, though there are exceptions. One way around this problem is using a staggered engine.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eDisadvantages\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIt makes heavier use of the front tyres (i.e., accelerating, braking, and turning), causing more wear in the front than in a rear-wheel-drive layout.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eUnder extreme braking (like for instance in a panic stop), the already front heavy layout further reduces traction to the rear wheels. This results in disproportionate gripping forces focused at the front while the rear does not have enough weight to e\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eectively use its brakes. Because the rear tyres\u0027 capabilities in braking are not very high, a significant number of cheaper front drive vehicles use drum brakes in the rear even today.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe steering \u0027feel\u0027 is more numbed than a RWD car. This is due to the extra weight of drive shafts and CV joint components that increase\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unsprung_weight\"\u003e unsprung weigh\u003c/a\u003et.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRear-wheel drive (RWD) typically places the engine in the front of the vehicle and the driven wheels are located at the rear, a configuration known as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front-engine,_rear-wheel-drive_layout\"\u003efront-engine, rear-wheel-drive layou\u003c/a\u003et (FR layout). The front mid-engine, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RMR_layout\"\u003erear mid-engin\u003c/a\u003ee and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RR_layout\"\u003erear engine\u003c/a\u003e layouts are also used. This was the traditional automobile layout for most vehicles up until the 1970s and 1980s.[20] Nearly all \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motorcycle\"\u003emotorcycle\u003c/a\u003es and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicycle\"\u003ebicycles\u003c/a\u003e use rear-wheel drive as well, either by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driveshaft\"\u003edriveshaf\u003c/a\u003et, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chain_drive\"\u003echain\u003c/a\u003e, or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belt_(mechanical)\"\u003ebelt\u003c/a\u003e, since the front wheel is turned for steering, and it would be very difficult and cumbersome to \"bend\" the drive mechanism around the turn of the front wheel. A relatively rare exception is with the \u0027moving bottom bracket\u0027 type of recumbent bicycle, where the entire drivetrain, including pedals and chain, pivot with the steering front wheel.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitudinal_engine\"\u003eThe vast majority of rear-wheel-drive vehicles use a longitudinall\u003c/a\u003ey mounted engine in the front of the vehicle, driving the rear wheels via a\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driveshaft\"\u003edriveshaft\u003c/a\u003e linked via a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_(mechanics)\"\u003edifferentia\u003c/a\u003el between the rear axles. Some FR layout vehicles place the gearbox at the rear, though most attach it to the engine at the front.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe FR layout is often chosen for its simple design and good handling characteristics. Placing the drive wheels at the rear allows ample room for the transmission in the centre of the vehicle and avoids the mechanical complexities associated with transmitting power to the front wheels. For performance-oriented vehicles, the FR layout is more suitable than front-wheel-drive designs, especially with engines that exceed 200 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horsepower\"\u003ehorsepowe\u003c/a\u003er. This is because weight transfers to the rear of the vehicle during acceleration, which loads the rear wheels and increases their grip.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitudinal_engine\"\u003eAnother advantage of the FR layout is relatively easy access to the engine compartment, a result of the longitudinal orientation of the drivetrain, as compared to the FF layout (front-engine, front-wheel drive). Powerful engines such as the inline-6 and 90° big-bore V8\n\u003c/a\u003eare usually too long to fit in a FF \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse_engine\"\u003etransverse engin\u003c/a\u003ee (\"east-west\") layout; the FF configuration can typically accommodate at the maximum an \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inline-4\"\u003einline-4\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V6\"\u003eV6\u003c/a\u003e. This is another reason luxury/sports cars almost never use the FF layout.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eEven weight distribution - The layout of a rear-wheel-drive car is much closer to an even fore-and-aft weight distribution than a front-wheel-drive car, as more of the engine can lie between the front and rear wheels (in the case of a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-engine_design\"\u003emid-engin\u003c/a\u003ee layout, the entire engine), and the transmission is moved much farther back.[21]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weight_transfer\"\u003eWeight transfe\u003c/a\u003er during acceleration - During heavy acceleration, weight is placed on the rear, or driving wheels, which improves \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_(engineering)\"\u003etractio\u003c/a\u003en.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eNo \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torque_steering\"\u003etorque stee\u003c/a\u003er[22] (unless it\u0027s an all-wheel steer with an offset differential).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eRear-wheel-drive layouts\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eFR layout\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eRR layout\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCharacteristics\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAdvantages\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSteering radius - As no complicated drive shaft joints are required at the front wheels, it is possible to turn them further than would be possible using front-wheel drive, resulting in a smaller steering radius for a given wheelbase. Better \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_handling\"\u003ehandlin\u003c/a\u003eg at the hands of an expert - the more even weight distribution and weight transfer improve the handling of the car. The front and rear tyres are placed under more even loads, which allows for more grip while cornering.[23]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBetter braking - the more even weight distribution helps prevent lockup from the rear wheels becoming unloaded under heavy braking.[23]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTowing - Rear-wheel drive puts the wheels which are pulling the load closer to the point where a trailer articulates, helping steering, especially for large loads.[24]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eServiceability - Drivetrain components on a rear-wheel-drive vehicle are modular and do not involve packing as many parts into as small a space as does front-wheel drive, thus requiring less disassembly or specialized tools in order to service the vehicle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRobustness - due to geometry and packaging constraints, the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_joints\"\u003e universal joint\u003c/a\u003es attached to the wheel hub have a tendency to wear out much later than the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constant-velocity_joint\"\u003e CV joint\u003c/a\u003es typically used in front-wheel-drive counterparts. The significantly shorter drive axles on a front-wheel-drive car causes the joint to flex through a much wider degree of motion, compounded by additional stress and angles of steering, while the CV joints of a rear-wheel-drive car regularly see angles and wear of less than half that of front-wheel-drive vehicles.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCan accommodate more powerful engines as a result of the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitudinal_engine\"\u003e longitudinal orientation of the drivetrai\u003c/a\u003en, such as the\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straight-six_engine\"\u003einline-6\u003c/a\u003e, 90° big-bore \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V8_engine\"\u003eV8\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V10_engine\"\u003eV10\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V12_engine\"\u003eV12\u003c/a\u003e making the FR a common configuration for luxury and sports cars. These engines are usually too long to fit in a FF\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse_engine\"\u003e transverse engin\u003c/a\u003ee (\"east-west\") layout; the FF configuration can typically accommodate at the maximum an inline-4 or V6.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRoad grip feedback - front wheels are not a\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eected by engine and gearbox, thus allowing for better feeling of tyre grip on road surface.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eUnder heavy acceleration (as in racing),\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oversteer\"\u003e overstee\u003c/a\u003er and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fishtailing\"\u003efishtailing\u003c/a\u003e may occur as the rear wheels break free and spin. The corrective action is to let o\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003e the throttle (this is what traction control automatically does for RWD vehicles).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOn snow, ice and sand, rear-wheel drive loses its traction advantage to front- or all-wheel-drive vehicles, which have greater weight on the driven wheels. This issue is particularly noticeable on pickup trucks, as the weight of the\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rear_engine\"\u003eengine and cab will significantly shift the weight from the rear to the front wheels. Rear-wheel-drive cars with rea\u003c/a\u003er engine or mid engine configuration do not su\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eer from this, although fishtailing remains an issue. To correct this situation, owners of RWD vehicles can load sandbags in the back of the vehicle (either in the bed, or boot) in order to increase the weight over the rear axle, however speeds should be restricted to correctly predicted available grip of the road.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome rear engine cars (e.g.,\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_911\"\u003e Porsche 91\u003c/a\u003e1) can suffer from reduced steering ability under heavy acceleration, because the engine is outside the wheelbase and at the opposite end of the car from the wheels doing the steering although the engine weight over the rear wheels provides outstanding traction and grip during acceleration. Decreased interior space - Though individual designs vary greatly, rear-wheel-drive vehicles may have: Less front leg room as the transmission tunnel takes up a space between the driver and front passenger, less leg room for centre rear passengers (due to the tunnel needed for the drive shaft), and sometimes les\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trunk_(automobile)\"\u003es boo\u003c/a\u003et space (since there is also more hardware that must be placed underneath the boot)\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rear_engine\"\u003e. Rear engine\u003c/a\u003e designs (such as the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_911\"\u003e Porsche 91\u003c/a\u003e1 and\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Beetle\"\u003eVolkswagen Beetl\u003c/a\u003ee) do not inherently take away interior space.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA rear-wheel drive vehicle with four-wheel drive, compared to a front-wheel drive vehicle with four-wheel drive, will have a less e\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eicient interior packaging since the transmission is often under the front passenger compartment between the two seats, whereas the latter can package all the components under the hood.[11] Increased weight - The components of a rear-wheel-drive vehicle\u0027s power train are less complex, but they are larger. The driveshaft adds weight. There is extra sheet metal to form the transmission tunnel. There is a re\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axle\"\u003e\u003cb\u003ea\u003c/b\u003er xle\u003c/a\u003e or rear half-shafts, which are typically longer than those in a front-wheel-drive car. A rear-wheel-drive car will weigh slightly more than a comparable front-wheel-drive car (but less than four-wheel drive).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRear biased weight distribution when loaded - A rear-wheel-drive car\u0027s centre of gravity is shifted rearward when heavily loaded with passengers or cargo, which may cause unpredictable handling behavior at the hands of an inexperienced driver.[4] It needs to be noted that rear engine cars are by their very nature, rear weight biased. Higher initial purchase price - Modern rear-wheel-drive vehicles are typically more expensive to purchase than comparable front-wheel-drive vehicles. Part of this can be explained by the added cost of materials and increased labor put into assembly of FR layouts, as the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powertrain\"\u003e powertrai\u003c/a\u003en is not one compact unit. However, the difference is more probably explained by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_scale\"\u003eproduction volume\u003c/a\u003es as most rear-wheel cars are usually in the sports/performance/luxury categories (which tend to be more upscale and/or have more powerful engines), while the FF configuration is typically in mass-produced mainstream cars.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe possibility of a slight loss in the mechanical efficiency of the drivetrain (approximately 17% coastdown losses between engine flywheel and road wheels compared to 15% for front-wheel drive - however these losses are highly\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eDisadvantages\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003edependent on the individual transmission). Cars with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rear_engine\"\u003erear engine\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid_engine\"\u003emid engine\u003c/a\u003e configuration and a transverse engine layout do not su\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eer from this.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe long \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driveshaft\"\u003edriveshaf\u003c/a\u003et (on front engine cars) adds to drivetrain elasticity.[4] The driveshaft must also be extended for cars with a stretched wheelbase (e.g. limousines, minivans).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eNote: in North America, Australia and New Zealand the term \"four-wheel drive\" usually refers only to drivetrains which are primarily two-wheel drive with a part-time four-wheel-drive capability, as typically found in\n\u003c/i\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickup_truck\"\u003e\u003ci\u003epickup truck\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003ci\u003es and other off-road vehicles, while the term \"all-wheel drive\" is used to refer to full time four-wheel-drive systems found in performance cars and smaller car-based SUVs. This section uses the term four-wheel drive to refer to both.\n\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMost 4WD layouts are front-engine and are derivatives of earlier front-engine, two-wheel-drive designs. They fall into two major categories:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front-engine,_rear-wheel_drive_layout\"\u003eFront-engine, rear-wheel driv\u003c/a\u003ee derived 4WD systems, standard in most \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_utility_vehicle\"\u003esport utility vehicle\u003c/a\u003es and in passenger cars, (usually referred to \"front engine, rear-wheel drive/four-wheel drive\"), forerunners of today\u0027s models include the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jensen_FF\"\u003e Jensen FF\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_Eagle\"\u003eAMC Eagl\u003c/a\u003ee and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W124\"\u003eMercedes-Benz W12\u003c/a\u003e4 with the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4Matic\"\u003e4Matic\u003c/a\u003e system and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suzuki_Grand_Vitara\"\u003eSuzuki Grand Vitara\u003c/a\u003e with/without 4 mode transfer case.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse_engine\"\u003eTransvers\u003c/a\u003ee and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitudinal_engine\"\u003elongitudinal engin\u003c/a\u003ee 4WD systems derived almost exclusively from\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front-wheel_drive\"\u003e front-engine, front-drive layout\u003c/a\u003es, fitted to luxury, sporting and heavy duty segments, for example the transverse-engine Mitsubishi 3000GT VR-4 and\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_RAV4\"\u003eToyota RAV4\u003c/a\u003e and the longitudinal-engine\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi_Quattro\"\u003e Audi Quattr\u003c/a\u003eo and most of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subaru\"\u003eSubaru\u003c/a\u003e line.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor a full explanation of 4WD engineering considerations, see the main article o\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-wheel_drive\"\u003en four-wheel driv\u003c/a\u003ee.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn terms of handling, traction and performance, 4WD systems generally have most of the advantages of both front-wheel drive \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eand\n\u003c/i\u003erear-wheel drive. Some unique benefits are:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTraction is nearly doubled compared to a two-wheel-drive layout. Given su\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eicient power, this results in unparalleled acceleration and driveability on surfaces with less than ideal grip, and superior engine braking on loose surfaces. The development of 4WD systems for high performance cars was stimulated primarily b\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rallying\"\u003ey rallying\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eHandling characteristics in normal conditions can be configured to emulate FWD or RWD, or some mixture, even to switch between these behaviours according to circumstance. However, at the limit of grip, a well balanced 4WD configuration will not degenerate into either understeer or oversteer, but instead break traction of all 4 wheels at the same time into a four-wheel drift. Combined with modern electronic driving aids, this flexibility allows production car engineers a wide range of freedom in selecting handling characteristics that will allow a 4WD car to be driven more safely at higher speeds by inexpert motorists than 2WD designs.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4WD systems require more machinery and complex transmission components, and so increase the manufacturing cost of the vehicle and complexity of maintenance procedures and repairs compared to 2WD designs\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4WD systems increase power-train mass, rotational inertia and power transmission losses, resulting in a reduction in performance in ideal dry conditions and increased fuel consumption compared to 2WD designs\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe handbrake cannot be used to induce over-steer for maneuvering purposes, as the drivetrain couples the front and rear axles together. To overcome this limitation, some custom prepared stage\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rallying\"\u003e rally\u003c/a\u003e cars have a special mechanism added to the transmission to disconnect the rear drive if the handbrake is applied while the car is moving.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eFour-wheel-drive layouts\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eFront-engine, rear-wheel drive derived \"F4\" layout\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAdvantages\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eDisadvantages\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eUnusual 4WD layouts\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eFrom 1989 onwards, some models of\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_911\"\u003e Porsche 91\u003c/a\u003e1 feature a rear-engine 4WD layout, which is akin to a longitudinal front-engine 4WD layout installed backwards with the engine at the rear of the car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFrom 2007 onwards, the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan_GT-R\"\u003e Nissan GT-R\u003c/a\u003e features a front-engine 4WD longitudinal layout, but with the gearbox at the rear of the vehicle. This provides a more ideal weight balance, and improves directional stability at very high speeds by increasing the vehicle\u0027s\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moment_of_inertia\"\u003e moment of inerti\u003c/a\u003ea around the vertical axis. This layout necessitates a second\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prop-shaft\"\u003e prop-shaf\u003c/a\u003et to carry power to the front wheels.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome types of farm tractors and construction site machinery use a 4WD layout where the wheels on each \u003ci\u003eside\u003c/i\u003e are coupled together, rather than the wheels on each axle, allowing these vehicles to pivot about their centre point. Such vehicles are controlled in a fashion similar to a military\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tank\"\u003e tank\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Citroën Sahara had a 4WD system using complete\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_2CV\"\u003e Citroën 2C\u003c/a\u003eV drivetrains at both ends of the car, such that the engine at the front powered the front wheels and the engine at the back powered the rear wheels.[25]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u0027through the road\u0027 hybrid vehicle uses a conventional piston engine to power two wheels, with electric motor/generators on the other two wheels, giving a form of part-time 4WD.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe 2005 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeep_Hurricane\"\u003eJeep Hurrican\u003c/a\u003ee concept had an all-wheel drive layout that featured two\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V8_engine\"\u003e V8\u003c/a\u003e engines powering a single driveshaft, with a gearbox mounted in the centre of the vehicle. The gears connected to two additional driveshafts, one on each side of the vehicle, that delivered power to the wheels via driveshaft joints.[26] This was designed in order to accommodate the vehicle\u0027s unique steering system.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrari_FF\"\u003eFerrari F\u003c/a\u003eF features a front-engine 4WD layout in which a separate transmission is used for each pair of driven wheels,[27] rather than the more conventional setup in which a single transmission is used, followed by a centre differential or viscous coupling unit to split power between the front and rear wheels.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe first FR car was an 1895 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panhard\"\u003ePanhard\u003c/a\u003e model, so this layout was known as the \"Système Panhard\" in the early years. Most American cars used the FR layout until the mid-1980s. The \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1973_oil_crisis\"\u003eOil crisis\u003c/a\u003e of the 1970s and the success of small FF cars like the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mini\"\u003eMini\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf\"\u003eVolkswagen Golf\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Tercel\"\u003eToyota Terce\u003c/a\u003el, and\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honda_Civic\"\u003eHonda Civi\u003c/a\u003ec led to the widespread adoption of that layout.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAfter the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1973_oil_crisis\"\u003eArab oil embargo\u003c/a\u003e of 1973 and the 1979 fuel crises, a majority of American FR vehicles (station wagons, luxury sedans) were phased out for the FF layout - this trend would spawn the SUV/van conversion market. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, most American companies set as a priority the eventual removal of rear-wheel drive from their mainstream and luxury lineup.[28] Chrysler went 100% FF by 1990 and\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Motors\"\u003eGM\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s American production went entirely FF by 1997 except the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontiac_Firebird\"\u003eFirebird\u003c/a\u003e,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet_Corvette\"\u003eCorvett\u003c/a\u003ee and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camaro\"\u003eCamar\u003c/a\u003eo. Ford\u0027s full-size cars (the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Crown_Victoria\"\u003eFord Crown Victoria\u003c/a\u003e,\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercury_Grand_Marquis\"\u003eMercury Grand Marquis\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Town_Car\"\u003eLincoln Town Car\u003c/a\u003e) have always been FR,[29] as was the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_LS\"\u003eLincoln LS\u003c/a\u003e. In 2008, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyundai_Motor_Company\"\u003eHyunda\u003c/a\u003ei introduced its own rear-wheel-drive car, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyundai_Genesis\"\u003eHyundai Genesi\u003c/a\u003es.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Australia, FR cars have remained popular throughout this period, with the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holden_Commodore\"\u003eHolden Commodor\u003c/a\u003ee and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Falcon_(Australia)\"\u003eFord Falco\u003c/a\u003en having consistently strong sales. In Europe, front-wheel drive was popularized by small cars like the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mini\"\u003eMin\u003c/a\u003ei, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault_5\"\u003eRenault 5\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf\"\u003eVolkswagen Golf\n\u003c/a\u003eand adopted for virtually all mainstream cars.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eUpscale marques like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz\"\u003eMercedes-Ben\u003c/a\u003ez, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMW\"\u003eBMW\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaguar_Cars\"\u003eJaguar\u003c/a\u003e remained mostly independent of this trend, and retained a lineup mostly or entirely made up of FR cars.[30] Japanese mainstream marques such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota\"\u003eToyota\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan\"\u003eNissan\u003c/a\u003e became mostly or entirely FF early on, while reserving for their latterly conceived luxury divisions (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexus\"\u003eLexus\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infiniti\"\u003eInfiniti\u003c/a\u003e, respectively) a mostly FR lineup. While many automakers lost sight of the true sports car, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazda\"\u003eMazda\u003c/a\u003e introduced the highly successful \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazda_MX-5_Miata\"\u003eMiata\u003c/a\u003e roadster in 1990, a true two-seater sports car using the traditional FR layout which led to other compaines such as General Motors to produce a FR sports car based on their\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GM_Kappa_Platform\"\u003eKappa\u003c/a\u003e platform.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCurrently most cars are FF, including virtually all front-engine economy cars, though FR cars are making a return as an alternative to large sport-utility vehicles. In North America, GM returned to production of the FR luxury car with the 2003 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadillac_CTS\"\u003eCadillac CT\u003c/a\u003eS, and with the removal of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadillac_DTS\"\u003eDTS\u003c/a\u003e,[31] Cadillac will be entirely FR (with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F4_layout\"\u003efour-wheel driv\u003c/a\u003ee available as an option on several models) by 2010, and the 2010 Camaro returns as a FR sports car. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysler\"\u003eChrysle\u003c/a\u003er returned its \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full-size\"\u003efull-size\u003c/a\u003e cars to this layout with the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysler_300\"\u003eChrysler 300\u003c/a\u003e and related\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eHistory and current use\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eFMR layout, standard in most Front-engine / Rear-wheel-drive cars pre-World War II, where the engine was located behind the front axle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003emodels.[32][33] Despite Ford\u0027s 2011 discontinuation of the rear-wheel drive \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Panther_platform\"\u003ePanther Platfor\u003c/a\u003em cars, they are seeking to develop a new FR replacement.[34] Nissan is also bringing back the Silvia to their line-up, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazda\"\u003eMazd\u003c/a\u003ea is said to be releasing a new rotary-powered FR car in their RX line-up, and Toyota has produced the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_86\"\u003eFT-86\u003c/a\u003e, an affordable RWD car which is the successor to the AE86. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyundai\"\u003eHyunda\u003c/a\u003ei introduced their affordable RWD car being the 2009\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyundai_Genesis\"\u003e Hyundai Genesi\u003c/a\u003es and 2010 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyundai_Genesis_Coupe\"\u003eHyundai Genesis Coup\u003c/a\u003ee.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the 21st century, with solutions to the engineering complexities of 4WD being widely understood, and consumer demand for increasing performance in production cars, front-engine 4WD layouts are rapidly becoming more common, and most major manufacturers now offer 4WD options on at least some models. Manufacturers with a notable expertise and history in producing 4WD performance cars are\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi\"\u003e Audi\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subaru\"\u003eSubaru\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile_handling\"\u003eCar handlin\u003c/a\u003eg\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_classification\"\u003eCar classificatio\u003c/a\u003en\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gyrocar\"\u003eGyrocar\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e1. Brauer, Karl (2009-05-12). \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.edmunds.com/car-technology/what-wheel-drive.html\"\u003e\"What Wheel Drive?\" (http://www.edmunds.com/car-technology/what-wheel-drive.html\u003c/a\u003e).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eEdmunds Inside Line\u003c/i\u003e. I\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number\"\u003eSBN\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-56091-526-9\"\u003e1-56091-526-\u003c/a\u003e9. \"Front-wheel drive has been most successful in the lower power/weight range and in situations in which superior directional stability on low coefficients is important. There has never been a successful front-drive Grand Prix car nor a competitive Indianapolis car of more than 300 hp.\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e3. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://mywebpages.comcast.net/cvetters3/test1.htm\"\u003e\"What\u0027s It Like To Drive\" (http://mywebpages.comcast.net/cvetters3/test1.ht\u003c/a\u003em) Archived (https://archive.is/201212192 30600/http://mywebpages.comcast.net/cvetters3/test1.htm) 2012-12-19 at \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archive.is\"\u003eArchive.i\u003c/a\u003es, describes a test between two\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodge_Daytona\"\u003eDodge Daytona\u003c/a\u003es, one FWD and one RWD\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.saabnet.com/tsn/models/1984/pr2.html\"\u003e\"The Hidden Virtues of Front Wheel Drive\" (http://www.saabnet.com/tsn/models/1984/pr2.html\u003c/a\u003e). Frere, Paul (1992). \"From Slipping to Sliding\". \u003ci\u003eSports Car and Competition Driving\u003c/i\u003e. entleyPublishers. p. 67pp.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number\"\u003eISBN\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-8376-0202-5\"\u003e0-8376-0202-\u003c/a\u003e5. \"Front-wheel drive which, due to the reduced front wheel grip under acceleration, is practical only for cars of moderate power-to-weight ratio\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7. Prost, Alain (1990). \"Controlling a car at the limit\". \u003ci\u003eCompetition Driving\u003c/i\u003e. Hazelton Publishing. p. 50pp.\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number\"\u003e ISBN\u003c/a\u003e 0-905138-80-5. \"Front-wheel drive. In this instance, both power and steering are directed through the front wheels, the rears remaining free. Following the principle of weight transfer once more, the lightening of the front wheels under acceleration considerably reduces their effectiveness and thus limits the usable power. Consequently, this type of transmission is generally less e\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003eective on racing circuits, a few exceptions notwithstanding, but has its advantages in road events where maximum power is not called into play so often\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e8. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://web.archive.org/web/20110719205824/http://www.carpoint.com.au/advice/2010/driving-wheels--front-rear-or-allwheel-drive-7382\"\u003eKenwright, Joe (2010-04-15). \"Driving Wheels - Front, Rear or All-Wheel Drive?\" (https://web.archive.org/web/2011\u003c/a\u003e0 719205824/http://www.carpoint.com.au/advice/2010/driving-wheels--front-rear-or-allwheel-drive-7382). \u003ci\u003eCarPoint\u003c/i\u003e. Retrieved 2012-12-09.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e13. \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.mscsoftware.com/support/library/conf/adams/euro/2002/papers/005_EUC_008_FORD.pdf\"\u003eJens Dornhege. \"Torque Steer Influences on McPherson Front Axles\" (http://www.mscsoftware.com/support/library/c onf/adams/euro/2002/papers/005_EUC_008_FORD.pdf) (PDF).\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSee also\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eReferences\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eRetrieved from \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAutomobile_layout\u0026amp;oldid\u003d806545141\"\u003ehttps://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAutomobile_layout\u0026amp;oldid\u003d8065451\u003c/a\u003e41\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eThis page was last edited on 22 October 2017, at 18:39.\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eText is available under the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Text_of_Creative_Commons_Attribution-ShareAlike_3.0_Unported_License\"\u003e Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike Licens\u003c/a\u003ee; additional terms may apply.
