Semi-independent suspension\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e9 Tilting Suspension System 10 Rocker bogie mechanism 11 Tracked vehicles\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e12 Armoured fighting vehicle suspension\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e13 See also\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e14 References\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e15 External links\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn early form of suspension on \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ox\"\u003eox\u003c/a\u003e-drawn carts had the platform swing on iron chains attached to the wheeled frame of the carriage. This system remained the basis for all suspension systems until the turn of the 19th century, although the iron chains were replaced with the use of leather straps by the 17th century. No modern automobiles use the \u0027strap suspension\u0027 system.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutomobiles were initially developed as self-propelled versions of horse-drawn vehicles. However, horse-drawn vehicles had been designed for relatively slow speeds, and their suspension was not well suited to the higher speeds permitted by the internal combustion engine.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe first workable spring-suspension required advanced metallurgical knowledge and skill, and only became possible with the advent of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution\"\u003eindustrialisatio\u003c/a\u003en. Obadiah Elliott registered the first patent for a spring-suspension vehicle; - each wheel had two durable steel leaf springs on each side and the body of the carriage was fixed directly to the springs which were attached to the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axle\"\u003eaxles\u003c/a\u003e. Within a decade, most British horse carriages were equipped with springs; wooden springs in the case of light one-horse vehicles to avoid taxation, and steel springs in larger vehicles. These were often made of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_steel\"\u003elow-carbon stee\u003c/a\u003el and usually took the form of multiple layer leaf springs.[3]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leaf_springs\"\u003eLeaf spring\u003c/a\u003es have been around since the early Egyptians. Ancient military engineers used leaf springs in the form of bows to power their siege engines, with little success at first. The use of leaf springs in catapults was later refined and made to work years later. Springs were not only made of metal, a sturdy tree branch could be used as a spring, such as with a bow. Horse-drawn carriages and the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Model_T\"\u003eFord Model T\u003c/a\u003e used this system, and it is still used today in larger vehicles, mainly mounted in the rear suspension.[4]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003ePart of car front suspension and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steering\"\u003esteering\u003c/a\u003e mechanism: tie rod, steering arm, king pin axis (using \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ball_joint\"\u003eball joints\u003c/a\u003e).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eVan Diemen RF01 Racing Car Suspension.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eHistory\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eStrap suspension 1605\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eStrap suspension 2008 note the transverse limiting straps\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis was the first modern suspension system and, along with advances in the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macadam\"\u003econstruction of roads\u003c/a\u003e, heralded the single greatest improvement in road transport until the advent of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile\"\u003eautomobile\u003c/a\u003e.[5] The British steel springs were not well suited for use on America\u0027s rough roads of the time, so the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbot-Downing_Company\"\u003eAbbot-Downing Compan\u003c/a\u003ey of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concord,_New_Hampshire\"\u003eConcord, New Hampshire\u003c/a\u003e re-introduced leather strap suspension, which gave a swinging motion instead of the jolting up and down of a spring suspension.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1901 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mors_(automobile)\"\u003eMors\u003c/a\u003e of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris\"\u003eParis\u003c/a\u003e first fitted an automobile with shock absorbers. With the advantage of a damped suspension system on his \u0027Mors Machine\u0027, Henri Fournier won the prestigious Paris-to-Berlin race on 20 June 1901. Fournier\u0027s superior time was 11 hrs 46 min 10 sec, while the best competitor was Léonce Girardot in a Panhard with a time of 12 hrs 15 min 40 sec.[6]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coil_spring\"\u003eCoil springs\u003c/a\u003e first appeared on a production vehicle in 1906 in the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brush_Runabout\"\u003eBrush Runabou\u003c/a\u003et made by the Brush Motor Company. Today, coil springs are used in most cars.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1920, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leyland_Motors_Ltd\"\u003eLeyland Motor\u003c/a\u003es used \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torsion_bar_suspension\"\u003etorsion bar\u003c/a\u003es in a suspension system.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 1922, independent front suspension was pioneered on the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lancia_Lambda\"\u003eLancia Lambda\u003c/a\u003e and became more common in mass market cars from 1932.[7] Today most cars have\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_suspension\"\u003eindependent suspensio\u003c/a\u003en on all four wheels.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 2002, a new passive suspension component was invented by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malcolm_C._Smith\"\u003eMalcolm C. Smit\u003c/a\u003eh, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inerter_(mechanical_networks)\"\u003einerter\u003c/a\u003e. This has the ability to increase the effective inertia of a wheel suspension using a geared flywheel, but without adding significant mass. It was initially employed in Formula 1 in secrecy but has since spread to other motorsport.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eObviously any four wheel vehicle needs suspension for both the front wheels and the rear suspension, but in two wheel drive vehicles these can be very different configuration. For \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front-wheel_drive\"\u003efront-wheel driv\u003c/a\u003ee \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile\"\u003ecars\u003c/a\u003e, rear suspension has few constraints and a variety of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beam_axle\"\u003ebeam axle\u003c/a\u003es and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_suspension\"\u003eindependent suspension\u003c/a\u003es are used. For \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rear-wheel_drive\"\u003erear-wheel driv\u003c/a\u003ee \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile\"\u003ecars\u003c/a\u003e, rear suspension has many constraints and the development of the superior but more expensive \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_suspension\"\u003eindependent suspensio\u003c/a\u003en layout has been difficult. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-wheel_drive\"\u003eFour-wheel drive\u003c/a\u003e often have suspensions that are similar for both the front and rear wheels.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Ford\"\u003eHenry Ford\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_T\"\u003eModel T\u003c/a\u003e used a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torque_tube\"\u003etorque tub\u003c/a\u003ee to restrain this force, for his \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_(mechanics)\"\u003edifferential\u003c/a\u003e was attached to the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chassis\"\u003echassi\u003c/a\u003es by a lateral \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leaf_spring\"\u003eleaf spring\n\u003c/a\u003eand two narrow rods. The torque tube surrounded the true \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driveshaft\"\u003edriveshaf\u003c/a\u003et and exerted the force to its \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ball_joint\"\u003eball join\u003c/a\u003et at the extreme rear of the transmission, which was attached to the engine. A similar method was used by the late-1930s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buick\"\u003eBuick\u003c/a\u003e and by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson_Motor_Car\"\u003eHudso\u003c/a\u003en\u0027s \u003ci\u003ebathtub car\u003c/i\u003e of 1948, which used helical springs which could not take fore-and-aft thrust.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotchkiss_drive\"\u003eHotchkiss drive\u003c/a\u003e, invented by Albert Hotchkiss, was the most popular rear suspension system used in American cars from the 1930s to the 1970s. The system uses longitudinal leaf springs attached both forward and behind the differential of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Live_axle\"\u003elive axle\u003c/a\u003e. These springs transmit the torque to the frame. Although scorned by many European car makers of the time, it was accepted by American car makers because it was \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inexpensive\"\u003einexpensiv\u003c/a\u003ee to manufacture. Also, the dynamic defects of this design were suppressed by the enormous weight of US passenger vehicles before implementation of th\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_Average_Fuel_Economy\"\u003ee Corporate Average Fuel Econom\u003c/a\u003ey standard.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAnother Frenchman invented the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Dion_tube\"\u003eDe Dion tube\u003c/a\u003e, which is sometimes called \"semi-independent\". Like a true independent rear suspension, this employs two \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_joint\"\u003euniversal joint\u003c/a\u003es or their equivalent from the center of the differential to each wheel. But the wheels cannot entirely rise and fall independently of each other; they are tied by a yoke that goes around the differential, below and behind it. This method has had little use in the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States\"\u003eUnited State\u003c/a\u003es, though it does not evidence the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bump_steer\"\u003ebump stee\u003c/a\u003er that a more expensive, true independent suspension does. Its use around 1900 was probably due to the poor quality of tires, which wore out quickly. By removing a good deal of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unsprung_weight\"\u003eunsprung weigh\u003c/a\u003et, as independent rear suspensions do, it made them last longer.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eHenri Fournier on his uniquely damped and racewinning \u0027Mors Machine\u0027, photo taken 1902\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eDifference between rear suspension and front suspension\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eHistory\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eRear wheel drive vehicles today frequently use a fairly complex fully independent, multi-link suspension to locate the rear wheels securely while providing decent\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ride_quality\"\u003e ride qualit\u003c/a\u003ey.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe spring rate (or suspension rate) is a component in setting the vehicle\u0027s ride height or its location in the suspension stroke. When a spring is compressed or stretched, the force it exerts is proportional to its change in length. The \u003ci\u003espring rate\n\u003c/i\u003eor \u003ci\u003espring constant\u003c/i\u003e of a spring is the change in the force it exerts, divided by the change in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deflection_(engineering)\"\u003edeflectio\u003c/a\u003en of the spring. Vehicles which carry heavy loads will often have heavier springs to compensate for the additional weight that would otherwise collapse a vehicle to the bottom of its travel (stroke). Heavier springs are also used in performance applications where the loading conditions experienced are more extreme.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSprings that are too hard or too soft cause the suspension to become ineffective because they fail to properly isolate the vehicle from the road. Vehicles that commonly experience suspension loads heavier than normal have heavy or hard springs with a spring rate close to the upper limit for that vehicle\u0027s weight. This allows the vehicle to perform properly under a heavy load when control is limited by the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inertia\"\u003einerti\u003c/a\u003ea of the load. Riding in an empty truck used for carrying loads can be uncomfortable for passengers because of its high spring rate relative to the weight of the vehicle. A race car would also be described as having heavy springs and would also be uncomfortably bumpy. However, even though we say they both have heavy springs, the actual spring rates for a 2,000 lb (910 kg) race car and a 10,000 lb (4,500 kg) truck are very different. A luxury car, taxi, or passenger bus would be described as having soft springs. Vehicles with worn out or damaged springs ride lower to the ground which reduces the overall amount of compression available to the suspension and increases the amount of body lean. Performance vehicles can sometimes have spring rate requirements other than vehicle weight and load.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpring rate is a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ratio\"\u003eratio\u003c/a\u003e used to measure how resistant a spring is to being compressed or expanded during the spring\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deflection_(engineering)\"\u003edeflectio\u003c/a\u003en. The magnitude of the spring force increases as deflection increases according t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hooke%27s_Law\"\u003eo Hooke\u0027s Law\u003c/a\u003e. Briefly, this can be stated as\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003ewhere\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eF\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e is the force the spring exerts\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003ek\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e is the spring rate of the spring.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003ex\u003c/i\u003e is the deflection of the spring from its equilibrium position (i.e., when no force is applied on the spring)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eNegative sign indicates direction of applied force and force exerted by spring are opposite. Spring rate is confined to a narrow interval by the weight of the vehicle, load the vehicle will carry, and to a lesser extent by suspension geometry and performance desires.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpring rates typically have units of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton_(unit)\"\u003eN\u003c/a\u003e/\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millimeter\"\u003emm\u003c/a\u003e (or l\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pound-force\"\u003ebf\u003c/a\u003e/\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inch\"\u003ein\u003c/a\u003e). An example of a linear spring rate is 500 lbf/in. For every inch the spring is compressed, it exerts 500 lbf. A non-linear spring rate is one for which the relation between the spring\u0027s compression and the force exerted cannot be fitted adequately to a linear model. For example, the first inch exerts 500 lbf force, the second inch exerts an additional 550 lbf (for a total of 1050 lbf), the third inch exerts another 600 lbf (for a total of 1650 lbf). In contrast a 500 lbf/in linear spring compressed to 3 inches will only exert 1500 lbf.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpring, wheel, and roll rates\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_BX\"\u003eCitroën BX\u003c/a\u003e Hydropneumatic suspension - maximum to minimum demonstration\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f5/Citro%C3%ABn_BX_-_Suspension_-_Maximum_to_minimum.ogv\"\u003ePlay medi\u003c/a\u003ea\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpring rate\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eMathematics of the spring rate\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe spring rate of a coil spring may be calculated by a simple algebraic equation or it may be measured in a spring testing machine. The spring constant \u003ci\u003ek\u003c/i\u003e can be calculated as follows:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003ewhere \u003ci\u003ed\u003c/i\u003e is the wire diameter, G is the spring\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shear_modulus\"\u003eshear modulu\u003c/a\u003es (e.g., about 12,000,000 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lbf/in%C2%B2\"\u003elbf/in²\u003c/a\u003e or 80 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPa\"\u003eGPa\u003c/a\u003e for steel), \u003ci\u003eN\u003c/i\u003e is the number of wraps and \u003ci\u003eD\u003c/i\u003e is the diameter of the coil.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWheel rate is the effective spring rate when measured at the wheel. This is as opposed to simply measuring the spring rate alone.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWheel rate is usually equal to or considerably less than the spring rate. Commonly, springs are mounted on control arms, swing arms or some other pivoting suspension member. Consider the example above where the spring rate was calculated to be 500 lbs/inch (87.5 N/mm), if you were to move the wheel 1 in (2.5 cm) (without moving the car), the spring more than likely compresses a smaller amount. Let\u0027s assume the spring moved 0.75 in (19 mm), the lever arm ratio would be 0.75:1. The wheel rate is calculated by taking the square of the ratio (0.5625) times the spring rate, thus obtaining 281.25 lbs/inch (49.25 N/mm). Squaring the ratio is because the ratio has two effects on the wheel rate. The ratio applies to both the force and distance traveled.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWheel rate on independent suspension is fairly straightforward. However, special consideration must be taken with some non-independent suspension designs. Take the case of the straight axle. When viewed from the front or rear, the wheel rate can be measured by the means above. Yet because the wheels are not independent, when viewed from the side under acceleration or braking the pivot point is at infinity (because both wheels have moved) and the spring is directly inline with the wheel contact patch. The result is often that the effective wheel rate under cornering is different from what it is under acceleration and braking. This variation in wheel rate may be minimized by locating the spring as close to the wheel as possible.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWheel rates are usually summed and compared with the sprung mass of a vehicle to create a \"ride rate\" and corresponding suspension\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resonance\"\u003enatural frequency\u003c/a\u003e in ride (also referred to as \"heave\"). This can be useful in creating a metric for suspension stiffness and travel requirements for a vehicle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRoll rate is analogous to a vehicle\u0027s ride rate, but for actions that include lateral accelerations, causing a vehicle\u0027s sprung mass to roll about its roll axis. It is expressed as torque per degree of roll of the vehicle sprung mass. It is influenced by factors including but not limited to vehicle sprung mass, track width, CG height, spring and damper rates, roll center heights of front and rear, anti-roll bar stiffness and tire pressure/construction. The roll rate of a vehicle can, and usually does, differ front to rear, which allows for the tuning ability of a vehicle for transient and steady state handling. The roll rate of a vehicle does not change the total amount of weight transfer on the vehicle, but shifts the speed at which and percentage of weight transferred on a particular axle to another axle through the vehicle chassis. Generally, the higher the roll rate on an axle of a vehicle, the faster and higher percentage the weight transfer on that axle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eRoll couple percentage is a simplified method of describing lateral load transfer distribution front to rear, and subsequently handling balance. It is the effective wheel rate, in roll, of each axle of the vehicle as a ratio of the vehicle\u0027s total roll rate. It is commonly adjusted through the use of\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-roll_bars\"\u003e anti-roll bar\u003c/a\u003es, but can also be changed through the use of different springs.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eWheel rate\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eRoll rate\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eRoll couple percentage\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eWeight transfer\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eWeight transfer during cornering, acceleration or braking is usually calculated per individual wheel and compared with the static weights for the same wheels.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe total amount of weight transfer is only affected by four factors: the distance between wheel centers (wheelbase in the case of braking, or track width in the case of cornering) the height of the center of gravity, the mass of the vehicle, and the amount of acceleration experienced.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe speed at which weight transfer occurs as well as through which components it transfers is complex and is determined by many factors including but not limited to roll center height, spring and damper rates, anti-roll bar stiffness and the kinematic design of the suspension links. In most conventional applications, when weight is transferred through intentionally compliant elements such as springs, dampers and anti-roll bars, the weight transfer is said to be \"elastic\", while the weight which is transferred through more rigid suspension links such as A-arms and toe links is said to be \"geometric\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eUnsprung weight transfer is calculated based on the weight of the vehicle\u0027s components that are not supported by the springs. This includes tires, wheels, brakes, spindles, half the control arm\u0027s weight and other components. These components are then (for calculation purposes) assumed to be connected to a vehicle with zero sprung weight. They are then put through the same dynamic loads. The weight transfer for cornering in the front would be equal to the total unsprung front weight times the G-Force times the front unsprung center of gravity height divided by the front track width. The same is true for the rear.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSprung weight transfer is the weight transferred by only the weight of the vehicle resting on the springs, not the total vehicle weight. Calculating this requires knowing the vehicle\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sprung_weight\"\u003esprung weigh\u003c/a\u003et (total weight less the unsprung weight), the front and rear roll center heights and the sprung center of gravity height (used to calculate the roll moment arm length). Calculating the front and rear sprung weight transfer will also require knowing the roll couple percentage.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe roll axis is the line through the front and rear roll centers that the vehicle rolls around during cornering. The distance from this axis to the sprung center of gravity height is the roll moment arm length. The total sprung weight transfer is equal to the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G-force\"\u003eG-force\n\u003c/a\u003etimes the sprung weight times the roll moment arm length divided by the effective track width. The front sprung weight transfer is calculated by multiplying the roll couple percentage times the total sprung weight transfer. The rear is the total minus the front transfer.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eJacking forces are the sum of the vertical force components experienced by the suspension links. The resultant force acts to lift the sprung mass if the roll center is above ground, or compress it if underground. Generally, the higher the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roll_center\"\u003eroll cente\u003c/a\u003er, the more jacking force is experienced.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eTravel is the measure of distance from the bottom of the suspension stroke (such as when the vehicle is on a jack and the wheel hangs freely) to the top of the suspension stroke (such as when the vehicle\u0027s wheel can no longer travel in an upward direction toward the vehicle). Bottoming or lifting a wheel can cause serious control problems or directly cause damage. \"Bottoming\" can be caused by the suspension, tires, fenders, etc. running out of space to move or the body or other components of the car hitting the road. The control problems caused by lifting a wheel are less severe if the wheel lifts when the spring reaches its unloaded shape than they are if travel is limited by contact of suspension members (See \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triumph_TR3B\"\u003eTriumph TR3\u003c/a\u003eB.) Many \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Off-road_vehicle\"\u003eoff-road vehicle\u003c/a\u003es, such as desert racers, use straps\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eUnsprung weight transfer\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSprung weight transfer\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eJacking forces\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eOther properties\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eTravel\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003ecalled \"limiting straps\" to limit the suspensions downward travel to a point within safe limits for the linkages and shock absorbers. This is necessary, since these trucks are intended to travel over very rough terrain at high speeds, and even become airborne at times. Without something to limit the travel, the suspension bushings would take all the force when the suspension reaches \"full droop\", and it can even cause the coil springs to come out of their \"buckets\" if they are held in by compression forces only. A limiting strap is a simple strap, often nylon of a predetermined length, that stops the downward movement at a preset point before the theoretical maximum travel is reached. The opposite of this is the \"bump-stop\", which protects the suspension and vehicle (as well as the occupants) from violent \"bottoming\" of the suspension, caused when an obstruction (or hard landing) causes the suspension to run out of upward travel without fully absorbing the energy of the stroke. Without bump-stops, a vehicle that \"bottoms out\" will experience a very hard shock when the suspension contacts the bottom of the frame or body, which is transferred to the occupants and every connector and weld on the vehicle. Factory vehicles often come with plain rubber \"nubs\" to absorb the worst of the forces, and insulate the shock. A desert race vehicle, which must routinely absorb far higher impact forces, may be provided with pneumatic or hydro-pneumatic bump-stops. These are essentially miniature shock absorbers (dampeners) that are fixed to the vehicle in a location such that the suspension will contact the end of the piston when it nears the upward travel limit. These absorb the impact far more effectively than a solid rubber bump-stop will, essential because a rubber bump-stop is considered a \"last-ditch\" emergency insulator for the occasional accidental bottoming of the suspension; it is entirely insufficient to absorb repeated and heavy bottomings such as a high-speed off-road vehicle encounters.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damping\"\u003eDamping\u003c/a\u003e is the control of motion or oscillation, as seen with the use of hydraulic gates and valves in a vehicle\u0027s shock absorber. This may also vary, intentionally or unintentionally. Like spring rate, the optimal damping for comfort may be less than for control.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDamping controls the travel speed and resistance of the vehicle\u0027s suspension. An undamped car will oscillate up and down. With proper damping levels, the car will settle back to a normal state in a minimal amount of time. Most damping in modern vehicles can be controlled by increasing or decreasing the resistance to fluid flow in the shock absorber.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSee dependent and independent below. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camber_angle\"\u003eCamber\u003c/a\u003e changes due to wheel travel, body roll and suspension system deflection or compliance. In general, a tire wears and brakes best at -1 to -2° of camber from vertical. Depending on the tire and the road surface, it may hold the road best at a slightly different angle. Small changes in camber, front and rear, can be used to tune handling. Some race cars are tuned with -2 to -7° camber depending on the type of handling desired and the tire construction. Often, too much camber will result in the decrease of braking performance due to a reduced contact patch size through excessive camber variation in the suspension geometry. The amount of camber change in bump is determined by the instantaneous front view swing arm (FVSA) length of the suspension geometry, or in other words, the tendency of the tire to camber inward when compressed in bump.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRoll center height is a product of suspension instant center heights and is a useful metric in analyzing weight transfer effects, body roll and front to rear roll stiffness distribution. Conventionally, roll stiffness distribution is tuned adjusting \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiroll_bar\"\u003eantiroll bars\u003c/a\u003e rather than roll center height (as both tend to have a similar effect on the sprung mass), but the height of the roll center is significant when considering the amount of jacking forces experienced.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDue to the fact that the wheel and tire\u0027s motion is constrained by the suspension links on the vehicle, the motion of the wheel package in the front view will scribe an imaginary arc in space with an \"instantaneous center\" of rotation at any given point along its path. The instant center for any wheel package can be found by following imaginary lines drawn through the suspension links to their intersection point.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eDamping\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCamber control\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eRoll center height\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eInstant center\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eA component of the tire\u0027s force vector points from the contact patch of the tire through instant center. The larger this component is, the less suspension motion will occur. Theoretically, if the resultant of the vertical load on the tire and the lateral force generated by it points directly into the instant center, the suspension links will not move. In this case, all weight transfer at that end of the vehicle will be geometric in nature. This is key information used in finding the force-based roll center as well.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn this respect the instant centers are more important to the handling of the vehicle than the kinematic roll center alone, in that the ratio of geometric to elastic weight transfer is determined by the forces at the tires and their directions in relation to the position of their respective instant centers.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAnti-dive and anti-squat are percentages that indicate the degree to which the front dives under braking and the rear squats under acceleration. They can be thought of as the counterparts for braking and acceleration, as jacking forces are to cornering. The main reason for the difference is due to the different design goals between front and rear suspension, whereas suspension is usually symmetrical between the left and right of the vehicle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe method of determining the anti-dive or anti-squat depends on whether the suspension linkages react to the torque of braking and accelerating. For example, with inboard brakes and half-shaft driven rear wheels, the suspension linkages do not, but with outboard brakes and a swing-axle driveline, they do.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTo determine the percentage of front suspension braking anti-dive for outboard brakes, it is first necessary to determine the tangent of the angle between a line drawn, in side view, through the front tire patch and the front suspension instant center, and the horizontal. In addition, the percentage of braking effort at the front wheels must be known. Then, multiply the tangent by the front wheel braking effort percentage and divide by the ratio of the center of gravity height to the wheelbase. A value of 50% would mean that half of the weight transfer to the front wheels, during braking, is being transmitted through the front suspension linkage and half is being transmitted through the front suspension springs.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor inboard brakes, the same procedure is followed but using the wheel center instead of contact patch center.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eForward acceleration anti-squat is calculated in a similar manner and with the same relationship between percentage and weight transfer. Anti-squat values of 100% and more are commonly used in drag racing, but values of 50% or less are more common in cars that have to undergo severe braking. Higher values of anti-squat commonly cause wheel hop during braking. It is important to note that, while the value of 100% means that all of the weight transfer is being carried through the suspension linkage. However, this does not mean that the suspension is incapable of carrying additional loads (aerodynamic, cornering, etc.) during an episode of braking or forward acceleration. In other words, no \"binding\" of the suspension is to be implied.[8]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn some modern cars, the flexibility is mainly in the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubber_bushing\"\u003erubber bushings\u003c/a\u003e, which are subject to decay over time. For high-stress suspensions, such as off-road vehicles, polyurethane bushings are available, which offer more longevity under greater stresses. However, due to weight and cost considerations, structures are not made more rigid than necessary. Some vehicles exhibit detrimental vibrations involving the flexing of structural parts, such as when accelerating while turning sharply. Flexibility of structures such as frames and suspension links can also contribute to springing, especially to damping out high frequency vibrations. The flexibility of wire wheels contributed to their popularity in times when cars had less advanced suspensions.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eVariations in suspension design\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAnti-dive and anti-squat\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eFlexibility and vibration modes of the suspension elements\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eLoad levelling\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutomobiles can be heavily laden with luggage, passengers, and trailers. This loading will cause a vehicle\u0027s tail to sink downwards. Maintaining a steady chassis level is essential to achieving the proper handling the vehicle was designed for. Oncoming drivers can be blinded by the headlight beam. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-levelling_suspension\"\u003eSelf-levelling suspensio\u003c/a\u003en counteracts this by inflating cylinders in the suspension to lift the chassis higher.[9]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor most purposes, the weight of the suspension components is unimportant, but at high frequencies, caused by road surface roughness, the parts isolated by rubber bushings act as a multistage filter to suppress noise and vibration better than can be done with only the tires and springs. (The springs work mainly in the vertical direction.)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThese are usually small, except that the suspension is related to whether the brakes and differential(s) are sprung.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis is the main functional advantage of aluminum wheels over steel wheels. Aluminum suspension parts have been used in production cars, and carbon fiber suspension parts are common in racing cars.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eDesigns differ as to how much space they take up and where it is located. It is generally accepted that \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacPherson_strut\"\u003eMacPherson strut\u003c/a\u003es are the most compact arrangement for front-engined vehicles, where space between the wheels is required to place the engine.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eInboard brakes (which reduce unsprung weight) are probably avoided more due to space considerations than to cost.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe suspension attachment must match the frame design in geometry, strength and rigidity.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCertain modern vehicles have \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Height_adjustable_suspension\"\u003eheight adjustable suspensio\u003c/a\u003en in order to improve aerodynamics and fuel efficiency. Modern formula cars that have exposed wheels and suspension typically use streamlined tubing rather than simple round tubing for their suspension arms to reduce \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerodynamic_drag\"\u003eaerodynamic drag\u003c/a\u003e. Also typical is the use of rocker arm, push rod, or pull rod type suspensions that, among other things, place the spring/damper unit inboard and out of the air stream to further reduce air resistance.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eProduction methods improve, but cost is always a factor. The continued use of the solid rear axle, with unsprung differential, especially on heavy vehicles, seems to be the most obvious example.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eMost conventional suspensions use passive\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_(device)\"\u003e spring\u003c/a\u003es to absorb impacts and dampers (or shock absorbers) to control spring motions.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome notable exceptions are the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydropneumatic\"\u003ehydropneumati\u003c/a\u003ec systems, which can be treated as an integrated unit of gas spring and damping components, used by the French manufacturer \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn\"\u003eCitroën\u003c/a\u003e and the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrolastic\"\u003ehydrolasti\u003c/a\u003ec, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydragas\"\u003ehydraga\u003c/a\u003es and rubber cone systems used by the British Motor Corporation, most notably on the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mini\"\u003e Mini\u003c/a\u003e. A number of different types of each have been used:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIsolation from high frequency shock\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eContribution to unsprung weight and total weight\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpace occupied\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eForce distribution\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAir resistance (drag)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCost\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSprings and dampers\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003ePassive suspensions\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eTraditional springs and dampers are referred to as passive suspensions - most vehicles are suspended in this manner.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe majority of land vehicles are suspended by steel springs, of these types:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leaf_spring\"\u003eLeaf sprin\u003c/a\u003eg - AKA Hotchkiss, Cart, or semi-elliptical spring[4]\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torsion_beam_suspension\"\u003eTorsion beam suspensio\u003c/a\u003en[10]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coil_spring\"\u003eCoil spring\u003c/a\u003e[11]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutomakers are aware of the inherent limitations of steel springs, that they tend to produce undesirable oscillations, and have developed other types of suspension materials and mechanisms in attempts to improve performance:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRubber \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bushing_(isolator)\"\u003ebushin\u003c/a\u003eg[12]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGas under pressure - \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_suspension\"\u003eair sprin\u003c/a\u003eg[13]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGas and hydraulic fluid under pressure -\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydropneumatic_suspension\"\u003e hydropneumatic suspensio\u003c/a\u003en[14] and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oleo_strut\"\u003eoleo stru\u003c/a\u003et\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe shock absorbers damp out the (otherwise simple harmonic) motions of a vehicle up and down on its springs. They also must damp out much of the wheel bounce when the unsprung weight of a wheel, hub, axle and sometimes brakes and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_(mechanics)\"\u003edifferentia\u003c/a\u003el bounces up and down on the springiness of a tire. Some have suggested that the regular bumps found on dirt roads (nicknamed \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corduroy_road\"\u003ecorduroy\u003c/a\u003e\", but properly corrugations or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washboarding\"\u003ewashboardin\u003c/a\u003eg) are caused by this wheel bounce, though some evidence exists that it is unrelated to suspension at all. (See \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washboarding\"\u003ewashboarding\u003c/a\u003e.)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIf the suspension is externally controlled then it is a semi-active or active suspension - the suspension is reacting to signals from an electronic controller.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor example, a hydropneumatic Citroën will \"know\" how far off the ground the car is supposed to be and constantly reset to achieve that level, regardless of load. It will \u003ci\u003enot\u003c/i\u003e instantly compensate for body roll due to cornering however. Citroën\u0027s system adds about 1% to the cost of the car versus passive steel springs.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSemi-active suspensions include devices such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_suspension\"\u003eair spring\u003c/a\u003es and switchable shock absorbers, various \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-levelling_suspension\"\u003eself-levellin\u003c/a\u003eg solutions, as well as systems like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydropneumatic\"\u003ehydropneumati\u003c/a\u003ec, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrolastic\"\u003ehydrolasti\u003c/a\u003ec, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydragas\"\u003ehydraga\u003c/a\u003es suspensions. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_Motors\"\u003eMitsubish\u003c/a\u003ei developed the world\u0027s first production semi-active electronically controlled suspension system in passenger cars; the system was first incorporated in the 1987 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_Galant\"\u003eGalant\n\u003c/a\u003emodel.[15][16][17][18][19] Delphi currently sells shock absorbers filled with a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MR_fluid\"\u003emagneto-rheological fluid\u003c/a\u003e, whose viscosity can be changed electromagnetically, thereby giving variable control without switching valves, which is faster and thus more effective.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFully \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_suspension\"\u003eactive suspension\u003c/a\u003e systems use electronic monitoring of vehicle conditions, coupled with the means to impact vehicle suspension and behavior in real time to directly control the motion of the car. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Cars\"\u003eLotus Cars\u003c/a\u003e developed several prototypes, from 1982 onwards, and introduced them to F1, where they have been fairly effective, but have now been banned. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan\"\u003eNissa\u003c/a\u003en introduced a low bandwidth active suspension in circa 1990 as an option that added an extra 20% to the price of luxury models. Citroën has also developed several active suspension models (see \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydractive\"\u003ehydractiv\u003c/a\u003ee). A recently publicised fully active system from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bose_Corporation\"\u003eBose Corporatio\u003c/a\u003en uses linear electric motors (i.e., solenoids) in place of hydraulic or pneumatic actuators that have generally been used up until recently.\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz\"\u003eMercedes\u003c/a\u003e introduced an active suspension system called\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_Body_Control\"\u003e Active Body Contro\u003c/a\u003el in its top-of-the-line\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CL-Class\"\u003e Mercedes-Benz CL-Clas\u003c/a\u003es in 1999.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSeveral \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_suspension\"\u003eelectromagnetic suspension\u003c/a\u003es have also been developed for vehicles. Examples include the electromagnetic suspension of Bose, and the electromagnetic suspension developed by prof. Laurentiu Encica. In addition, the new Michelin wheel with embedded suspension working on an electromotor is also similar.[20]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSprings\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003ePneumatic spring on a semitrailer\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eDampers or shock absorbers\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSemi-active and active suspensions\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eWith the help of control system, various semi-active/active suspensions realize an improved design compromise among different vibrations modes of the vehicle, namely bounce, roll, pitch and warp modes. However, the applications of these advanced suspensions are constrained by the cost, packaging, weight, reliability, and/or the other challenges.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eInterconnected suspension, unlike semi-active/active suspensions, could easily decouple different vehicle vibration modes in a passive manner. The interconnections can be realized by various means, such as mechanical, hydraulic and pneumatic. Anti-roll bars are one of the typical examples of mechanical interconnections, while it has been stated that fluidic interconnections offer greater potential and flexibility in improving both the stiffness and damping properties.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydropneumatic_suspension\"\u003eConsidering the considerable commercial potentials of hydro-pneumatic technology (Corolla, 1996), interconnected hydropneumati\u003c/a\u003ec suspensions have also been explored in some recent studies, and their potential benefits in enhancing vehicle ride and handling have been demonstrated. The control system can also be used for further improving performance of interconnected suspensions. Apart from academic research, an Australian company, Kinetic,[21] had some success (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Rally_Championship\"\u003eWRC\u003c/a\u003e: 3 Championships, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dakar_Rally\"\u003eDakar Rally\u003c/a\u003e: 2 Championships, Lexus GX470 2004 4×4 of the year with KDSS, 2005 PACE award) with various passive or semi-active systems, which generally decouple at least two vehicle modes (roll, warp (articulation), pitch and/or heave (bounce)) to simultaneously control each mode\u0027s stiffness and damping, by using interconnected shock absorbers, and other methods. In 1999, Kinetic was bought out by Tenneco. Later developments by a Catalan company, \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.creuat.com/\"\u003eCreuat\u003c/a\u003e has devised a simpler system design based on single-acting cylinders. After some projects on competition Creuat is active in providing retrofit systems for some vehicle models.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eHistorically, the first mass production car with front to rear mechanical interconnected suspension was the 1948 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_2CV\"\u003eCitroën 2CV\u003c/a\u003e. The suspension of the 2CV was extremely soft-the longitudinal link was making pitch softer instead of making roll stiffer. It relied on extreme antidive and antisquat geometries to compensate for that. This redunded into a softer axle crossing stiffness that anti-roll bars would have otherwise compromised. The leading arm / trailing arm \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trailing_arm\"\u003eswinging arm\u003c/a\u003e, fore-aft linked suspension system together with inboard front brakes had a much smaller unsprung weight than existing coil spring or leaf designs. The interconnection transmitted some of the force deflecting a front wheel up over a bump, to push the rear wheel down on the same side. When the rear wheel met that bump a moment later, it did the same in reverse, keeping the car level front to rear. The 2CV had a design brief to be able to be driven at speed over a ploughed field. It originally featured friction dampers and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuned_mass_damper\"\u003etuned mass damper\u003c/a\u003es. Later models had tuned mass dampers at the front with telescopic dampers/shock absorbers front and rear.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Motor_Corporation\"\u003eBritish Motor Corporatio\u003c/a\u003en was also an early adopter of interconnected suspension. A system dubbed \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrolastic\"\u003eHydrolasti\u003c/a\u003ec was introduced in 1962 on the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMC_ADO16\"\u003eMorris 1100\u003c/a\u003e and went on to be used on a variety of BMC models. Hydrolastic was developed by suspension engineer\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Moulton\"\u003eAlex Moulto\u003c/a\u003en and used rubber cones as the springing medium (these were first used on the 1959 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mini\"\u003eMini\u003c/a\u003e) with the suspension units on each side connected to each other by a fluid filled pipe. The fluid transmitted the force of road bumps from one wheel to the other (on the same principle as the Citroen 2CV\u0027s mechanical system described above) and because each suspension unit contained valves to restrict the flow of fluid also served as a shock absorber.[22] Moulton went on to develop a replacement for Hydrolastic for BMC\u0027s successor, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Leyland\"\u003eBritish Leyland\u003c/a\u003e. This system manufactured under licence by Dunlop in Coventry, called \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrolastic#Hydragas\"\u003eHydragas\u003c/a\u003e worked on the same principle but instead of rubber spring units it used metal spheres divided internally by a rubber diaphragm. The top half contained pressurised gas and the lower half the same fluid as used on the Hydrolastic system. The fluid transmitted suspension forces between the units on each side whilst the gas acted as the springing medium via the diaphragm. This is the same principle as the Citroen\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydropneumatic_suspension\"\u003ehydropneumati\u003c/a\u003ec system and provides a similar\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ride_quality\"\u003e ride qualit\u003c/a\u003ey but is self-contained and doesn\u0027t require an engine-driven pump to provide hydraulic pressure. The downside is that Hydragas is, unlike the Citroen system, not height adjustable or self-levelling. Hydragas was introduced in 1973 on the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin_Allegro\"\u003eAustin Allegr\u003c/a\u003eo and was used on several models, the last car to use it being the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MG_F_/_MG_TF\"\u003eMG \u003c/a\u003eF in 2002. The system was changed in favour of coil springs over dampers, due to cost reasons, towards the end of the vehicle\u0027s life. When it was decommissioned in 2006 the Hydragas manufacturing line was over 40 years old.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome of the last post-war\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packard\"\u003e Packard\u003c/a\u003e models also featured interconnected suspension.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eInterconnected suspensions\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSuspension geometry\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSuspension systems can be broadly classified into two subgroups: dependent and independent. These terms refer to the ability of opposite wheels to move independently of each other.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u003ci\u003edependent suspension\u003c/i\u003e normally has a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beam_axle\"\u003ebeam\u003c/a\u003e (a simple \u0027cart\u0027 axle) or (driven) live axle that holds wheels parallel to each other and perpendicular to the axle. When the camber of one wheel changes, the camber of the opposite wheel changes in the same way (by convention on one side this is a positive change in camber and on the other side this a negative change). \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Dion_tube\"\u003eDe Dion\u003c/a\u003e suspensions are also in this category as they rigidly connect the wheels together.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_suspension\"\u003e\u003ci\u003eindependent suspension\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e allows wheels to rise and fall on their own without affecting the opposite wheel. Suspensions with other devices, such as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sway_bar\"\u003esway bar\u003c/a\u003es that link the wheels in some way are still classed as independent.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA third type is a \u003ci\u003esemi-dependent\u003c/i\u003e suspension. In this case, the motion of one wheel does affect the position of the other but they are not rigidly attached to each other. A\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twist-beam_rear_suspension\"\u003etwist-beam rear suspensio\u003c/a\u003en is such a system.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDependent systems may be differentiated by the system of linkages used to locate them, both longitudinally and transversely. Often both functions are combined in a set of linkages.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of location linkages include:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSatchell link\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panhard_rod\"\u003ePanhard ro\u003c/a\u003ed\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watt%27s_linkage\"\u003eWatt\u0027s linkage\n\u003c/a\u003eWOBLink Mumford linkage\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leaf_spring\"\u003eLeaf spring\u003c/a\u003es used for location (transverse or longitudinal)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFully elliptical springs usually need supplementary location links and are no longer in common use\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLongitudinal semi-elliptical springs used to be common and still are used in heavy-duty trucks and aircraft. They have the advantage that the spring rate can easily be made progressive (non-linear).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA single transverse leaf spring for both front wheels and/or both\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company\"\u003eback wheels, supporting solid axles, was used by Ford Moto\u003c/a\u003er Company, before and soon after World War II, even on expensive models. It had the advantages of simplicity and low unsprung weight (compared to other solid axle designs).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn a front engine, rear-drive vehicle, dependent rear suspension is either \"live axle\" or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeDion_axle\"\u003edeDion axle\u003c/a\u003e, depending on whether or not the differential is carried on the axle. Live axle is simpler but the unsprung weight contributes to wheel bounce.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBecause it assures constant camber, dependent (and semi-independent) suspension is most common on vehicles that need to carry large loads as a proportion of the vehicle weight, that have relatively soft springs and that do not (for cost and simplicity reasons) use active suspensions. The use of dependent front suspension has become limited to heavier commercial vehicles.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eCommon types seen from behind; in order:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLive axle with Watt bar Suspension like on a bike fork Swing axle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eDouble wishbone suspension MacPherson\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis diagram is not exhaustive; notably excluding elements such as trailing arm links and those that are flexible.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eDependent suspensions\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIndependent suspensions\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe variety of independent systems is greater and includes:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swing_axle\"\u003eSwing axle\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_pillar\"\u003eSliding pillar\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacPherson_strut\"\u003eMacPherson stru\u003c/a\u003et/\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chapman_strut\"\u003eChapman stru\u003c/a\u003et\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eUpper and lower \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A-arm\"\u003eA-arm\u003c/a\u003e (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_wishbone_suspension\"\u003edouble wishbon\u003c/a\u003ee)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-link_suspension\"\u003eMulti-link suspensio\u003c/a\u003en\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi-trailing_arm_suspension\"\u003eSemi-trailing arm suspensio\u003c/a\u003en\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSwinging arm\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLeaf springs\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTransverse leaf springs when used as a suspension link, or four quarter elliptics on one end of a car are similar to wishbones in geometry, but are more compliant. Examples are the front of the original \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiat_500\"\u003eFiat 500\u003c/a\u003e, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panhard_Dyna_Z\"\u003ePanhard Dyna \u003c/a\u003eZ and the early examples of Peugeot 403 and the back of the AC Ace and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AC_Aceca\"\u003eAC Acec\u003c/a\u003ea.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBecause the wheels are not constrained to remain perpendicular to a flat road surface in turning, braking and varying load conditions, control of the wheel camber is an important issue. Swinging arm was common in small cars that were sprung softly and could carry large loads, because the camber is independent of load. Some active and semi-active suspensions maintain the ride height, and therefore the camber, independent of load. In\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_car\"\u003e sports car\u003c/a\u003es, optimal camber change when turning is more important.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWishbone and multi-link allow the engineer more control over the geometry, to arrive at the best compromise, than swing axle, MacPherson strut or swinging arm do; however the cost and space requirements may be greater. Semi-trailing arm is in between, being a variable compromise between the geometries of swinging arm and swing axle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn a semi-independent suspensions, the wheels of an axle are able to move relative to one another as in an independent suspension but the position of one wheel has an effect on the position and attitude of the other wheel. This effect is achieved via the twisting or deflecting of suspension parts under load. The most common type of semi-independent suspension is the twist beam.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twist-beam_rear_suspension\"\u003eTwist beam\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eTilting Suspension System\u003c/b\u003e[23] (Also known as \u003cb\u003eLeaning Suspension System\u003c/b\u003e) is not actually a different type or different geometry of construction, moreover it is a technology addition to the conventional suspension system.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis kind of suspension system mainly consist of independent suspension (e.g., \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacPherson_strut\"\u003eMacPherson stru\u003c/a\u003et, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A-arm\"\u003eA-arm\u003c/a\u003e (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_wishbone_suspension\"\u003edouble wishbone\u003c/a\u003e)). With addition with these suspension system there is a further tilting or leaning mechanism which connects the suspension system with the vehicle body (chassis).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis kind of suspension system improves stability, traction, turning radius of vehicle and comfort of riders as well. While turning right or left passengers or objects on a vehicle feel G-force or inertial force outward the radius of curvature that is why Two Wheeler riders lean towards the center of curvature while turning which improves stability and decrease the chances of toppling. But for vehicle more than two wheels and with conventional suspension system could not do the same till now so the passengers feel the outward inertial force which reduce the stability of passengers and comfort as well. This kind of tilting suspension system is the solution of the problem. If the road do not have \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cant_(road/rail)\"\u003esuper-elevation\u003c/a\u003e or banking it will not affect the comfort with this suspension system, the vehicle tilt and decrease the height of center of gravity with increase the stability. This is also used in fun vehicle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome trains also use tilting suspension \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tilting_train\"\u003e(Tilting Train\u003c/a\u003e) with increase the speed at cornering.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eA rear independent suspension on an\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-wheel_drive\"\u003eAWD\u003c/a\u003e car.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSemi-independent suspension\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eTilting Suspension System\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eRocker bogie mechanism\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cb\u003erocker-bogie\u003c/b\u003e system is the suspension arrangement in which there are some trailing arm fitted with some idler wheels, due to the articulation between the driving section and the followers this suspension is very flexible. this kind of suspension is appropriate for extremely rough terrain.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis kind of suspension was used in the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curiosity_(rover)\"\u003e \u003ci\u003eCuriosity\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e rover.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome vehicles such as trains run on long \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_(rail_transport)\"\u003erail track\u003c/a\u003es fixed to the ground, and some such as tractors, snow vehicles and tanks run on\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_track\"\u003econtinuous track\u003c/a\u003es that are part of the vehicle. Though either sort helps to smooth the path and reduce ground pressure, many of the same considerations apply.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eMilitary \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armoured_fighting_vehicle\"\u003eAFVs\u003c/a\u003e, including t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tank\"\u003eanks\u003c/a\u003e, have specialized suspension requirements. They can weigh more than seventy tons and are required to move as quickly as possible over very rough or soft ground. Their suspension components must be protected from \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_mine\"\u003eland mine\u003c/a\u003es and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antitank\"\u003eantitank\n\u003c/a\u003eweapons. Tracked AFVs can have as many as nine road wheels on each side. Many wheeled AFVs have six or eight large wheels. Some have a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Tire_Inflation_System\"\u003eCentral Tire Inflation System\u003c/a\u003e to reduce ground loading on poor surfaces. Some wheels are too big and confined to turn, so skid steering is used with some wheeled, as well as with tracked, vehicles.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe earliest tanks of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I\"\u003eWorld War I\u003c/a\u003e had fixed suspension with no designed movement whatsoever. This unsatisfactory situation was improved with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leaf_spring\"\u003eleaf spring\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coil_spring\"\u003ecoil spring\n\u003c/a\u003esuspensions adopted from agricultural, automotive or railway machinery, but even these had very limited travel.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpeeds increased due to more powerful engines, and the quality of ride had to be improved. In the 1930s, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christie_suspension\"\u003eChristie suspensio\u003c/a\u003en was developed, which allowed the use of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coil_spring\"\u003ecoil springs\u003c/a\u003e inside a vehicle\u0027s armored hull, by changing the direction of force deforming the spring, using a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_crank\"\u003ebell crank\u003c/a\u003e. The \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-34\"\u003eT-34\u003c/a\u003e\u0027s suspension was directly descended from Christie designs. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horstmann_suspension\"\u003eHorstmann suspensio\u003c/a\u003en was a variation which used a combination of bell crank and exterior coil springs, in use from the 1930s to the 1990s. The \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bogie\"\u003ebogie\u003c/a\u003e, but nonetheless independent, suspension of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M3_Lee\"\u003eM3 Lee\u003c/a\u003e/Grant and the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M4_Sherman\"\u003eM4 Sherma\u003c/a\u003en was similar to the Hortsmann type, with the suspension contained within the track oval.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBy \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II\"\u003eWorld War II\u003c/a\u003e the other common type was \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torsion_bar_suspension\"\u003etorsion bar suspensio\u003c/a\u003en, getting spring force from twisting bars inside the hull - this sometimes had less travel than the Christie-type, but was significantly more compact, allowing more space inside the hull, with consequent possibility to install larger turret rings and thus a heavier main armament. The torsion-bar suspension, sometimes including shock absorbers, has been the dominant heavy armored vehicle suspension since World War II. Torsion bars may take space under or near the floor, which may interfere with making the tank low to reduce exposure.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs with cars, wheel travel and spring rate affect the bumpiness of the ride and the speed at which rough terrain can be negotiated. It may be significant that a smooth ride, which is often associated with comfort, increases the accuracy when firing on the move (analogously to battle ships with reduced stability, due to reduced \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metacentric_height\"\u003emetacentric heigh\u003c/a\u003et). It also reduces shock on optics and other equipment. The unsprung weight and track link weight may limit speed on roads and affect the life of the track and other components.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMost German WW II half tracks and their tanks introduced during the war such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panther_tank\"\u003ePanther tan\u003c/a\u003ek had overlapping and sometimes interleaved road wheels to distribute the load more evenly on the track and therefore on the ground. This apparently made a significant contribution to speed, range and track life, as well as providing a continuous band of protection. It has not been used since the end of that war, probably due to the maintenance requirements of more complicated mechanical parts working in mud, sand,\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eTracked vehicles\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eArmoured fighting vehicle suspension\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M3_Grant\"\u003eGrant \u003c/a\u003eI tank\u0027s suspension has road wheels mounted on wheel trucks, or\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bogie\"\u003e\u003ci\u003ebogie\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003ci\u003es\u003c/i\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003erocks, snow and ice, as well as to cost. Rocks and frozen mud often got stuck between the overlapping wheels, which could prevent them from turning or cause damage to the road wheels. If one of the interior road wheels were damaged, it would require other road wheels to be removed in order to access the damaged road wheel, making the process more complicated and time-consuming.[24]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4-poster\"\u003e4-poste\u003c/a\u003er - a test rig\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/7_post_shaker\"\u003e7 post shake\u003c/a\u003er - a test rig for high speed vehicles\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_suspension_design\"\u003eAutomotive suspension desig\u003c/a\u003en - the design process\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caster_angle\"\u003eCaster angl\u003c/a\u003ee - self centering steering\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coilover\"\u003eCoilove\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corvette_leaf_spring\"\u003eCorvette leaf sprin\u003c/a\u003eg - independent suspension combined with a transverse fiber reinforced plastic leaf spring\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korres_P4\"\u003eKorres P\u003c/a\u003e4 - a Greek all-terrain supercar, with a unique suspension\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_levitation\"\u003eMagnetic levitatio\u003c/a\u003en\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maglev_train\"\u003eMaglev trai\u003c/a\u003en\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scrub_radius\"\u003eScrub radius\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short_long_arms_suspension\"\u003eShort long arms suspensio\u003c/a\u003en - also known as \"unequal length A arm\", one of the design parameters of double wishbone suspension\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strut_bar\"\u003eStrut ba\u003c/a\u003er - a form of semi-independent suspension\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oleo_strut\"\u003eOleo stru\u003c/a\u003et - design used in most large\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft\"\u003e aircraf\u003c/a\u003et, with compressed gas and\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydraulic_fluid\"\u003e hydraulic flui\u003c/a\u003ed - conceptually similar to automobile Hydropneumatic suspension\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e1. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://books.google.com/books?id\u003dPvsv78xj7UIC\u0026amp;printsec\u003dfrontcover\u0026amp;dq\u003dvehicle+dynamics\u0026amp;hl\u003den\u0026amp;sa\u003dX\u0026amp;ei\u003dRr3nT8KaO4Oq2QX016jaCQ\u0026amp;ved\u003d0CDcQ6AEwAA#v\u003donepage\u0026amp;q\u003dsuspension\u0026amp;f\u003dfalse\"\u003eReza N. Jazar (2008). \u003ci\u003eVehicle Dynamics: Theory and Applications\u003c/i\u003e (https://books.google.com/books?id\u003dPvsv78xj7U\u003c/a\u003eI C\u0026amp;printsec\u003dfrontcover\u0026amp;dq\u003dvehicle+dynamics\u0026amp;hl\u003den\u0026amp;sa\u003dX\u0026amp;ei\u003dRr3nT8KaO4Oq2QX016jaCQ\u0026amp;ved\u003d0CDcQ6AEwAA #v\u003donepage\u0026amp;q\u003dsuspension\u0026amp;f\u003dfalse). Spring. p. 455. London: Tata McGraw-Hill. pp. 293-294.\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number\"\u003e ISBN\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-07-044529-X\"\u003e0-07-044529-\u003c/a\u003eX. 8. Retrieved 2015-01-29.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSee also\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eReferences\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://auto.howstuffworks.com/car-suspension.htm\"\u003eHow Car Suspensions Work\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://books.google.co.uk/books?id\u003dM9gDAAAAMBAJ\u0026amp;pg\u003dPA128\u0026amp;lpg\u003dPA90\u0026amp;dq\u003dgyrocopter+ejection+seat\u0026amp;source\u003dbl\u0026amp;ots\u003dF6XdY0Bwxr\u0026amp;sig\u003dD-qy0YIKOrhLBxDFV7-jbgpwi8o\u0026amp;hl\u003den\u0026amp;ei\u003dkYKGTNG4Ksf84Abll6jSBA\u0026amp;sa\u003dX\u0026amp;oi\u003dbook_result\u0026amp;ct\u003dresult\u0026amp;resnum\u003d9\u0026amp;ved\u003d0CDcQ6AEwCA#v\u003donepage\u0026amp;q\u003dgyrocopter%20ejection%20seat\u0026amp;f\u003dtrue\"\u003eRobert W. Temple, \u003ci\u003eThe ABCs of Chassis Frame and Suspensions\u003c/i\u003e, September 196\u003c/a\u003e9\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.racingaspirations.com/suspensiongeometry.php\"\u003eSuspension Geometry Calculato\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003eRetrieved from \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dSuspension_(vehicle)\u0026amp;oldid\u003d807378421\"\u003ehttps://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dSuspension_(vehicle)\u0026amp;oldid\u003d8073784\u003c/a\u003e21\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eThis page was last edited on 27 October 2017, at 15:43.\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eText is available under the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Text_of_Creative_Commons_Attribution-ShareAlike_3.0_Unported_License\"\u003e Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike Licens\u003c/a\u003ee; additional terms may apply. (http://www.mitsubishi-motors.co.za/featuresites/mm_history/Galant.asp\u003c/a\u003e), Mitsubishi Motors\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://web.archive.org/web/20071230102112/http://www.mitsubishi-motors.co.za/featuresites/mm_history/Galant.asp\"\u003eSouth Africa website Archived
