Chevrolet Colorado, Mitsubishi Triton/L200 ,\n\nNissan Navara, Toyota Hilux\n\nFull-size pickup truck\n\nHeavy duty pickup truck\n\nSpecial purpose vehicle\n\nPickup Standardpickup truck\n\nLimousine Special purpose vehicle\n\nDodge Ram , Ford F-150 , GMC Sierra ,\n\nNissan Titan, Toyota Tundra\n\nChevrolet Silverado HD, Ram Heavy Duty , Ford Super Duty\n\n-\n\n- - - Lincoln MKTLivery\n\nStraddling the boundary between car and motorbike, these vehicles have engines under 1.0 litre, typically seat only two passengers, and are sometimes unorthodox in construction. Some microcars are three-wheelers, while the majority have four wheels. Microcars were popular in post-war Europe, where their appearance led them to be called \"Bubble cars\". More recent microcars are often electric powered.\n\nExamples of microcars:\n\nIsetta Smart Fortwo Tata Nano\n\nIn 2012, Japan\u0027s Transport and Tourism Ministry allowed local government to use ultracompact cars as transport for residents and tourists in their limiting areas. The size of ultracompact cars will be less than minicars, but have engine greater than 50cc displacement and able to transport 1 or 2 persons. Ultracompact cars cannot use minicars standard, because of strict safety standards for minicars. The regulation about running capacity and safety performance of ultracompact cars will be published in early autumn. Today, there are cars smaller than ultracompact cars, called category-1 motorized vehicles which it has 50cc displacement or less and only one seat for the driver.[19]\n\nA city car is a small automobile intended for use in urban areas. Unlike microcars, a city car\u0027s greater speed, capacity and (in perception at least) occupant protection are safer in mixed traffic environments and weather conditions. While city cars can reach highway speeds, that is not their intended use. In Japan, city cars are called kei cars.[20] Kei cars have to meet strict size and engine requirements: engines have a maximum displacement of 660 cc and the car\u0027s length must be under 3400 mm.\n\nExamples of kei cars:\n\nDaihatsu Move\n\nEconomy car\n\nMicrocar\n\nMicrocar Abaca\n\nHatchbacks\n\nUltracompact car\n\nCity car\n\nCitroën C1\n\nHonda Life\n\nSuzuki Cervo Examples of city cars:\n\nFiat Panda Maruti 800\n\nMini (Original 1959 model) Other small cars:\n\nCarver One Citroën Type C Smith Flyer\n\nThis class is known as supermini in the UK, subcompact in North America. Superminis have three, four or five doors, and even as an estate shape. They are designed to seat four passengers comfortably. Current supermini hatchbacks are approximately 3900 mm long, while saloons and estate cars are around 4200 mm long. Currently (2013) sedan variants are generally not available in Europe and are marketed at a lower price than hatchback models in North America.\n\nIn Europe, the first superminis were the Fiat 500 of 1957 and the Austin Mini of 1959. Superminis can be premium cars, such as the Citroën DS3, named 2010 Car of the Year by\n\nTop Gear Magazine. Superminis are some of the best selling vehicles in Europe with 25% of the market shares (2013). In 2007, the Peugeot 207 has been the most sold car in Europe, whereas the best seller is almost systematically a car from the compact segment.\n\nIn Australia, the motoring press tends to distinguish between a light car such as the Daihatsu Charade or early models of the Holden Barina, and slightly larger models such as the Ford Fiesta which is considered to be a small car. As the general size of vehicles in this class has gradually increased, the category of light car has almost disappeared.\n\nExamples of superminis/subcompact cars:\n\nOpel Corsa Peugeot 208 Volkswagen Polo\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Superminis\".\n\nSmall family/compact cars refer to the hatchbacks and shortest saloons and estate cars with similar size. They are approximately 4,250 mm (167 in) long in case of hatchbacks and 4,500 mm (177 in) in the case of saloons and estate cars. Compact cars have room for five adults and usually have engines between 1.4 and 2.2 litres, but some have engines of up to 2.5 litres.\n\nExamples of hatchback small family cars/compact cars:\n\nPeugeot 308 Toyota Auris Renault Megane\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small Family Cars\". In Australia, this class is generally referred to as being small-medium sized cars.\n\nSupermini/subcompact car\n\nRenault Clio IV\n\nFamily car\n\nSmall family car/compact car\n\nVolkswagen Golf\n\nTraditionally, mid-size cars are sedans, but recently cars such as the Citroën DS5, which is a large hatchback family car, have introduced other body styles.[21]\n\nA class described as \"large family\" in Europe and \"mid-size\" in the USA, these cars have room for five adults and a large trunk (boot). Engines are more powerful than small family/compact cars and six-cylinder engines are more common than in smaller cars. Car sizes vary from region to region; in Europe, large family cars are rarely over 4,700 mm (15.4 ft) long, while in North America, Middle East and Australasia they may be well over 4,800 mm (15.7 ft).\n\nExamples of large family cars/mid-size cars:\n\nChevrolet Malibu Ford Mondeo Kia Optima\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Large Family Cars\". These are known in Australia as Medium sized cars.\n\nThis term is used most in North America, Middle East and Australia where it refers to the largest affordable sedans on the market. Full-size cars may be well over 4,900 mm (16.1 ft) long.\n\nExamples of full-size cars:\n\nDodge Charger Ford Falcon Toyota Avalon [22]\n\nCrossover SUVs are derived from an automobile platform using a monocoque construction with light off-road capability and lower ground clearance than SUVs. They may be styled similar to conventional \"off-roaders\", or may be look similar to an estate car or station wagon.\n\nExamples of crossover SUVs:\n\nChevrolet Equinox Nissan Qashqai Tata Aria\n\nLarge family / mid-size\n\nCitroën DS5\n\nSaloons / sedans\n\nLarge family / mid-size\n\nToyota Camry\n\nFull size / large\n\nHolden Commodore\n\nCrossover SUV\n\nMitsubishi Outlander\n\nAlso known as \"people carriers\", this class of cars resembles tall estate cars. Larger MPVs may have seating for up to eight passengers. (Beyond that size, similar vehicles tend to be derived from vans (see below) and in Europe are called minibuses.)\n\nBeing taller than a family car improves visibility for the driver (while reducing visibility for other road users) and may help access for the elderly or disabled. They also offer more seats and increased load capacity than hatchbacks or estate cars.\n\nExamples of mini MPVs:\n\nCitroën C3 Picasso Ford B-Max Nissan Note Examples of compact MPVs:\n\nOpel Zafira Tourer Peugeot 5008 Renault Scénic\n\nBoth categories are equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small MPVs\".\n\nExamples of large MPVs / minivans:\n\nDodge Caravan Ford S-Max Mazda5\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"MPVs\".\n\nThese are luxurious equivalents to mid-size and compact cars. Rear seat room and trunk space are smaller than executive cars simply because of their smaller overall size.\n\nExamples of compact premium cars/entry-level luxury cars:\n\nAudi A4 BMW 3 Series Buick Regal\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Large Family Cars\".\n\nThese are luxurious equivalents to full-size cars. This also refers to the largest hatchbacks within the similar length in this class, such as the Porsche Panamera.\n\nExamples of executive cars/mid-luxury cars:\n\nPeugeot 607 Jaguar XF MG Magnette\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Executive Cars\".\n\nMinivans / MPVs\n\nRenault Espace, one of the first true minivans\n\nFord C-Max, a compact MPV\n\nOpel Meriva a mini MPV\n\nLuxury vehicle\n\nCompact executive\n\nLexus IS\n\nExecutive/mid-luxury\n\nBMW 5 Series\n\nFull-size luxury / Grand saloon\n\nAlso known as full-size luxury cars, grand saloons, or premium large cars, while\n\n\"Oberklasse\" is used in Germany. Typically a four-door saloon (sedan). These are the most powerful saloons, with six, eight and twelve-cylinder engines and have more equipment than smaller models. Vehicles in this category include some of the models from the flagship lines of luxury car brands, such as Cadillac CT6,[23] Lincoln Town Car and Maserati Quattroporte.\n\nExamples of grand saloons:\n\nAudi A8 Lexus LS BMW 7 Series\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Executive Cars\".\n\nA station wagon (also known as an estate or estate car) is an automobile with a body style variant of a sedan/saloon with its roof extended rearward over a shared passenger/cargo volume with access at the back via a third or fifth door (the liftgate or tailgate), instead of a trunk lid. The body style transforms a standard three-box design into a two-box design-to include an A, B, and C-pillar, as well as a D-pillar. Station wagons can flexibly reconfigure their interior volume via fold-down rear seats to prioritize either passenger or cargo volume.\n\nExamples of estates/station wagons:\n\nHyundai i40 Tourer Jaguar XF Sportbrake Mercedes-Benz CLS Shooting Brake\n\nA hot hatch is a high-performance hatchback, based on standard superminis or small family cars with improved performance, handling and styling. Hot hatches are very popular in Europe, where hatchbacks are by far the most common body style for this size of car. In North America, sport compacts are usually sold as saloons or coupés rather than hatchbacks.\n\nExamples of hot hatches:\n\nVolkswagen Golf GTi Peugeot 205 GTi Fiat 500 Abarth\n\nThese are high-performance versions of saloons. Sometimes originally homologated for production based motorsports (touring cars or rally cars) and like regular saloons, seats four or five people.\n\nExamples of sports saloons/sedans:\n\nBMW M5 Mazdaspeed6/Mazda 6 MPS Dodge Charger Examples of sport compact saloons/sedans:\n\nMercedes-Benz S-Class\n\nEstate cars / station wagons\n\nAudi A6 avant\n\nSports cars\n\nHot hatch\n\nPeugeot 205 GTI crowned \"The Greatest Ever Hot Hatch\"[24]\n\nSports saloon / sports sedan\n\nPontiac G8 GT\n\nDodge SRT-4\n\nLotus Cortina\n\nMitsubishi EVO\n\nThe term \"sports car\" does not appear to have a clear definition.[25] It is commonly used to describe vehicles which prioritise acceleration and handling; however, some people claim it is also defined as a vehicle with two seats.[26]\n\nA Sports car (sportscar or sport car) is a small, usually two-seat, two-door automobile designed for spirited performance and nimble handling.[27] Sports cars may be spartan or luxurious but high maneuverability and minimum weight are requisite.[28]\n\nExamples of sports cars:\n\nChevrolet Corvette Mazda MX-5 Porsche 911\n\nLarger, more powerful and heavier than sports cars, these vehicles typically have a FR layout and seating for four passengers (2+2). These are more expensive than sports cars but not as expensive as supercars. Grand Tourers encompass both luxury and high-performance. Some grand tourers are hand-built.\n\nExamples of grand tourers:\n\nAston Martin V8 Lexus SC300/400 Ferrari 612 Scaglietti\n\nSupercar is a term generally used for ultra-high-end exotic cars, whose performance is superior to that of its contemporaries. The proper application of the term is subjective and disputed, especially among enthusiasts.\n\nExamples of supercars:\n\nMcLaren P1 Koenigsegg Agera R Bugatti Veyron 16.4\n\nThe muscle car term generally refers to rear wheel drive mid-size cars with powerful V8 engines, typically manufactured in the U.S.[29][30] Some definitions limit it to two-door vehicles;[31] however, others include four-door body style versions.[32] Although opinions vary, it is generally accepted that classic muscle cars were produced in the late 1960s and early 1970s.[33][34][35][36] Muscle cars were also produced in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and other nations.\n\nExamples of American muscle cars from the 1960s and 1970s:\n\nFord Torino Plymouth Road Runner\n\nSports car\n\nJaguar E-Type\n\nGrand tourer\n\nMaserati GranTurismo\n\nSupercar\n\nLamborghini Countach\n\nMuscle car\n\n1970 AMC The Machine\n\nPontiac GTO Examples of Australian muscle cars:\n\nFord Falcon Holden Monaro Valiant Charger\n\nThe pony car is a class of American Muscle car[37] automobile launched and inspired by the Ford Mustang in 1964. It describes an affordable, compact, highly styled car with a sporty or performance-oriented image.[38][39]\n\nExamples of pony cars:\n\nAMC Javelin Chevrolet Camaro Dodge Challenger\n\nA body design that features a flexibly operating roof for open or enclosed mode driving. Also known as a cabriolet or roadster (if a 2-seater). Historically, convertibles used folding roof structures with fabric or other flexible materials. Some designs have roofs made of metal or other stiff materials that retract into the body.\n\nExamples of cabriolets:\n\nMazda MX-5 Honda S2000 Volvo C70\n\nOff-road vehicles, or \"off-roaders\" are sometimes referred to as \"four-wheel drives\", \"four by fours\", or 4x4s - this can happen colloquially in cases where certain models or even an entire range does not possess four-wheel drive.\n\nSport utility vehicles are off-road vehicles with four-wheel drive and true off-road capability. They most often feature high ground clearance and an upright, boxy body design. Sport Utilities are typically defined by a body on frame construction which offers more off-road capability but reduced on-road ride comfort and handling compared to a cross-over or car based utility vehicle.\n\nExamples of compact SUVs:\n\nLand Rover Freelander Jeep Patriot\n\nToyota FJ Cruiser\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small Off-Roaders\".\n\nPony car\n\n1966 Ford Mustang\n\nConvertible\n\nFull-sized convertible with its fabric covered top folded behind the rear seat\n\nOff-roaders\n\nSport utility vehicle\n\nJeep Commander\n\nExamples of SUVs:\n\nLand Rover Discovery Mitsubishi Pajero Mahindra Scorpio\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Large Off-Roaders\".\n\nIn some countries, the term \"van\" can refer to a small panel van based on a passenger car design (often the estate model / station wagon); it also refers to light trucks, which themselves are sometimes based on SUVs or MPVs. (But note that those retaining seats and windows, while being larger and more utilitarian than MPVs, may be called \"minibuses\".) The term is also used in the term \"camper van\" (or just \"camper\") - equivalent to a North American recreational vehicle (RV).\n\nIn the United States, the term \"van\" refers to vehicles that, like European minibuses, are even larger than large MPVs and are rarely seen being driven for domestic purposes - except for \"conversion vans\". These possess extremely large interior space and are often more intended for hauling cargo than people. Most vans use body-on-frame construction and are thus suitable for extensive modification and coachwork, known as conversion. Conversion vans are often quite luxurious, boasting comfortable seats, soft rides, built-in support for electronics such as television sets, and other amenities. The more elaborate conversion vans straddle the line between cars and recreational vehicles.\n\nExamples of North American \"vans\":\n\nDodge Ram Van Ford E-Series GMC Savana Examples of European \"vans\":\n\nFord Transit Volkswagen Transporter Mercedes-Benz Sprinter Examples of Japanese \"vans\"\n\nToyota Hiace Nissan NV\n\nBakkie\n\nA generic South African term for light pickup truck.[40]\n\nBaquet\n\nrefers to cars made in the early 1900s in Europe. Baquet means bath tub. These cars had two rows of raised seats similar to horse-drawn carriages. Baquets usually did not have front doors, a top, or windshield.[41]\n\nBuggy\n\nA Buggy is an automobile with wheels that project beyond the vehicle body.\n\nCabrio coach\n\nKia Sportage\n\nCommercial vehicle\n\nVan\n\nAmerican conversion van\n\nOther car classification terms\n\nNormally a two-door body design with special form of car roof, where a retractable textile cover amounts to a large sunroof.[42]\n\nCoupé\n\nA 2-door, 2- or 4-seat car with a fixed roof. Its doors are often longer than those of an equivalent sedan and the rear passenger area smaller; the roof may also be low. In cases where the rear seats are very small and not intended for regular use it is called a 2+2 (pronounced \"two plus two\"). Originally, a coupé was required to have only one side window per side, but this consideration has not been used for many years. Occasionally seen as Fixed Head Coupé, or FHC, particularly when referring to a hardtop version of a convertible.\n\nCombi Coupé\n\nA 2-door, 4-seat car with hatchback door at rear and, collapsible rear seats, resembling a fastback. The idea is to maximize the carrying capacity without bargaining on the performance.\n\nCoupé utility\n\nA passenger-car derived vehicle with an integral exterior cargo area.\n\nCrossover (or CUV) A loose marketing term to describe a vehicle that blends features of a SUV with features of a car - especially forgoing the body on frame construction of the SUV in favor of the car\u0027s unibody or monocoque construction. Crossovers usually borrow drivetrains and other parts from traditional cars in the same manufacturer\u0027s line. Crossovers typically employ an FF layout or an FF-based four-wheel drive layout with a transverse engine, rather than an FR layout or an FR-based 4WD layout with a longitudinal engine as is typically used on traditional truck-based SUVs.\n\nDrop Head Coupé\n\nOften abbreviated to DHC. Generally a European term referring to a 2-door, 4 place automobile with a retractable canvas / cloth top with both a padded headliner and rollup windows (as opposed to side curtains).\n\nEstate\n\nBritish name for a station wagon.\n\nFastback\n\nA design where the roof slopes at a smooth angle to the tail of the car, but the rear window does not open as a separate \"door\".\n\nFlower Car\n\nin US, similar to ute in Australia, i.e. generic for Chevy El Camino, Ford Ranchero, GMC Sprint/Diablo, etc.\n\nHatchback\n\nIncorporates a shared passenger and cargo volume, with rearmost accessibility via a rear third or fifth door, typically a top-hinged liftgate-and features such as fold-down rear seats to enable flexibility within the shared passenger/cargo volume. As a two-box design, the body style typically includes A, B and C-pillars, and may include a D-pillar.\n\nHardtop\n\nOriginally a removable solid roof on a convertible; later, also a fixed-roof car whose doors have no fixed window frames, which is designed to resemble such a convertible (sometimes also called\n\n\"Fixed Head Coupé\", or FHC.)\n\nHearse\n\nA converted car (often a station wagon), light truck or minivan usually used to transport the dead. Often longer and heavier than the vehicle on which they are usually based. Can sometimes double up as an ambulance in some countries, such as the United States, especially in rural areas.\n\nKammback\n\nOriginally, a car with a tapered rear that cuts off abruptly.\n\nLandaulet\n\nA limousine with the passenger section covered by a convertible top.\n\nLeisure activity vehicle\n\nA small van, generally related to a supermini, with a second or even a third seat row, and a large, tall boot.\n\nLiftback\n\nA broad marketing term for a hatchback, which incorporates a shared passenger and cargo volume, with rearmost accessibility via a top-hinged liftgate.\n\nLimousine\n\nBy definition, a chauffeur-driven car with a (normally glass-windowed) division between the front seats and the rear. In German, the term simply means a sedan.\n\nMicrovan\n\nTerm for a boxy wagon-type of car that is smaller than a conventional minivan; often without rear sliding door(s). Examples are Citroën Picasso, Renault Scénic, Toyota Yaris Verso or Mercedes-Benz A-Class. In Japan, this term is used for Kei car based vans.\n\nMinibus\n\nDesigned to carry fewer people than a full-size bus, generally up to 16 people in multiple rows of seats. Passenger access in normally via a sliding door on one side of the vehicle. One example of a van with a minibus version available is the Ford Transit.\n\nMPV\n\nMulti-purpose vehicle, a large car or small bus designed to be used on and off-road and easily convertible to facilitate loading of goods from facilitating carrying people.\n\nNotchback\n\nA configuration where the third box of a three-box styling configuration is less pronounced - especially where the rear deck (third box) is short or where the rear window is upright.\n\nPeople carrier or people mover\n\nEuropean name to describe what is usually referred to in North America as a Minivan.\n\nPhaeton\n\nA Phaeton is a style of open car or carriage without proper weather protection for passengers.\n\nPickup truck (or pickup) A light-duty, open-bed truck.\n\nPillarless\n\nUsually a prefix to coupé, fastback, or hardtop; completely open at the sides when the windows are down, without a central pillar, e.g. the Sunbeam Rapier fastback coupé.\n\nRagtop\n\nOriginally an open car like a roadster, but with a soft top (cloth top) that can be raised or lowered. Unlike a convertible, it had no roll-up side windows. Now often used as slang for a convertible.\n\nRetractable Hardtop\n\naka Coupé convertible or Coupé Cabriolet. A type of convertible forgoing a foldable textile roof in favor of a multi-segment rigid roof retracts into the lower bodywork.\n\nRoadster\n\nOriginally a two-seat open car with minimal weather protection - without top or side glass - though possibly with optional hard or soft top and side curtains (i.e., without roll-up glass windows). In modern usage, the term means simply a two-seat sports car convertible, a variation of spyder.\n\nSedan\n\nA car seating four or more with a fixed roof that is full-height up to the rear window. Known in British English as a saloon. Sedans can have 2 or 4-doors. This is the most common body style. In the U.S., this term has been used to denote a car with fixed window frames, as opposed to the hardtop\n\nstyle wherein the sash, if any, winds down with the glass.\n\nSedan delivery\n\nNorth American term for a vehicle similar to a wagon but without side windows, similar to a panel truck but with two doors (one on each side), and one or two rear doors\n\nSport utility vehicle (SUV) Derivative of a pickup truck or 4-wheel-drive vehicle, but with fully enclosed passenger cabin interior and carlike levels of interior equipment.\n\nSpyder (or Spider) Similar to a roadster but originally with less weather protection.Nowadays it simply means a convertible with two seater only. The name comes from the old carriages with two seats and no roof, whose small central cabin and big wheels at the corners are reminiscent of a spider.\n\nShooting-brake\n\nInitially a vehicle used to carry shooting parties with their equipment and game; later used to describe custom-built wagons by high-end coachbuilders, subsequently synonymous with station wagon or estate; and in contemporary usage a three or five-door wagons combining features of a wagon and a coupé.\n\nStation wagon\n\nA variant of a sedan/saloon, (also known as estate or estate car) or with its roof extended rearward over a shared passenger/cargo volume; access at the back via a third or fifth door instead of a trunk lid; flexible configurations to vary passenger or cargo volume; and two or three rows of seating - in a two-box design with a A, B \u0026 C-pillar, as well as a D pillar.\n\nT-top\n\nA derivative of the Targa top, called a T-bar roof, this fixed-roof design has two removable panels and retains a central narrow roof section along the front to back axis of the car (e.g. Toyota MR2 Mark I.)\n\nTarga top\n\nA semi-convertible style used on some sports cars, featuring a fully removable hard top roof panel which leaves the A and B pillars in place on the car body.\n\nTown car (US) Essentially the inverse of the landaulet, a historical body style in which the front seats were open and the rear compartment closed, normally with a removable top to cover the front chauffeur\u0027s compartment. In Europe the style is also known as Sedanca de Ville, often shortened to Sedanca or de Ville. Note that the modern Lincoln Town Car derives its name, but nothing else, from this style.\n\nUte\n\nA term used originally in Australia and New Zealand to describe usually two-wheel-drive, traditionally passenger vehicles with a cargo tray in the rear integrated with the passenger body; as opposed to a pickup whose cargo tray is not integrated with the passenger body.\n\nWagon delivery\n\nNorth American term (mainly U.S. and Canada). Similar to a sedan delivery, with four doors.\n\nVan\n\nIn North America \"van\" refers to a truck-based commercial vehicle of the wagon style, whether used for passenger or commercial use. Usually a van has no windows at the side rear (panel van), although for passenger use, side windows are included. In other parts of the world, \u0027van\u0027 denotes a passenger-based wagon with no rear side windows.\n\nSome non-English language terms are familiar from their use on imported vehicles in English-speaking nations even though the terms have not been adopted into English.\n\nBarchetta\n\nItalian term for a roadster with no roof. The name, roughly \"small boat\", comes from an exclamation when the Ferrari 166MM Touring was shown.\n\nNon-English terms\n\nBerlina\n\nItalian term for a sedan. Berline\n\nFrench term for a sedan. Berlinetta\n\nItalian term for a sport coupé. Break\n\nFrench term for a station wagon. Camioneta\n\nBrazilian Portuguese term for a station wagon (specially in the state of Rio de Janeiro). Spanish term also used in Argentina and Uruguay. Carrinha\n\nPortuguese term for a station wagon. Not used in Brazilian Portuguese. Espada\n\nPortuguese nickname for a limousine (the same word for Sword - long piece of metal). Not used in Brazilian Portuguese. Furgoneta\n\nSpanish and Polish term for a van, in the latter language almost always used in its diminutive form furgonetka. Furgão\n\nPortuguese alternative term (less used) for a van. Used in Brazilian Portuguese, most often for vans but sometimes for panel van variants of passenger cars. Kombi\n\nis a German abbreviation of \"Kombinationswagen\" (Combination Car) and it is German name for station wagon. Since Germany is a major producer of cars for many European countries, the term Kombi in this meaning is also used in Swedish, Czech, Slovak, Polish, Slovenian, Serbian, Bosnian, Croatian, Hungarian, Spanish, Portuguese, Bulgarian. In Afrikaans and in Australia, Kombi is also used to refer to a Volkswagen Microbus. In Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay the word specifically refers to the VW Microbus. Perua\n\nBrazilian Portuguese term either designating a van (especially as spoken in the city of São Paulo) or a station wagon (in the city of Rio de Janeiro). Turismo\n\nSpanish term for a sedan. Literally means tourism, used mostly in Latin American countries and Spain. Ijapa\n\nYoruba term for a two door car. Literally modeled after a Tortoise animal. Also refers to Volkswagen Beetle. Vagoneta\n\nBolivian Spanish Colloquial term for a station wagon (with o without SUV capabilities).\n\nACRISS Car Classification Code Car color\n\nCar safety and road safety\n\nProduction vehicle\n\nThree-wheeler\n\nTruck classification\n\nVehicle category\n\nVehicle size class\n\n1. This article details commonly used classification schemes in use worldwide.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e1 Classification methods\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e2 Size and usage-based vehicle classification systems worldwide 3 Economy car\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e3.1 Microcar 3.2 Hatchbacks\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e3.2.1 Ultracompact car 3.2.2 City car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e3.2.3 Supermini/subcompact car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e4 Family car\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4.1 Small family car/compact car 4.2 Large family / mid-size\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e5 Saloons / sedans\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e5.1 Large family / mid-size 5.2 Full size / large 5.3 Crossover SUV\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e5.4 Minivans / MPVs\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e6 Luxury vehicle\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e6.1 Compact executive 6.2 Executive/mid-luxury\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e6.3 Full-size luxury / Grand saloon\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e6.4 Estate cars / station wagons\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e7 Sports cars\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7.1 Hot hatch\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7.2 Sports saloon / sports sedan 7.3 Sports car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7.4 Grand tourer\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7.5 Supercar\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7.6 Muscle car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7.7 Pony car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7.8 Convertible\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e8 Off-roaders\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e8.1 Sport utility vehicle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e9 Commercial vehicle\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e9.1 Van\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e10 Other car classification terms\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e10.1 Non-English terms\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e11 See also 12 References 13 External links\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eContents\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eClassification methods\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eVehicles can be categorized in numerous ways. For example, by means of the body style and the \"level of commonality in vehicle construction as defined by number of doors and roof treatment (e.g., sedan, convertible, fastback, hatchback) and number of seats\" that require \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seat_belt\"\u003eseat belt\u003c/a\u003es to meet safety regulations.[1]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eRegulatory agencies may also establish a vehicle classification system for determining a tax amount. In the United Kingdom, a vehicle is taxed according to the vehicle\u0027s construction, engine, weight, type of fuel and emissions, as well as the purpose for which it is used.[2] Other jurisdictions may determine vehicle tax based upon environmental principles, such as the user pays principle.[3] In another example, certain cities in the United States in the 1920s chose to exempt electric-powered vehicles because officials believed those vehicles did not cause \"substantial wear upon the pavements\".[4]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAnother standard for road vehicles of all types that is used internationally (except for Australia, India, and the U.S.) is ISO 3833-1977.[5]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn an example from private enterprise, many car rental companies use the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACRISS_Car_Classification_Code\"\u003eACRISS Car Classification Code\u003c/a\u003e to describe the size, type and equipment of vehicles to ensure that rental agents can match customer needs to available vehicles, regardless of distance between the agent and the rental company or the languages spoken by either party. In the United States, since 2010 the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insurance_Institute_for_Highway_Safety\"\u003eInsurance Institute for Highway Safety\n\u003c/a\u003euses a scheme it has developed that takes into account a combination of both vehicle shadow (length times width) and weight.[6]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eUS Highway Loss Data Institute classification\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eDefinition\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eRegular Two Door \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eTwo door sedans and hatchbacks\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eRegular Four Door \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eFour door sedans and hatchbacks\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eStation Wagons \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eFour doors, a rear hatch and four pillars\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eMinivans \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eVans with sliding rear doors\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eSports \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eTwo seaters and cars with significant high performance features\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eLuxury\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eRelatively expensive cars that are not classified as sports (price in USD to curb weight in pounds more than 9.0 in 2010) (small cars over $27,000, midsize cars over $31,500, large cars over $36,000, etc.)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd colspan\u003d\"5\"\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eUS Insurance Institute for Highway Safety | Highway Loss Data Institute \u0027Guide to car size groups\u0027 (includes minivans)\u003c/b\u003e[7]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e-\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003ePickup trucks \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003ePU \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e-\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eVans \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eVAN \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e-\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe United States \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Highway_Administration\"\u003eFederal Highway Administratio\u003c/a\u003en has developed a classification scheme used for automatically calculating road use t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toll_road\"\u003eolls\u003c/a\u003e. There are two broad categories depending on whether the vehicle carries passengers or commodities. Vehicles that carry commodities are further subdivided by number of axles and number of units, including both power and trailer units.[10]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency\"\u003eUnited States Environmental Protection Agency\u003c/a\u003e (US EPA) has developed a classification scheme used to compare fuel economy among similar vehicles. Passenger vehicles are classified based on a vehicle\u0027s total interior passenger and cargo volumes. Trucks are classified based upon their gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR). Heavy duty vehicles are not included within the EPA scheme.[11]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eUS EPA car class \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eTotal passenger and cargo volume (cu. ft.)\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eTwo-seaters \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd rowspan\u003d\"7\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eAny (designed to seat only two adults) Less than 85 cu ft (2,400 l) 85 to 99 cu ft (2,400-2,800 l) 100 to 109 cu ft (2,850-3,100 l) 110 to 119 cu ft (3,100-3,350 l) 120 cu ft (3,400 l) or more Less than 130 cu ft (3,700 l) 130 to 159 cu ft (3,700-4,500 l)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eMinicompact \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003estation wagon\u003c/a\u003es \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA similar set of classes is used by the Canadian EPA.[12] The Canadian National Collision Database (NCDB) system defines \"passenger car\" as a unique class, but also identifies two other categories involving passenger vehicles-the \"passenger van\" and \"light utility vehicle\"-and these categories are inconsistently handled across the country with the boundaries between the vehicles increasingly blurred.[13]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Australia, the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries publishes its own classifications.[14]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis is a summary table listing several diferent methods of vehicle truck\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpecial purpose vehicle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003ePickup \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eStandardpickup truck\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limousine\"\u003eLimousine\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eSpecial purpose vehicle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodge_Ram\"\u003eDodge Ram \u003c/a\u003e, Ford F-150 ,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GMC_Sierra\"\u003eGMC Sierra \u003c/a\u003e,\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eNissan Titan,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Tundra\"\u003eToyota Tundra\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet_Silverado\"\u003eChevrolet Silverado HD, Ram\n\u003c/a\u003eHeavy Duty ,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Super_Duty\"\u003eFord Super Duty\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e- \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e- - - \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_MKT#Livery_Use\"\u003eLincoln MKTLivery\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eStraddling the boundary between car and motorbike, these vehicles have engines under 1.0 litre, typically seat only two passengers, and are sometimes unorthodox in construction. Some microcars are three-wheelers, while the majority have four wheels. Microcars were popular in post-war Europe, where their appearance led them to be called \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bubble_car\"\u003eBubble cars\u003c/a\u003e\". More recent microcars are often electric powered.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of microcars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isetta\"\u003eIsett\u003c/a\u003ea\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_Fortwo\"\u003eSmart Fortw\u003c/a\u003eo\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Nano\"\u003eTata Nano\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn 2012, Japan\u0027s Transport and Tourism Ministry allowed local government to use ultracompact cars as transport for residents and tourists in their limiting areas. The size of ultracompact cars will be less than minicars, but have engine greater than 50cc displacement and able to transport 1 or 2 persons. Ultracompact cars cannot use minicars standard, because of strict safety standards for minicars. The regulation about running capacity and safety performance of ultracompact cars will be published in early autumn. Today, there are cars smaller than ultracompact cars, called category-1 motorized vehicles which it has 50cc displacement or less and only one seat for the driver.[19]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA city car is a small automobile intended for use in urban areas. Unlike microcars, a city car\u0027s greater speed, capacity and (in perception at least) occupant protection are safer in mixed traffic environments and weather conditions. While city cars can reach \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Highway\"\u003ehighway\u003c/a\u003e speeds, that is not their intended use. In Japan, city cars are called\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kei_car\"\u003e kei car\u003c/a\u003es.[20] Kei cars have to meet strict size and engine requirements: engines have a maximum displacement of 660 cc and the car\u0027s length must be under 3400 mm.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of kei cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daihatsu_Move\"\u003eDaihatsu Mov\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eEconomy car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eMicrocar\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eMicrocar Abaca\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eHatchbacks\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eUltracompact car\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCity car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C1\"\u003eCitroën C1\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honda_Life\"\u003eHonda Lif\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suzuki_Cervo\"\u003eSuzuki Cervo\n\u003c/a\u003eExamples of city cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiat_Panda\"\u003eFiat Pand\u003c/a\u003ea\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maruti_800\"\u003eMaruti 80\u003c/a\u003e0\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mini\"\u003eMini\u003c/a\u003e (Original 1959 model) Other small cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carver_(automobile)\"\u003eCarver One\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Type_C\"\u003eCitroën Type C\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smith_Flyer\"\u003eSmith Flye\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis class is known as \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermini\"\u003esupermin\u003c/a\u003ei in the UK, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subcompact_car\"\u003esubcompac\u003c/a\u003et in North America. Superminis have three, four or five doors, and even as an estate shape. They are designed to seat four passengers comfortably. Current supermini hatchbacks are approximately 3900 mm long, while saloons and estate cars are around 4200 mm long. Currently (2013) sedan variants are generally not available in Europe and are marketed at a lower price than hatchback models in North America.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Europe, the first superminis were the Fiat 500 of 1957 and the Austin Mini of 1959. Superminis can be premium cars, such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS3\"\u003eCitroën DS3\u003c/a\u003e, named 2010 Car of the Year by\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Top_Gear_Magazine\"\u003eTop Gear Magazin\u003c/a\u003ee. Superminis are some of the best selling vehicles in Europe with 25% of the market shares (2013). In 2007, the Peugeot 207 has been the most sold car in Europe, whereas the best seller is almost systematically a car from the \u003ci\u003ecompact\u003c/i\u003e segment.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn Australia, the motoring press tends to distinguish between a \u003cb\u003elight car\u003c/b\u003e such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daihatsu_Charade\"\u003eDaihatsu Charad\u003c/a\u003ee or early models of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holden_Barina\"\u003eHolden Barin\u003c/a\u003ea, and slightly larger models such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Fiesta\"\u003eFord Fiesta\u003c/a\u003e which is considered to be a \u003cb\u003esmall car.\u003c/b\u003e As the general size of vehicles in this class has gradually increased, the category of \u003cb\u003elight car\u003c/b\u003e has almost disappeared.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of superminis/subcompact cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opel_Corsa\"\u003eOpel Cors\u003c/a\u003ea\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot_208\"\u003ePeugeot 20\u003c/a\u003e8\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Polo\"\u003eVolkswagen Pol\u003c/a\u003eo\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Superminis\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSmall family/compact cars refer to the hatchbacks and shortest saloons and estate cars with similar size. They are approximately 4,250 mm (167 in) long in case of hatchbacks and 4,500 mm (177 in) in the case of saloons and estate cars. Compact cars have room for five adults and usually have engines between 1.4 and 2.2 litres, but some have engines of up to 2.5 litres.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of hatchback small family cars/compact cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot_308\"\u003ePeugeot 30\u003c/a\u003e8\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Auris\"\u003eToyota Auri\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault_Megane\"\u003eRenault Megan\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small Family Cars\". In Australia, this class is generally referred to as being \u003cb\u003esmall-medium\u003c/b\u003e sized cars.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eSupermini/subcompact car\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault_Clio\"\u003eRenault Cli\u003c/a\u003eo IV\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eFamily car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSmall family car/compact car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf\"\u003eVolkswagen Gol\u003c/a\u003ef\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003eTraditionally, mid-size cars are sedans, but recently cars such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS5\"\u003eCitroën DS\u003c/a\u003e5, which is a large hatchback family car, have introduced other body styles.[21]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA class described as \"large family\" in Europe and \"mid-size\" in the USA, these cars have room for five adults and a large trunk (boot). Engines are more powerful than small family/compact cars and six-cylinder engines are more common than in smaller cars. Car sizes vary from region to region; in Europe, large family cars are rarely over 4,700 mm (15.4 ft) long, while in North America, Middle East and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australasia\"\u003eAustralasia\u003c/a\u003e they may be well over 4,800 mm (15.7 ft).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of large family cars/mid-size cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet_Malibu\"\u003eChevrolet Malib\u003c/a\u003eu\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Mondeo\"\u003eFord Mondeo\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kia_Optima\"\u003eKia Optima\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Large Family Cars\". These are known in Australia as \u003cb\u003eMedium\u003c/b\u003e sized cars.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis term is used most in North America, Middle East and Australia where it refers to the largest affordable sedans on the market. Full-size cars may be well over 4,900 mm (16.1 ft) long.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of full-size cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodge_Charger_(LX)\"\u003eDodge Charge\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Falcon_(Australia)\"\u003eFord Falco\u003c/a\u003en\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Avalon\"\u003eToyota Avalon\u003c/a\u003e [22]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCrossover SUVs are derived from an \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile_platform\"\u003eautomobile platform\u003c/a\u003e using a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monocoque\"\u003emonocoqu\u003c/a\u003ee construction with light off-road capability and lower ground clearance than SUVs. They may be styled\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003esimilar to conventional \"off-roaders\", or may be look similar to an estate car or statio\u003c/a\u003en wagon.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of crossover SUVs:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet_Equinox\"\u003eChevrolet Equino\u003c/a\u003ex\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan_Qashqai\"\u003eNissan Qashqa\u003c/a\u003ei\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Aria\"\u003eTata Ari\u003c/a\u003ea\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eLarge family / mid-size\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS5\"\u003eCitroën DS\u003c/a\u003e5\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSaloons / sedans\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eLarge family / mid-size\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Camry\"\u003eToyota Camr\u003c/a\u003ey\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eFull size / large\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holden_Commodore\"\u003eHolden Commodor\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCrossover SUV\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_Outlander\"\u003eMitsubishi Outlande\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAlso known as \"people carriers\", this class of cars resembles tall estate cars. Larger MPVs may have seating for up to eight passengers. (Beyond that size, similar vehicles tend to be derived from vans (see below) and in Europe are called\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minibus\"\u003e minibuses\u003c/a\u003e.)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBeing taller than a family car improves visibility for the driver (while reducing visibility for other road users) and may help access for the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_age\"\u003eelderly\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disability\"\u003edisable\u003c/a\u003ed. They also offer more seats and increased load capacity than hatchbacks or estate cars.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of mini MPVs:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C3_Picasso\"\u003eCitroën C3 Picass\u003c/a\u003eo\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_B-Max\"\u003eFord B-Ma\u003c/a\u003ex\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan_Note\"\u003eNissan Not\u003c/a\u003ee Examples of compact MPVs:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opel_Zafira_Tourer\"\u003eOpel Zafira Tourer\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot_5008\"\u003ePeugeot 500\u003c/a\u003e8\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault_Sc%C3%A9nic\"\u003eRenault Scéni\u003c/a\u003ec\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBoth categories are equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small MPVs\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of large MPVs / minivans:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodge_Caravan\"\u003eDodge Caravan\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_S-Max\"\u003eFord S-Ma\u003c/a\u003ex\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazda5\"\u003eMazda5\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"MPVs\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThese are luxurious equivalents to mid-size and compact cars. Rear seat room and trunk space are smaller than executive cars simply because of their smaller overall size.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of compact premium cars/entry-level luxury cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi_A4\"\u003eAudi A4\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMW_3_Series\"\u003eBMW 3 Serie\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buick_Regal\"\u003eBuick Rega\u003c/a\u003el\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis category is equivalent to the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EuroNCAP\"\u003e EuroNCA\u003c/a\u003eP class \"Large Family Cars\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThese are luxurious equivalents to full-size cars. This also refers to the largest hatchbacks within the similar length in this class, such as the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_Panamera\"\u003e Porsche Panamer\u003c/a\u003ea.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of executive cars/mid-luxury cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot_607\"\u003ePeugeot MPVs\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renault_Espace\"\u003eRenault Espac\u003c/a\u003ee, one of the first true minivans\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_C-Max\"\u003eFord C-Max\u003c/a\u003e, a compact MPV\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eLuxury vehicle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eCompact executive\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eLexus IS\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eExecutive/mid-luxury\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMW_5_Series\"\u003eBMW 5 Serie\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eFull-size luxury / Grand saloon\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAlso known as full-size luxury cars, grand saloons, or premium large cars, while\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\"Oberklasse\" is used in Germany. Typically a four-door saloon (sedan). These are the most powerful saloons, with six, eight and twelve-cylinder engines and have more equipment than smaller models. Vehicles in this category include some of the models from the flagship lines of luxury car brands, such as Cadillac CT6,[23] Lincoln Town Car and Maserati Quattroporte.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of grand saloons:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audi_A8\"\u003eAudi A8\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexus_LS\"\u003eLexus L\u003c/a\u003eS\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMW_7_Series\"\u003eBMW 7 Serie\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Executive Cars\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u003cb\u003estation wagon\u003c/b\u003e (also known as an \u003cb\u003eestate\u003c/b\u003e or \u003cb\u003eestate car\u003c/b\u003e) is an automobile with a body style variant of a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(automobile)\"\u003esedan/saloo\u003c/a\u003en with its roof extended rearward over a shared passenger/cargo volume with access at the back via a third or fifth door (the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liftgate\"\u003eliftgat\u003c/a\u003ee or tailgate), instead of a trunk lid. The body style transforms a standard t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-box_styling\"\u003ehree-bo\u003c/a\u003ex design into a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-box_styling#One-box_and_Two-Box_design\"\u003etwo-box\u003c/a\u003e design-to include an \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pillar_(car)\"\u003eA, B, and C-pillar\u003c/a\u003e, as well as a D-pillar. Station wagons can flexibly reconfigure their interior volume via fold-down rear seats to prioritize either passenger or cargo volume.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of estates/station wagons:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyundai_i40\"\u003eHyundai i40 Tourer\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaguar_XF\"\u003eJaguar XF Sportbrak\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CLS\"\u003eMercedes-Benz CLS Shooting Brak\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u003cb\u003ehot hatch\u003c/b\u003e is a high-performance hatchback, based on standard superminis or small family cars with improved performance, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car_handling\"\u003ehandlin\u003c/a\u003eg and styling. Hot hatches are very popular in Europe, where hatchbacks are by far the most common body style for this size of car. In North America, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_compacts\"\u003esport compact\u003c/a\u003es are usually sold as saloons or coupés rather than hatchbacks.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of hot hatches:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf\"\u003eVolkswagen Golf GTi\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot_205_GTi\"\u003ePeugeot 205 GTi\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiat_500_(2007)\"\u003eFiat 500 Abart\u003c/a\u003eh\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThese are high-performance versions of saloons. Sometimes originally \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homologation\"\u003ehomologate\u003c/a\u003ed for production based motorsports (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Touring_car_racing\"\u003etouring car\u003c/a\u003es or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rally_car\"\u003erally car\u003c/a\u003es) and like regular saloons, seats four or five people.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of sports saloons/sedans:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca S-Clas\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eEstate cars / station wagons\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAudi A6 href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_EVO\"\u003eMitsubishi EV\u003c/a\u003eO\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe term \"sports car\" does not appear to have a clear definition.[25] It is commonly used to describe vehicles which prioritise acceleration and handling; however, some people claim it is also defined as a vehicle with two seats.[26] \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA \u003cb\u003eSports car\u003c/b\u003e (sportscar or sport car) is a small, usually two-seat, two-door \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile\"\u003eautomobil\u003c/a\u003ee designed for spirited performance and nimble handling.[27] Sports cars may be spartan or luxurious but high maneuverability and minimum weight are requisite.[28]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of sports cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet_Corvette\"\u003eChevrolet Corvett\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazda_MX-5\"\u003eMazda MX-\u003c/a\u003e5\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_911\"\u003ePorsche 911\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLarger, more powerful and heavier than sports cars, these vehicles typically have a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FR_layout\"\u003eFR layou\u003c/a\u003et and seating for four passengers (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2%2B2_(car_body_style)\"\u003e2+2\u003c/a\u003e). These are more expensive than sports cars but not as expensive as supercars. Grand Tourers encompass both luxury and high-performance. Some grand tourers are hand-built.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of grand tourers:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aston_Martin_V8\"\u003eAston Martin V\u003c/a\u003e8\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexus_SC400#First_generation_.281992-2001.29\"\u003eLexus SC300/40\u003c/a\u003e0\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrari_612_Scaglietti\"\u003eFerrari 612 Scagliett\u003c/a\u003ei\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSupercar is a term generally used for ultra-high-end exotic cars, whose performance is superior to that of its contemporaries. The proper application of the term is subjective and disputed, especially among enthusiasts.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of supercars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McLaren_P1\"\u003eMcLaren P1\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koenigsegg_Agera_R\"\u003eKoenigsegg Agera \u003c/a\u003eR\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bugatti_Veyron_16.4\"\u003eBugatti Veyron 16.\u003c/a\u003e4\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cb\u003emuscle car\u003c/b\u003e term generally refers to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rear_wheel_drive\"\u003erear wheel drive\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-size_car\"\u003emid-size cars\u003c/a\u003e with powerful V8 engines, typically manufactured in the U.S.[29][30] Some definitions limit it to two-door vehicles;[31] however, others include four-door body style versions.[32] Although opinions vary, it is generally accepted that classic muscle cars were produced in the late 1960s and early 1970s.[33][34][35][36] Muscle cars were also produced in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and other nations.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of American muscle cars from the 1960s and 1970s:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Torino\"\u003eFord Torino\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca Charge\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pony_car\"\u003epony car\u003c/a\u003e is a class of American \u003ca It describes an affordable, compact, highly styled car with a sporty or performance-oriented image.[38][39]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of pony cars:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_Javelin\"\u003eAMC Javelin\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chevrolet_Camaro\"\u003eChevrolet Camar\u003c/a\u003eo\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodge_Challenger\"\u003eDodge Challenge\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA body design that features a flexibly operating roof for open or enclosed mode driving. Also known as a \u003cb\u003ecabriolet\u003c/b\u003e or \u003cb\u003eroadster\u003c/b\u003e (if a 2-seater). Historically, convertibles used folding roof structures with fabric or other flexible materials. Some designs have roofs made of metal or other stiff materials that retract into the body.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of cabriolets:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazda_MX-5\"\u003eMazda MX-\u003c/a\u003e5\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honda_S2000\"\u003eHonda S200\u003c/a\u003e0\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volvo_C70\"\u003eVolvo C70\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eOff-road vehicles, or \"off-roaders\" are sometimes referred to as \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-wheel_drive\"\u003efour-wheel drive\u003c/a\u003es\", \"four by fours\", or 4x4s - this can happen colloquially in cases where certain models or even an entire range does not posses\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-wheel_drive\"\u003es four-wheel driv\u003c/a\u003ee.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSport utility vehicles are \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Off-road_vehicle\"\u003eoff-road vehicle\u003c/a\u003es with four-wheel drive and true off-road capability. They most often feature high ground clearance and an upright, boxy body design. Sport Utilities are typically defined by a body on frame construction which offers more off-road capability but reduced on-road ride comfort and handling compared to a cross-over or car based utility vehicle.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of compact SUVs:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_Rover_Freelander\"\u003eLand Rover Freelande\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeep_Patriot\"\u003eJeep Patrio\u003c/a\u003et\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_FJ_Cruiser\"\u003eToyota FJ Cruise\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small Off-Roaders\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003ePony car\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e1966 Ford Mustang\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eConvertible\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eFull-sized convertible with its fabric covered top folded behind the rear seat\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eOff-roaders\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSport utility vehicle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeep_Commander\"\u003eJeep Commande\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of SUVs:\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_Rover_Discovery\"\u003eLand Rover Discover\u003c/a\u003ey\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_Pajero\"\u003eMitsubishi Pajer\u003c/a\u003eo\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahindra_Scorpio\"\u003eMahindra Scorpi\u003c/a\u003eo\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Large Off-Roaders\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn some countries, the term \"van\" can refer to a small \u003ci\u003epanel van\u003c/i\u003e based on a passenger car design (often the estate model / station wagon); it also refers to light trucks, which themselves are sometimes based on SUVs or MPVs. (But note that those retaining seats and windows, while being larger and more utilitarian than MPVs, may be called \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minibus\"\u003eminibuses\u003c/a\u003e\".) The term is also used in the term \"camper van\" (or just \"camper\") - equivalent to a North American \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recreational_vehicle\"\u003erecreational vehicl\u003c/a\u003ee (RV).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the United States, the term \"van\" refers to vehicles that, like European minibuses, are even larger than large MPVs and are rarely seen being driven for domestic purposes - except for \"conversion vans\". These possess extremely large interior space and are often more intended for hauling cargo than people. Most vans use body-on-frame construction and are thus suitable for extensive modification and coachwork, known as conversion. Conversion vans are often quite luxurious, boasting comfortable seats, soft rides, built-in support for electronics such as television sets, and other amenities. The more elaborate conversion vans straddle the line between cars and recreational vehicles.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eExamples of North American \"vans\":\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodge_Ram_Van\"\u003eDodge Ram Van\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_E-Series#1992.E2.80.93present\"\u003eFord E-Serie\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GMC_Savana\"\u003eGMC Savan\u003c/a\u003ea Examples of European \"vans\":\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Transit\"\u003eFord Transi\u003c/a\u003et\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Transporter\"\u003eVolkswagen Transporte\u003c/a\u003er\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter\"\u003eMercedes-Benz Sprinte\u003c/a\u003er Examples of Japanese \"vans\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Hiace\"\u003eToyota Hiac\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan_NV200\"\u003eNissan N\u003c/a\u003eV\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eBakkie \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA generic \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Africa\"\u003eSouth African\u003c/a\u003e term for light pickup truck.[40]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eBaquet\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003erefers to cars made in the early 1900s in Europe. Baquet means bath tub. These cars had two rows of raised seats similar to horse-drawn carriages. Baquets usually did not have front doors, a top, or windshield.[41]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buggy_(automobile)\"\u003eBuggy\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA Buggy is an automobile with wheels that project beyond the vehicle body.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabrio_coach\"\u003eCabrio coach\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kia_Sportage\"\u003eKia Sportag\u003c/a\u003ee\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eCommercial vehicle\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eVan\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eAmerican conversion van\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eOther car classification terms\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eNormally a two-door body design with special form of car roof, where a retractable textile cover amounts to a large \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunroof\"\u003esunroof\u003c/a\u003e.[42]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coup%C3%A9\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eCoupé\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA 2-door, 2- or 4-seat car with a fixed roof. Its doors are often longer than those of an equivalent sedan and the rear passenger area smaller; the roof may also be low. In cases where the rear seats are very small and not intended for regular use it is called a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2%2B2_(car_body_style)\"\u003e2+2\u003c/a\u003e (pronounced \u003ci\u003e\"two plus two\"\u003c/i\u003e). Originally, a coupé was required to have only one side window per side, but this consideration has not been used for many years. Occasionally seen as \u003cb\u003eFixed Head Coupé\u003c/b\u003e, or FHC, particularly when referring to a hardtop version of a convertible.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dCombi_Coup%C3%A9\u0026amp;action\u003dedit\u0026amp;redlink\u003d1\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eCombi Coupé\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA 2-door, 4-seat car with \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hatchback\"\u003ehatchback\u003c/a\u003e door at rear and, collapsible rear seats, resembling a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fastback\"\u003efastback\u003c/a\u003e. The idea is to maximize the carrying capacity without bargaining on the performance.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coup%C3%A9_utility\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eCoupé utility\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA passenger-car derived vehicle with an integral exterior cargo area.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crossover_(automobile)\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eCrossover\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e (or CUV)\n\u003c/b\u003eA loose marketing term to describe a vehicle that blends features of a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SUV\"\u003eSUV\u003c/a\u003e with features of a car - especially forgoing the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_on_frame\"\u003ebody on frame\u003c/a\u003e construction of the SUV in favor of the car\u0027s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unibody\"\u003eunibody\u003c/a\u003e or\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monocoque\"\u003emonocoque\u003c/a\u003e construction. Crossovers usually borrow drivetrains and other parts from traditional cars in the same manufacturer\u0027s line. Crossovers typically employ an \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front-engine,_front-wheel-drive_layout\"\u003eFF layout\u003c/a\u003e or an FF-based\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-wheel_drive\"\u003efour-wheel drive\u003c/a\u003e layout with a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse_engine\"\u003etransverse engine\u003c/a\u003e, rather than an \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front-engine,_rear-wheel-drive_layout\"\u003eFR layout\u003c/a\u003e or an FR-based 4WD layout with a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitudinal_engine\"\u003elongitudinal engine\u003c/a\u003e as is typically used on traditional truck-based SUVs.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eDrop Head Coupé\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOften abbreviated to DHC. Generally a European term referring to a 2-door, 4 place automobile with a retractable canvas / cloth top with \u003ci\u003eboth\u003c/i\u003e a padded headliner and rollup windows (as opposed to side curtains).\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eEstate\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBritish name for a \u003ci\u003estation wagon\u003c/i\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fastback\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eFastback\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA design where the roof slopes at a smooth angle to the tail of the car, but the rear window does not open as a separate \"door\".\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eFlower Car\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003ein US, similar to ute in Australia, i.e. generic for Chevy El Camino, Ford Ranchero, GMC Sprint/Diablo, etc.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hatchback\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eHatchback\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIncorporates a shared passenger and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cargo\"\u003ecargo\u003c/a\u003e volume, with rearmost accessibility via a rear third or fifth door, typically a top-hinged \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liftgate\"\u003eliftgate\u003c/a\u003e-and features such as fold-down rear seats to enable flexibility within the shared passenger/cargo volume. As a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-box_styling\"\u003etwo-box design\u003c/a\u003e, the body style typically includes A, B and C-\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pillar_(car)\"\u003epillars\u003c/a\u003e, and may include a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pillar_(car)\"\u003eD-pillar\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardtop\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eHardtop\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOriginally a removable solid roof on a \u003ci\u003econvertible\u003c/i\u003e; later, also a fixed-roof car whose doors have no fixed window frames, which is designed to resemble such a convertible (sometimes also called\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\"Fixed Head Coupé\", or FHC.)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearse\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eHearse\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA converted car (often a station wagon), light truck or minivan usually used to transport the dead.
