Passenger access in normally via a sliding door on one side of the vehicle. One example of a van with a minibus version available is the Ford Transit.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-purpose_vehicle\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eMPV\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMulti-purpose vehicle, a large car or small bus designed to be used on and off-road and easily convertible to facilitate loading of goods from facilitating carrying people.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notchback\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eNotchback\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA configuration where the third box of a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-box_styling\"\u003ethree-box styling\u003c/a\u003e configuration is less pronounced - especially where the rear deck (third box) is short or where the rear window is upright.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People_carrier\"\u003e\u003cb\u003ePeople carrier\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e or people mover\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eEuropean name to describe what is usually referred to in North America as a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minivan\"\u003eMinivan\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phaeton_body\"\u003e\u003cb\u003ePhaeton\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA Phaeton is a style of open car or carriage without proper weather protection for passengers.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickup_truck\"\u003e\u003cb\u003ePickup truck\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e (or \u003c/b\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003ci\u003epickup\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003cb\u003e)\n\u003c/b\u003eA light-duty, open-bed truck.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003ePillarless\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eUsually a prefix to \u003ci\u003ecoupé\u003c/i\u003e, \u003ci\u003efastback\u003c/i\u003e, or \u003ci\u003ehardtop\u003c/i\u003e; completely open at the sides when the windows are down, without a central \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pillar_(car)\"\u003epillar\u003c/a\u003e, e.g. the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunbeam_Rapier#Sunbeam_Rapier_Fastback_coup.C3.A9\"\u003eSunbeam Rapier\u003c/a\u003e fastback coupé.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eRagtop\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOriginally an open car like a \u003ci\u003eroadster\u003c/i\u003e, but with a soft top (cloth top) that can be raised or lowered. Unlike a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convertible_(car)\"\u003econvertible\u003c/a\u003e, it had no roll-up side windows. Now often used as slang for a convertible.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retractable_Hardtop\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eRetractable Hardtop\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eaka Coupé convertible or Coupé Cabriolet. A type of convertible forgoing a foldable textile roof in favor of a multi-segment rigid roof retracts into the lower bodywork.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roadster_(automobile)\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eRoadster\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOriginally a two-seat open car with minimal weather protection - without top or side glass - though possibly with optional hard or soft top and side curtains (i.e., without roll-up glass windows). In modern usage, the term means simply a two-seat \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_car\"\u003esports car\u003c/a\u003e \u003ci\u003econvertible\u003c/i\u003e, a variation of \u003ci\u003espyder\u003c/i\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(car)\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eSedan\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA car seating four or more with a fixed roof that is full-height up to the rear window. Known in British English as a saloon. Sedans can have 2 or 4-doors. This is the most common body style. In the U.S., this term has been used to denote a car with fixed window frames, as opposed to the \u003ci\u003ehardtop\n\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003estyle wherein the sash, if any, winds down with the glass.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_delivery\"\u003eSedan delivery\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panel_truck\"\u003eNorth American term for a vehicle similar to a \u003ci\u003ewagon\u003c/i\u003e but without side windows, similar to a panel truck but with two doors (one on each side), and one or two rear doors\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_utility_vehicle\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eSport utility vehicle\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e (SUV)\n\u003c/b\u003eDerivative of a pickup truck or 4-wheel-drive vehicle, but with fully enclosed passenger cabin interior and carlike levels of interior equipment.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eSpyder (or Spider)\n\u003c/b\u003eSimilar to a \u003ci\u003eroadster\u003c/i\u003e but originally with less weather protection.Nowadays it simply means a convertible with two seater only. The name comes from the old carriages with two seats and no roof, whose small central cabin and big wheels at the corners are reminiscent of a spider.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shooting-brake\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eShooting-brake\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eInitially a vehicle used to carry shooting parties with their equipment and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_(food)\"\u003egame\u003c/a\u003e; later used to\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003edescribe custom-built wagons by high-end coachbuilders, subsequently synonymous with \u003ci\u003estation wagon\u003c/i\u003e or \u003ci\u003eestate\u003c/i\u003e; and in contemporary usage a three or five-door wagons combining features of \u003c/a\u003ea\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003ewagon\u003c/a\u003e and a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coup%C3%A9\"\u003ecoupé\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eStation wagon\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA variant of a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(automobile)\"\u003esedan\u003c/a\u003e/\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(automobile)\"\u003esaloon\u003c/a\u003e, (also known as estate or estate car) or with its roof extended rearward over a shared passenger/cargo volume; access at the back via a third or fifth door instead of a trunk lid; flexible configurations to vary passenger or cargo volume; and two or three rows of seating - in a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-box_styling#One-box_and_Two-Box_design\"\u003etwo-box\u003c/a\u003e design with a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pillar_(car)\"\u003eA, B \u0026amp; C-pillar\u003c/a\u003e, as well as a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pillar_(car)\"\u003eD pillar\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-top\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eT-top\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA derivative of the Targa top, called a T-bar roof, this fixed-roof design has two removable panels and retains a central narrow roof section along the front to back axis of the car (\u003ci\u003ee.g.\u003c/i\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_MR2\"\u003eToyota MR2\n\u003c/a\u003eMark I.)\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Targa_top\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eTarga top\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA semi-convertible style used on some sports cars, featuring a fully removable hard top roof panel which leaves the A and B \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pillar_(car)\"\u003epillars\u003c/a\u003e in place on the car body.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Town_car\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eTown car (US)\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003eEssentially the inverse of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landaulet\"\u003elandaulet\u003c/a\u003e, a historical body style in which the front seats were open and the rear compartment closed, normally with a removable top to cover the front chauffeur\u0027s compartment. In Europe the style is also known as Sedanca de Ville, often shortened to Sedanca or de Ville. Note that the modern \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Town_Car\"\u003eLincoln Town Car\u003c/a\u003e derives its name, but nothing else, from this style.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ute_(vehicle)\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eUte\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eA term used originally in Australia and New Zealand to describe usually two-wheel-drive, traditionally passenger vehicles with a cargo tray in the rear integrated with the passenger body; as opposed to a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickup_truck\"\u003epickup\u003c/a\u003e whose cargo tray is not integrated with the passenger body.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_delivery\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eWagon delivery\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eNorth American term (mainly U.S. and Canada). Similar to a \u003ci\u003esedan delivery\u003c/i\u003e, with four doors.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eVan\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_America\"\u003eNorth America\u003c/a\u003e \"van\" refers to a truck-based commercial vehicle of the wagon style, whether used for passenger or commercial use. Usually a van has no windows at the side rear (panel van), although for passenger use, side windows are included. In other parts of the world, \u0027van\u0027 denotes a passenger-based wagon with no rear side windows.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome non-\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language\"\u003eEnglish languag\u003c/a\u003ee terms are familiar from their use on imported vehicles in English-speaking nations even though the terms have not been adopted into English.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barchetta\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eBarchetta\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_language\"\u003eItalian\u003c/a\u003e term for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roadster_(automobile)\"\u003eroadster\u003c/a\u003e with no roof. The name, roughly \"small boat\", comes from an exclamation when the Ferrari 166MM Touring was shown.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eNon-English terms\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(car)\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eBerlina\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_language\"\u003eItalian\u003c/a\u003e term for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(car)\"\u003esedan\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003cb\u003eBerline \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language\"\u003eFrench\u003c/a\u003e term for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlinetta\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eBerlinetta\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language\"\u003eFrench\u003c/a\u003e term for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003estation wagon\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003cb\u003eCamioneta \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBrazilian Portuguese term for a station wagon (specially in the state of Rio de Janeiro). \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language\"\u003eSpanish\n\u003c/a\u003eterm also used in Argentina and Uruguay.\n\u003cb\u003eCarrinha \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portuguese_language\"\u003ePortuguese\u003c/a\u003e term for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003estation wagon\u003c/a\u003e. Not used in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese\"\u003eBrazilian Portuguese\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Espada\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eEspada\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portuguese_language\"\u003ePortuguese\u003c/a\u003e nickname for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limousine\"\u003elimousine\u003c/a\u003e (the same word for \u003ci\u003eSword\u003c/i\u003e - long piece of metal). Not used in\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese\"\u003eBrazilian Portuguese\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003cb\u003eFurgoneta \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language\"\u003eSpanish\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_language\"\u003ePolish\u003c/a\u003e term for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van\"\u003evan\u003c/a\u003e, in the latter language almost always used in its diminutive form\n\u003ci\u003efurgonetka\u003c/i\u003e.\n\u003cb\u003eFurgão \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portuguese_language\"\u003ePortuguese\u003c/a\u003e alternative term (less used) for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van\"\u003evan\u003c/a\u003e. Used in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese\"\u003eBrazilian Portuguese\u003c/a\u003e, most often for vans but sometimes for panel van variants of passenger cars.\n\u003cb\u003eKombi \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eis a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language\"\u003eGerman\u003c/a\u003e abbreviation of \"Kombinationswagen\" (Combination Car) and it is German name for\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003estation wagon\u003c/a\u003e. Since \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany\"\u003eGermany\u003c/a\u003e is a major producer of cars for many European countries, the term Kombi in this meaning is also used in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swedish_language\"\u003eSwedish\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czech_language\"\u003eCzech\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slovak_language\"\u003eSlovak\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_language\"\u003ePolish\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slovene_language\"\u003eSlovenian\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbian_language\"\u003eSerbian\u003c/a\u003e,\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnian_language\"\u003eBosnian\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatian_language\"\u003eCroatian\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_language\"\u003eHungarian\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language\"\u003eSpanish\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portuguese_language\"\u003ePortuguese\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulgarian_language\"\u003eBulgarian\u003c/a\u003e. In \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afrikaans_language\"\u003eAfrikaans\u003c/a\u003e and in Australia, Kombi is also used to refer to a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VW_Type_2\"\u003eVolkswagen Microbus\u003c/a\u003e. In Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay the word specifically refers to the VW Microbus.\n\u003cb\u003ePerua\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese\"\u003eBrazilian Portuguese\u003c/a\u003e term either designating a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van\"\u003evan\u003c/a\u003e (especially as spoken in the city of São Paulo) or a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Station_wagon\"\u003estation wagon\u003c/a\u003e (in the city of Rio de Janeiro).\n\u003cb\u003eTurismo \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language\"\u003eSpanish\u003c/a\u003e term for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(car)\"\u003esedan\u003c/a\u003e. Literally means \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourism\"\u003etourism\u003c/a\u003e, used mostly in Latin American countries and Spain.\n\u003cb\u003eIjapa \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigerian_language\"\u003eYoruba\u003c/a\u003e term for a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dTwo_door_door\u0026amp;action\u003dedit\u0026amp;redlink\u003d1\"\u003etwo door car\u003c/a\u003e. McFarland. p. 29.\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number\"\u003eISBN\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781476614809\"\u003e9781476614809\u003c/a\u003e. Retrieved 17 August 2015.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eExternal links\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003c/body\u003e\u003c/html\u003e","id":"ad5bceaab636c34f9d12975a221d0908","text":"no title\n\nCar classification\n\nGovernments and private organizations have developed car classification schemes that are used for innumerable purposes including regulation, description and categorization, among others. This article details commonly used classification schemes in use worldwide.\n\n1 Classification methods\n\n2 Size and usage-based vehicle classification systems worldwide 3 Economy car\n\n3.1 Microcar 3.2 Hatchbacks\n\n3.2.1 Ultracompact car 3.2.2 City car\n\n3.2.3 Supermini/subcompact car\n\n4 Family car\n\n4.1 Small family car/compact car 4.2 Large family / mid-size\n\n5 Saloons / sedans\n\n5.1 Large family / mid-size 5.2 Full size / large 5.3 Crossover SUV\n\n5.4 Minivans / MPVs\n\n6 Luxury vehicle\n\n6.1 Compact executive 6.2 Executive/mid-luxury\n\n6.3 Full-size luxury / Grand saloon\n\n6.4 Estate cars / station wagons\n\n7 Sports cars\n\n7.1 Hot hatch\n\n7.2 Sports saloon / sports sedan 7.3 Sports car\n\n7.4 Grand tourer\n\n7.5 Supercar\n\n7.6 Muscle car\n\n7.7 Pony car\n\n7.8 Convertible\n\n8 Off-roaders\n\n8.1 Sport utility vehicle\n\n9 Commercial vehicle\n\n9.1 Van\n\n10 Other car classification terms\n\n10.1 Non-English terms\n\n11 See also 12 References 13 External links\n\nContents\n\nClassification methods\n\nVehicles can be categorized in numerous ways. For example, by means of the body style and the \"level of commonality in vehicle construction as defined by number of doors and roof treatment (e.g., sedan, convertible, fastback, hatchback) and number of seats\" that require seat belts to meet safety regulations.[1]\n\nRegulatory agencies may also establish a vehicle classification system for determining a tax amount. In the United Kingdom, a vehicle is taxed according to the vehicle\u0027s construction, engine, weight, type of fuel and emissions, as well as the purpose for which it is used.[2] Other jurisdictions may determine vehicle tax based upon environmental principles, such as the user pays principle.[3] In another example, certain cities in the United States in the 1920s chose to exempt electric-powered vehicles because officials believed those vehicles did not cause \"substantial wear upon the pavements\".[4]\n\nAnother standard for road vehicles of all types that is used internationally (except for Australia, India, and the U.S.) is ISO 3833-1977.[5]\n\nIn an example from private enterprise, many car rental companies use the ACRISS Car Classification Code to describe the size, type and equipment of vehicles to ensure that rental agents can match customer needs to available vehicles, regardless of distance between the agent and the rental company or the languages spoken by either party. In the United States, since 2010 the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety uses a scheme it has developed that takes into account a combination of both vehicle shadow (length times width) and weight.[6]\n\nUS Highway Loss Data Institute classification Definition\n\nRegular Two Door Two door sedans and hatchbacks\n\nRegular Four Door Four door sedans and hatchbacks\n\nStation Wagons Four doors, a rear hatch and four pillars\n\nMinivans Vans with sliding rear doors\n\nSports Two seaters and cars with significant high performance features\n\nLuxury Relatively expensive cars that are not classified as sports (price in USD to curb weight in pounds more than 9.0 in 2010) (small cars over $27,000, midsize cars over $31,500, large cars over $36,000, etc.)\n\nUS Insurance Institute for Highway Safety | Highway Loss Data Institute \u0027Guide to car size groups\u0027 (includes minivans)[7]\n\nShadow (square footage of exterior length × width)\n\nCurb Weight 70 to 80 sq ft(6.5-7.4 m2) ft (7.4 m2)\n\nSmall 3,001 to 3,750 lb (1,350-1,700 kg)\n\nMidsize 3,751 to 4,750 lb (1,700-2,150 kg)\n\nLarge 4,751 to 5,750 lb (2,150-2,600 kg)\n\nVery large \u003e5,750 lb (2,600 kg) or shadow \u003e115 sq ft (10.7 m2)\n\nThe United States National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) separates vehicles into classes by the curb weight of the vehicle with standard equipment including the maximum capacity of fuel, oil, coolant, and air conditioning, if so equipped.[9]\n\nUS NHTSA classification Code Curb weight\n\nPassenger cars: mini PC/Mi 1,500 to 1,999 lb (700-900 kg)\n\nPassenger cars: light PC/L 2,000 to 2,499 lb (900-1,150 kg)\n\nPassenger cars: compact PC/C 2,500 to 2,999 lb (1,150-1,350 kg)\n\nPassenger cars: medium PC/Me 3,000 to 3,499 lb (1,350-1,600 kg)\n\nPassenger cars: heavy PC/H 3,500 lb (1,600 kg) and over\n\nSport utility vehicles SUV -\n\nPickup trucks PU -\n\nVans VAN -\n\nThe United States Federal Highway Administration has developed a classification scheme used for automatically calculating road use tolls. There are two broad categories depending on whether the vehicle carries passengers or commodities. Vehicles that carry commodities are further subdivided by number of axles and number of units, including both power and trailer units.[10]\n\nThe United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) has developed a classification scheme used to compare fuel economy among similar vehicles. Passenger vehicles are classified based on a vehicle\u0027s total interior passenger and cargo volumes. Trucks are classified based upon their gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR). Heavy duty vehicles are not included within the EPA scheme.[11]\n\nUS EPA car class Total passenger and cargo volume (cu. ft.)\n\nTwo-seaters Any (designed to seat only two adults) Less than 85 cu ft (2,400 l) 85 to 99 cu ft (2,400-2,800 l) 100 to 109 cu ft (2,850-3,100 l) 110 to 119 cu ft (3,100-3,350 l) 120 cu ft (3,400 l) or more Less than 130 cu ft (3,700 l) 130 to 159 cu ft (3,700-4,500 l)\n\nMinicompact\n\nSubcompact\n\nCompact\n\nMid-size\n\nLarge\n\nMid-size station wagons\n\nLarge station wagons 160 cu ft (4,550 l) or more\n\nSmall station wagons\n\nA similar set of classes is used by the Canadian EPA.[12] The Canadian National Collision Database (NCDB) system defines \"passenger car\" as a unique class, but also identifies two other categories involving passenger vehicles-the \"passenger van\" and \"light utility vehicle\"-and these categories are inconsistently handled across the country with the boundaries between the vehicles increasingly blurred.[13]\n\nIn Australia, the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries publishes its own classifications.[14]\n\nThis is a summary table listing several diferent methods of vehicle classification.\n\nSize and usage-based vehicle classification systems worldwide\n\nNot well-defined / vernacular Defined by law or regulation\n\nExamples Market segment (American English)\n\nMarket segment (British Special purpose vehicle\n\nDodge Ram , Ford F-150 , GMC Sierra ,\n\nNissan Titan, Toyota Tundra\n\nChevrolet Silverado HD, Ram Heavy Duty , Ford Super Duty\n\n-\n\n- - - Lincoln MKTLivery\n\nStraddling the boundary between car and motorbike, these vehicles have engines under 1.0 litre, typically seat only two passengers, and are sometimes unorthodox in construction. Some microcars are three-wheelers, while the majority have four wheels. Microcars were popular in post-war Europe, where their appearance led them to be called \"Bubble cars\". More recent microcars are often electric powered.\n\nExamples of microcars:\n\nIsetta Smart Fortwo Tata Nano\n\nIn 2012, Japan\u0027s Transport and Tourism Ministry allowed local government to use ultracompact cars as transport for residents and tourists in their limiting areas. The size of ultracompact cars will be less than minicars, but have engine greater than 50cc displacement and able to transport 1 or 2 persons. Ultracompact cars cannot use minicars standard, because of strict safety standards for minicars. The regulation about running capacity and safety performance of ultracompact cars will be published in early autumn. Today, there are cars smaller than ultracompact cars, called category-1 motorized vehicles which it has 50cc displacement or less and only one seat for the driver.[19]\n\nA city car is a small automobile intended for use in urban areas. Unlike microcars, a city car\u0027s greater speed, capacity and (in perception at least) occupant protection are safer in mixed traffic environments and weather conditions. While city cars can reach highway speeds, that is not their intended use. In Japan, city cars are called kei cars.[20] Kei cars have to meet strict size and engine requirements: engines have a maximum displacement of 660 cc and the car\u0027s length must be under 3400 mm.\n\nExamples of kei cars:\n\nDaihatsu Move\n\nEconomy car\n\nMicrocar\n\nMicrocar Abaca\n\nHatchbacks\n\nUltracompact car\n\nCity car\n\nCitroën C1\n\nHonda Life\n\nSuzuki Cervo Examples of city cars:\n\nFiat Panda Maruti 800\n\nMini (Original 1959 model) Other small cars:\n\nCarver One Citroën Type C Smith Flyer\n\nThis class is known as supermini in the UK, subcompact in North America. Superminis have three, four or five doors, and even as an estate shape. They are designed to seat four passengers comfortably. Current supermini hatchbacks are approximately 3900 mm long, while saloons and estate cars are around 4200 mm long. Currently (2013) sedan variants are generally not available in Europe and are marketed at a lower price than hatchback models in North America.\n\nIn Europe, the first superminis were the Fiat 500 of 1957 and the Austin Mini of 1959. Superminis can be premium cars, such as the Citroën DS3, named 2010 Car of the Year by\n\nTop Gear Magazine. Superminis are some of the best selling vehicles in Europe with 25% of the market shares (2013). In 2007, the Peugeot 207 has been the most sold car in Europe, whereas the best seller is almost systematically a car from the compact segment.\n\nIn Australia, the motoring press tends to distinguish between a light car such as the Daihatsu Charade or early models of the Holden Barina, and slightly larger models such as the Ford Fiesta which is considered to be a small car. As the general size of vehicles in this class has gradually increased, the category of light car has almost disappeared.\n\nExamples of superminis/subcompact cars:\n\nOpel Corsa Peugeot 208 Volkswagen Polo\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Superminis\".\n\nSmall family/compact cars refer to the hatchbacks and shortest saloons and estate cars with similar size. They are approximately 4,250 mm (167 in) long in case of hatchbacks and 4,500 mm (177 in) in the case of saloons and estate cars. Compact cars have room for five adults and usually have engines between 1.4 and 2.2 litres, but some have engines of up to 2.5 litres.\n\nExamples of hatchback small family cars/compact cars:\n\nPeugeot 308 Toyota Auris Renault Megane\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small Family Cars\". In Australia, this class is generally referred to as being small-medium sized cars.\n\nSupermini/subcompact car\n\nRenault Clio IV\n\nFamily car\n\nSmall family car/compact car\n\nVolkswagen Golf\n\nTraditionally, mid-size cars are sedans, but recently cars such as the Citroën DS5, which is a large hatchback family car, have introduced other body styles.[21]\n\nA class described as \"large family\" in Europe and \"mid-size\" in the USA, these cars have room for five adults and a large trunk (boot). Engines are more powerful than small family/compact cars and six-cylinder engines are more common than in smaller cars. Car sizes vary from region to region; in Europe, large family cars are rarely over 4,700 mm (15.4 ft) long, while in North America, Middle East and Australasia they may be well over 4,800 mm (15.7 ft).\n\nExamples of large family cars/mid-size cars:\n\nChevrolet Malibu Ford Mondeo Kia Optima\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Large Family Cars\". These are known in Australia as Medium sized cars.\n\nThis term is used most in North America, Middle East and Australia where it refers to the largest affordable sedans on the market. Full-size cars may be well over 4,900 mm (16.1 ft) long.\n\nExamples of full-size cars:\n\nDodge Charger Ford Falcon Toyota Avalon [22]\n\nCrossover SUVs are derived from an automobile platform using a monocoque construction with light off-road capability and lower ground clearance than SUVs. They may be styled similar to conventional \"off-roaders\", or may be look similar to an estate car or station wagon.\n\nExamples of crossover SUVs:\n\nChevrolet Equinox Nissan Qashqai Tata Aria\n\nLarge family / mid-size\n\nCitroën DS5\n\nSaloons / sedans\n\nLarge family / mid-size\n\nToyota Camry\n\nFull size / large\n\nHolden Commodore\n\nCrossover SUV\n\nMitsubishi Outlander\n\nAlso known as \"people carriers\", this class of cars resembles tall estate cars. Larger MPVs may have seating for up to eight passengers. (Beyond that size, similar vehicles tend to be derived from vans (see below) and in Europe are called minibuses.)\n\nBeing taller than a family car improves visibility for the driver (while reducing visibility for other road users) and may help access for the elderly or disabled. They also offer more seats and increased load capacity than hatchbacks or estate cars.\n\nExamples of mini MPVs:\n\nCitroën C3 Picasso Ford B-Max Nissan Note Examples of compact MPVs:\n\nOpel Zafira Tourer Peugeot 5008 Renault Scénic\n\nBoth categories are equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small MPVs\".\n\nExamples of large MPVs / minivans:\n\nDodge Caravan Ford S-Max Mazda5\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"MPVs\".\n\nThese are luxurious equivalents to mid-size and compact cars. Rear seat room and trunk space are smaller than executive cars simply because of their smaller overall size.\n\nExamples of compact premium cars/entry-level luxury cars:\n\nAudi A4 BMW 3 Series Buick Regal\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Large Family Cars\".\n\nThese are luxurious equivalents to full-size cars. This also refers to the largest hatchbacks within the similar length in this class, such as the Porsche Panamera.\n\nExamples of executive cars/mid-luxury cars:\n\nPeugeot 607 Jaguar XF MG Magnette\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Executive Cars\".\n\nMinivans / MPVs\n\nRenault Espace, one of the first true minivans\n\nFord C-Max, a compact MPV\n\nOpel Meriva a mini MPV\n\nLuxury vehicle\n\nCompact executive\n\nLexus IS\n\nExecutive/mid-luxury\n\nBMW 5 Series\n\nFull-size luxury / Grand saloon\n\nAlso known as full-size luxury cars, grand saloons, or premium large cars, while\n\n\"Oberklasse\" is used in Germany. Typically a four-door saloon (sedan). These are the most powerful saloons, with six, eight and twelve-cylinder engines and have more equipment than smaller models. Vehicles in this category include some of the models from the flagship lines of luxury car brands, such as Cadillac CT6,[23] Lincoln Town Car and Maserati Quattroporte.\n\nExamples of grand saloons:\n\nAudi A8 Lexus LS BMW 7 Series\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Executive Cars\".\n\nA station wagon (also known as an estate or estate car) is an automobile with a body style variant of a sedan/saloon with its roof extended rearward over a shared passenger/cargo volume with access at the back via a third or fifth door (the liftgate or tailgate), instead of a trunk lid. The body style transforms a standard three-box design into a two-box design-to include an A, B, and C-pillar, as well as a D-pillar. Station wagons can flexibly reconfigure their interior volume via fold-down rear seats to prioritize either passenger or cargo volume.\n\nExamples of estates/station wagons:\n\nHyundai i40 Tourer Jaguar XF Sportbrake Mercedes-Benz CLS Shooting Brake\n\nA hot hatch is a high-performance hatchback, based on standard superminis or small family cars with improved performance, handling and styling. Hot hatches are very popular in Europe, where hatchbacks are by far the most common body style for this size of car. In North America, sport compacts are usually sold as saloons or coupés rather than hatchbacks.\n\nExamples of hot hatches:\n\nVolkswagen Golf GTi Peugeot 205 GTi Fiat 500 Abarth\n\nThese are high-performance versions of saloons. Sometimes originally homologated for production based motorsports (touring cars or rally cars) and like regular saloons, seats four or five people.\n\nExamples of sports saloons/sedans:\n\nBMW M5 Mazdaspeed6/Mazda 6 MPS Dodge Charger Examples of sport compact saloons/sedans:\n\nMercedes-Benz S-Class\n\nEstate cars / station wagons\n\nAudi A6 avant\n\nSports cars\n\nHot hatch\n\nPeugeot 205 GTI crowned \"The Greatest Ever Hot Hatch\"[24]\n\nSports saloon / sports sedan\n\nPontiac G8 GT\n\nDodge SRT-4\n\nLotus Cortina\n\nMitsubishi EVO\n\nThe term \"sports car\" does not appear to have a clear definition.[25] It is commonly used to describe vehicles which prioritise acceleration and handling; however, some people claim it is also defined as a vehicle with two seats.[26]\n\nA Sports car (sportscar or sport car) is a small, usually two-seat, two-door automobile designed for spirited performance and nimble handling.[27] Sports cars may be spartan or luxurious but high maneuverability and minimum weight are requisite.[28]\n\nExamples of sports cars:\n\nChevrolet Corvette Mazda MX-5 Porsche 911\n\nLarger, more powerful and heavier than sports cars, these vehicles typically have a FR layout and seating for four passengers (2+2). These are more expensive than sports cars but not as expensive as supercars. Grand Tourers encompass both luxury and high-performance. Some grand tourers are hand-built.\n\nExamples of grand tourers:\n\nAston Martin V8 Lexus SC300/400 Ferrari 612 Scaglietti\n\nSupercar is a term generally used for ultra-high-end exotic cars, whose performance is superior to that of its contemporaries. The proper application of the term is subjective and disputed, especially among enthusiasts.\n\nExamples of supercars:\n\nMcLaren P1 Koenigsegg Agera R Bugatti Veyron 16.4\n\nThe muscle car term generally refers to rear wheel drive mid-size cars with powerful V8 engines, typically manufactured in the U.S.[29][30] Some definitions limit it to two-door vehicles;[31] however, others include four-door body style versions.[32] Although opinions vary, it is generally accepted that classic muscle cars were produced in the late 1960s and early 1970s.[33][34][35][36] Muscle cars were also produced in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and other nations.\n\nExamples of American muscle cars from the 1960s and 1970s:\n\nFord Torino Plymouth Road Runner\n\nSports car\n\nJaguar E-Type\n\nGrand tourer\n\nMaserati GranTurismo\n\nSupercar\n\nLamborghini Countach\n\nMuscle car\n\n1970 AMC The Machine\n\nPontiac GTO Examples of Australian muscle cars:\n\nFord Falcon Holden Monaro Valiant Charger\n\nThe pony car is a class of American Muscle car[37] automobile launched and inspired by the Ford Mustang in 1964. It describes an affordable, compact, highly styled car with a sporty or performance-oriented image.[38][39]\n\nExamples of pony cars:\n\nAMC Javelin Chevrolet Camaro Dodge Challenger\n\nA body design that features a flexibly operating roof for open or enclosed mode driving. Also known as a cabriolet or roadster (if a 2-seater). Historically, convertibles used folding roof structures with fabric or other flexible materials. Some designs have roofs made of metal or other stiff materials that retract into the body.\n\nExamples of cabriolets:\n\nMazda MX-5 Honda S2000 Volvo C70\n\nOff-road vehicles, or \"off-roaders\" are sometimes referred to as \"four-wheel drives\", \"four by fours\", or 4x4s - this can happen colloquially in cases where certain models or even an entire range does not possess four-wheel drive.\n\nSport utility vehicles are off-road vehicles with four-wheel drive and true off-road capability. They most often feature high ground clearance and an upright, boxy body design. Sport Utilities are typically defined by a body on frame construction which offers more off-road capability but reduced on-road ride comfort and handling compared to a cross-over or car based utility vehicle.\n\nExamples of compact SUVs:\n\nLand Rover Freelander Jeep Patriot\n\nToyota FJ Cruiser\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Small Off-Roaders\".\n\nPony car\n\n1966 Ford Mustang\n\nConvertible\n\nFull-sized convertible with its fabric covered top folded behind the rear seat\n\nOff-roaders\n\nSport utility vehicle\n\nJeep Commander\n\nExamples of SUVs:\n\nLand Rover Discovery Mitsubishi Pajero Mahindra Scorpio\n\nThis category is equivalent to the EuroNCAP class \"Large Off-Roaders\".\n\nIn some countries, the term \"van\" can refer to a small panel van based on a passenger car design (often the estate model / station wagon); it also refers to light trucks, which themselves are sometimes based on SUVs or MPVs. (But note that those retaining seats and windows, while being larger and more utilitarian than MPVs, may be called \"minibuses\".) The term is also used in the term \"camper van\" (or just \"camper\") - equivalent to a North American recreational vehicle (RV).\n\nIn the United States, the term \"van\" refers to vehicles that, like European minibuses, are even larger than large MPVs and are rarely seen being driven for domestic purposes - except for \"conversion vans\". These possess extremely large interior space and are often more intended for hauling cargo than people. Most vans use body-on-frame construction and are thus suitable for extensive modification and coachwork, known as conversion. Conversion vans are often quite luxurious, boasting comfortable seats, soft rides, built-in support for electronics such as television sets, and other amenities. The more elaborate conversion vans straddle the line between cars and recreational vehicles.\n\nExamples of North American \"vans\":\n\nDodge Ram Van Ford E-Series GMC Savana Examples of European \"vans\":\n\nFord Transit Volkswagen Transporter Mercedes-Benz Sprinter Examples of Japanese \"vans\"\n\nToyota Hiace Nissan NV\n\nBakkie\n\nA generic South African term for light pickup truck.[40]\n\nBaquet\n\nrefers to cars made in the early 1900s in Europe. Baquet means bath tub. These cars had two rows of raised seats similar to horse-drawn carriages. Baquets usually did not have front doors, a top, or windshield.[41]\n\nBuggy\n\nA Buggy is an automobile with wheels that project beyond the vehicle body.\n\nCabrio coach\n\nKia Sportage\n\nCommercial vehicle\n\nVan\n\nAmerican conversion van\n\nOther car classification terms\n\nNormally a two-door body design with special form of car roof, where a retractable textile cover amounts to a large sunroof.[42]\n\nCoupé\n\nA 2-door, 2- or 4-seat car with a fixed roof. Its doors are often longer than those of an equivalent sedan and the rear passenger area smaller; the roof may also be low. In cases where the rear seats are very small and not intended for regular use it is called a 2+2 (pronounced \"two plus two\"). Originally, a coupé was required to have only one side window per side, but this consideration has not been used for many years. Occasionally seen as Fixed Head Coupé, or FHC, particularly when referring to a hardtop version of a convertible.\n\nCombi Coupé\n\nA 2-door, 4-seat car with hatchback door at rear and, collapsible rear seats, resembling a fastback. The idea is to maximize the carrying capacity without bargaining on the performance.\n\nCoupé utility\n\nA passenger-car derived vehicle with an integral exterior cargo area.\n\nCrossover (or CUV) A loose marketing term to describe a vehicle that blends features of a SUV with features of a car - especially forgoing the body on frame construction of the SUV in favor of the car\u0027s unibody or monocoque construction. Crossovers usually borrow drivetrains and other parts from traditional cars in the same manufacturer\u0027s line. Crossovers typically employ an FF layout or an FF-based four-wheel drive layout with a transverse engine, rather than an FR layout or an FR-based 4WD layout with a longitudinal engine as is typically used on traditional truck-based SUVs.\n\nDrop Head Coupé\n\nOften abbreviated to DHC. Generally a European term referring to a 2-door, 4 place automobile with a retractable canvas / cloth top with both a padded headliner and rollup windows (as opposed to side curtains).\n\nEstate\n\nBritish name for a station wagon.\n\nFastback\n\nA design where the roof slopes at a smooth angle to the tail of the car, but the rear window does not open as a separate \"door\".\n\nFlower Car\n\nin US, similar to ute in Australia, i.e. generic for Chevy El Camino, Ford Ranchero, GMC Sprint/Diablo, etc.\n\nHatchback\n\nIncorporates a shared passenger and cargo volume, with rearmost accessibility via a rear third or fifth door, typically a top-hinged liftgate-and features such as fold-down rear seats to enable flexibility within the shared passenger/cargo volume. As a two-box design, the body style typically includes A, B and C-pillars, and may include a D-pillar.\n\nHardtop\n\nOriginally a removable solid roof on a convertible; later, also a fixed-roof car whose doors have no fixed window frames, which is designed to resemble such a convertible (sometimes also called\n\n\"Fixed Head Coupé\", or FHC.)\n\nHearse\n\nA converted car (often a station wagon), light truck or minivan usually used to transport the dead. Often longer and heavier than the vehicle on which they are usually based. Can sometimes double up as an ambulance in some countries, such as the United States, especially in rural areas.\n\nKammback\n\nOriginally, a car with a tapered rear that cuts off abruptly.\n\nLandaulet\n\nA limousine with the passenger section covered by a convertible top.\n\nLeisure activity vehicle\n\nA small van, generally related to a supermini, with a second or even a third seat row, and a large, tall boot.\n\nLiftback\n\nA broad marketing term for a hatchback, which incorporates a shared passenger and cargo volume, with rearmost accessibility via a top-hinged liftgate.\n\nLimousine\n\nBy definition, a chauffeur-driven car with a (normally glass-windowed) division between the front seats and the rear. In German, the term simply means a sedan.\n\nMicrovan\n\nTerm for a boxy wagon-type of car that is smaller than a conventional minivan; often without rear sliding door(s). Examples are Citroën Picasso, Renault Scénic, Toyota Yaris Verso or Mercedes-Benz A-Class. In Japan, this term is used for Kei car based vans.\n\nMinibus\n\nDesigned to carry fewer people than a full-size bus, generally up to 16 people in multiple rows of seats. Passenger access in normally via a sliding door on one side of the vehicle. One example of a van with a minibus version available is the Ford Transit.\n\nMPV\n\nMulti-purpose vehicle, a large car or small bus designed to be used on and off-road and easily convertible to facilitate loading of goods from facilitating carrying people.\n\nNotchback\n\nA configuration where the third box of a three-box styling configuration is less pronounced - especially where the rear deck (third box) is short or where the rear window is upright.\n\nPeople carrier or people mover\n\nEuropean name to describe what is usually referred to in North America as a Minivan.\n\nPhaeton\n\nA Phaeton is a style of open car or carriage without proper weather protection for passengers.\n\nPickup truck (or pickup) A light-duty, open-bed truck.\n\nPillarless\n\nUsually a prefix to coupé, fastback, or hardtop; completely open at the sides when the windows are down, without a central pillar, e.g. the Sunbeam Rapier fastback coupé.\n\nRagtop\n\nOriginally an open car like a roadster, but with a soft top (cloth top) that can be raised or lowered. Unlike a convertible, it had no roll-up side windows. Now often used as slang for a convertible.\n\nRetractable Hardtop\n\naka Coupé convertible or Coupé Cabriolet. A type of convertible forgoing a foldable textile roof in favor of a multi-segment rigid roof retracts into the lower bodywork.\n\nRoadster\n\nOriginally a two-seat open car with minimal weather protection - without top or side glass - though possibly with optional hard or soft top and side curtains (i.e., without roll-up glass windows). In modern usage, the term means simply a two-seat sports car convertible, a variation of spyder.\n\nSedan\n\nA car seating four or more with a fixed roof that is full-height up to the rear window. Known in British English as a saloon. Sedans can have 2 or 4-doors. This is the most common body style. In the U.S., this term has been used to denote a car with fixed window frames, as opposed to the hardtop\n\nstyle wherein the sash, if any, winds down with the glass.\n\nSedan delivery\n\nNorth American term for a vehicle similar to a wagon but without side windows, similar to a panel truck but with two doors (one on each side), and one or two rear doors\n\nSport utility vehicle (SUV) Derivative of a pickup truck or 4-wheel-drive vehicle, but with fully enclosed passenger cabin interior and carlike levels of interior equipment.\n\nSpyder (or Spider) Similar to a roadster but originally with less weather protection.Nowadays it simply means a convertible with two seater only. The name comes from the old carriages with two seats and no roof, whose small central cabin and big wheels at the corners are reminiscent of a spider.\n\nShooting-brake\n\nInitially a vehicle used to carry shooting parties with their equipment and game; later used to describe custom-built wagons by high-end coachbuilders, subsequently synonymous with station wagon or estate; and in contemporary usage a three or five-door wagons combining features of a wagon and a coupé.\n\nStation wagon\n\nA variant of a sedan/saloon, (also known as estate or estate car) or with its roof extended rearward over a shared passenger/cargo volume; access at the back via a third or fifth door instead of a trunk lid; flexible configurations to vary passenger or cargo volume; and two or three rows of seating - in a two-box design with a A, B \u0026 C-pillar, as well as a D pillar.\n\nT-top\n\nA derivative of the Targa top, called a T-bar roof, this fixed-roof design has two removable panels and retains a central narrow roof section along the front to back axis of the car (e.g. Toyota MR2 Mark I.)\n\nTarga top\n\nA semi-convertible style used on some sports cars, featuring a fully removable hard top roof panel which leaves the A and B pillars in place on the car body.\n\nTown car (US) Essentially the inverse of the landaulet, a historical body style in which the front seats were open and the rear compartment closed, normally with a removable top to cover the front chauffeur\u0027s compartment. In Europe the style is also known as Sedanca de Ville, often shortened to Sedanca or de Ville. Note that the modern Lincoln Town Car derives its name, but nothing else, from this style.\n\nUte\n\nA term used originally in Australia and New Zealand to describe usually two-wheel-drive, traditionally passenger vehicles with a cargo tray in the rear integrated with the passenger body; as opposed to a pickup whose cargo tray is not integrated with the passenger body.\n\nWagon delivery\n\nNorth American term (mainly U.S. and Canada). Similar to a sedan delivery, with four doors.\n\nVan\n\nIn North America \"van\" refers to a truck-based commercial vehicle of the wagon style, whether used for passenger or commercial use. Usually a van has no windows at the side rear (panel van), although for passenger use, side windows are included. In other parts of the world, \u0027van\u0027 denotes a passenger-based wagon with no rear side windows.\n\nSome non-English language terms are familiar from their use on imported vehicles in English-speaking nations even though the terms have not been adopted into English.\n\nBarchetta\n\nItalian term for a roadster with no roof. The name, roughly \"small boat\", comes from an exclamation when the Ferrari 166MM Touring was shown.\n\nNon-English terms\n\nBerlina\n\nItalian term for a sedan. Berline\n\nFrench term for a sedan. Berlinetta\n\nItalian term for a sport coupé. Break\n\nFrench term for a station wagon. Camioneta\n\nBrazilian Portuguese term for a station wagon (specially in the state of Rio de Janeiro). Spanish term also used in Argentina and Uruguay. Carrinha\n\nPortuguese term for a station wagon. Not used in Brazilian Portuguese. Espada\n\nPortuguese nickname for a limousine (the same word for Sword - long piece of metal). Not used in Brazilian Portuguese. Furgoneta\n\nSpanish and Polish term for a van, in the latter language almost always used in its diminutive form furgonetka. Furgão\n\nPortuguese alternative term (less used) for a van. Used in Brazilian Portuguese, most often for vans but sometimes for panel van variants of passenger cars. Kombi\n\nis a German abbreviation of \"Kombinationswagen\" (Combination Car) and it is German name for station wagon. Since Germany is a major producer of cars for many European countries, the term Kombi in this meaning is also used in Swedish, Czech, Slovak, Polish, Slovenian, Serbian, Bosnian, Croatian, Hungarian, Spanish, Portuguese, Bulgarian. In Afrikaans and in Australia, Kombi is also used to refer to a Volkswagen Microbus. In Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay the word specifically refers to the VW Microbus. Perua\n\nBrazilian Portuguese term either designating a van (especially as spoken in the city of São Paulo) or a station wagon (in the city of Rio de Janeiro). Turismo\n\nSpanish term for a sedan. Literally means tourism, used mostly in Latin American countries and Spain. Ijapa\n\nYoruba term for a two door car. Literally modeled after a Tortoise animal. Also refers to Volkswagen Beetle. Vagoneta\n\nBolivian Spanish Colloquial term for a station wagon (with o without SUV capabilities).\n\nACRISS Car Classification Code Car color\n\nCar safety and road safety\n\nProduction vehicle\n\nThree-wheeler\n\nTruck classification\n\nVehicle category\n\nVehicle size class\n\n1. Board","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.530098},{"text":"car seats","sentiment":{"score":0.81644,"label":"positive"},"relevance":0.524161},{"text":"Folding seats","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.520769},{"text":"child seats","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.514277},{"text":"lumbar support Headrest","sentiment":{"score":0.36797,"label":"positive"},"relevance":0.513109},{"text":"adjustable lumbar cushion","sentiment":{"score":0.517397,"label":"positive"},"relevance":0.508499},{"text":"automobile seats","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.505877}]},"searchText":["no title\n\nCar seat\n\nA car seat is the seat used in automobiles. Most car seats are made from inexpensive but durable material in order to withstand prolonged use. The most common material is polyester.\n\n1 Bucket seat and bench seat 2 Folding seats\n\n3 Ergonomy: lumbar and thigh support\n\n4 Safety\n\n5 Power seats\n\n6 Covers\n\n7 Seat construction\n\n7.1 Parts 7.2 Adjustments\n\n8 Climate control and ventilation 9 See also 10 References\n\nA bucket seat is a separate seat with a contoured platform designed to accommodate one person, distinct from a bench seat that is a flat platform designed to seat up to three people. Individual bucket seats typically have rounded backs and may offer a variety of adjustments to fit diferent passengers.\n\nEarly touring cars featured folding auxiliary seats to offer additional passenger capacity.[1] Some early automobiles were available with an exterior rumble seat that folded open into an upholstered seat for one or two passengers.\n\nSome sedan models offer fold-down rear seats (e.g. Chevrolet Corvair), to gain cargo space when they are not occupied by passengers.\n\nA fold-down front-passenger seat was a feature on the Chrysler PT Cruiser to fit longer items such as a 8-foot (2.4 m) ladder inside the vehicle.[2]\n\nThe lumbar is the region of the spine between the diaphragm and the pelvis; it supports the most weight and is the most flexible. The adjustable lumbar mechanisms in seats allow the user to change the seat back shape in this region, to make it more comfortable and include adjustable lumbar cushion. Some seats are long enough to support full thigh and follow back curves.\n\nFront bucket seats in a BMW Alpina\n\nContents\n\nBucket seat and bench seat\n\nRear bench seat for three adult passengers in a AMC Ambassador\n\nFolding seats\n\nErgonomy: lumbar and thigh support\n\nThe National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act enacted by the U.S. in 1966 established standards of strength for automobile seats. These included requirements for proper anchorage and construction of automobile vehicle seat assemblies.[3] The legal requirements in some jurisdictions for a child to sit up front is 5\u00270 and they must weigh more than 80 lbs. Some studies have shown that drivers have an aversion towards carrying the full capacity amount of passengers due to concerns over insufficient vision through the back window.[4]\n\nAn anti-submarine seat is a kind of seat that incorporates specially shaped panels in the forward edge of the seat cushion, reducing the tendency for the occupant to slide beneath the seatbelt in a severe frontal collision. Anti-submarine seating is a safety feature that may be more important for the front seats than the rear seats.[5]\n\nA child safety seat or child restraint system is a restraint which is secured to the seat of an automobile equipped with safety harnesses or seat belts, to hold a child in the event of a crash. All 50 states require child seats with specific criteria. Requirements vary based on a child\u0027s age, weight and height. The National Child Passenger Safety Board, managed by the National Safety Council, maintains the quality and integrity of the National Child Passenger Safety Certification Training Program. The program is used to train and certify child passenger safety technicians and instructors in order to assist caregivers in safe transportation of children.[6]\n\nSide airbags are often built right into the side of the seat. Seats so equipped should not be covered which impedes the operation of the airbag.[7]\n\nSome car seat systems are set up with a battery-powered automatic control to adjust how the seat sits in the car.\n\nIn suitably equipped cars, seats and mirrors can be adjusted using electric controls. Some vehicles let the driver(s) save the adjustments in memory (memory seat) for later recall, with the push of a button. Most systems allow users to store more than one set of adjustments. This allows multiple drivers to store their comfort settings, or a single driver to store several different occupant positions. Some vehicles associate memorized settings with a specifically numbered, remotely operated key fob, resetting a seat to the position associated with that fob when the vehicle is unlocked (e.g. key fob #1 sets seats to memory position #1, #2 to #2, etc.).\n\nCar seat covers are accessories that protect the original seat upholstery from wear and add a custom look to a vehicle\u0027s interior. They can help to maintain the resale value of the vehicle and maximize the comfort of the driver and passengers.\n\nArmrest Backrest, with lumbar support Headrest\n\nSeat base Seat track\n\nAuxiliary folding seat in a 1921 Hudson Phaeton\n\nSafety\n\nPower seats\n\nThe power seat adjustments in a Lincoln Town Car. The seat controls are located on the door panels, next to the memory seat controls. Above the seat settings are the memory control settings that also set the mirrors and foot pedals.\n\nCovers\n\nSeat construction\n\nParts\n\nBackrest angle\n\nCushion edge\n\nFore-and-aft position\n\nHeadrest angle\n\nHeadrest level\n\nLumbar position\n\nSeat depth\n\nSeat height\n\nThe upper section of the seat backrest, may be tilted to the front for optimum, individual shoulder support\n\nVariable head support at the sides Cushion Tilt\n\nTurning Seat\n\nSome vehicles includes the option of seat climate control (i.e. heating by seat warmers) and ventilation. Ventilation was introduced in 1997 by Saab and heating by Cadillac in 1966.\n\n1. \"Recent Developments in Body Design\" (https://books.google.com/books?id\u003d02gfAQAAMAAJ\u0026pg\u003dPA261\u0026lpg\u003dPA2 61\u0026dq\u003dfolding+auxiliary+seats+touring+cars). Horseless Age: The Automobile Trade Magazine. 33 (6): 264. 11 February 1914. Retrieved 7 September 2014.\n\n2. Cullen, Cheryl Dangel; Haller, Lynn. Design Secrets: Products 2 (https://books.google.com/books?id\u003dhr6PizO4_uYC \u0026pg\u003dPA14\u0026lpg\u003dPA14\u0026dq\u003dPT+Cruiser+has+all+the+fun+and+jaw-dropping+exterior+cues+but+will+also+fit+an+8-f oot+(2.4+m)+stepladder+from+the+front+seat). Rockport Publishers. p. 14. ISBN 9781610596572. Retrieved 7 September 2014.\n\n3. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, U.S. Dept. of Transportation. 1985. pp. 50-51. Retrieved 7 September 2014.\n\n4. Vitito, Christopher J. \"For a motor vehicle, boat, or aircraft.\" U.S. Patent No. 5,775,762. 7 Jul. 1998.\n\n5. \"Question \u0027N\u0027 Auto\" (http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/iw/2005/09/25/stories/2005092500421500.htm). thehindubusinessline.com. 25 September 2005. Retrieved 7 September 2014.\n\n6. National Child Passenger Safety Board (http://cpsboard.org/)\n\n7. Turner, Brian. \"Your Corner Wrench: Seat covers and airbags do not mix\" (http://driving.ca/auto-news/news/your-cor ner-wrench-seat-covers-and-airbags-do-not-mix). The National Post. Retrieved 5 September 2017.\n\nRetrieved from \"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dCar_seat\u0026oldid\u003d799102181\"\n\nThis page was last edited on 5 September 2017, at 17:08.\n\nArmrest Cushion Ergonomics Folding seat\n\nHeadrest List of chairs Lumbar Massage chair\n\nSeat belt Sedentary lifestyle\n\nSheepskin cover Upholstery seat\n\nFully reclining front seat backs to form a bed in a 1954 Nash Ambassador\n\nSwiveling front seats to ease entry and exit in a 1960 Chrysler 300F\n\nAdjustments\n\nClimate control and ventilation\n\nSee also\n\nReferences\n\nText is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License; additional terms may apply. page was last edited on 5 September 2017, at 17:08.\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armrest\"\u003eArmres\u003c/a\u003et\n\u003ca bed in a 1954 Nash Ambassador\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eSwiveling front seats to ease entry and exit in a 1960 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysler_300_letter_series\"\u003eChrysler 300\u003c/a\u003eF\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAdjustments\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch2\u003e\u003cp\u003eClimate control and ventilation\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ch2\u003e\u003cp\u003eSee also\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ch2\u003e\u003cp\u003eReferences\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eText is available under the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Text_of_Creative_Commons_Attribution-ShareAlike_3.0_Unported_License\"\u003e Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike Licens\u003c/a\u003ee; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Terms_of_Use\"\u003e Terms of Use\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Privacy_policy\"\u003ePrivacy Polic\u003c/a\u003ey. Wikipedia((R)) is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003c/body\u003e\u003c/html\u003e","id":"c47053c53f61d89a87ee9f80c46cdb43","text":"no title\n\nCar seat\n\nA car seat is the seat used in automobiles. Most car seats are made from inexpensive but durable material in order to withstand prolonged use. The most common material is polyester.\n\n1 Bucket seat and bench seat 2 Folding seats\n\n3 Ergonomy: lumbar and thigh support\n\n4 Safety\n\n5 Power seats\n\n6 Covers\n\n7 Seat construction\n\n7.1 Parts 7.2 Adjustments\n\n8 Climate control and ventilation 9 See also 10 References\n\nA bucket seat is a separate seat with a contoured platform designed to accommodate one person, distinct from a bench seat that is a flat platform designed to seat up to three people. Individual bucket seats typically have rounded backs and may offer a variety of adjustments to fit diferent passengers.\n\nEarly touring cars featured folding auxiliary seats to offer additional passenger capacity.[1] Some early automobiles were available with an exterior rumble seat that folded open into an upholstered seat for one or two passengers.\n\nSome sedan models offer fold-down rear seats (e.g. Chevrolet Corvair), to gain cargo space when they are not occupied by passengers.\n\nA fold-down front-passenger seat was a feature on the Chrysler PT Cruiser to fit longer items such as a 8-foot (2.4 m) ladder inside the vehicle.[2]\n\nThe lumbar is the region of the spine between the diaphragm and the pelvis; it supports the most weight and is the most flexible. The adjustable lumbar mechanisms in seats allow the user to change the seat back shape in this region, to make it more comfortable and include adjustable lumbar cushion. Some seats are long enough to support full thigh and follow back curves.\n\nFront bucket seats in a BMW Alpina\n\nContents\n\nBucket seat and bench seat\n\nRear bench seat for three adult passengers in a AMC Ambassador\n\nFolding seats\n\nErgonomy: lumbar and thigh support\n\nThe National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act enacted by the U.S. in 1966 established standards of strength for automobile seats. These included requirements for proper anchorage and construction of automobile vehicle seat assemblies.[3] The legal requirements in some jurisdictions for a child to sit up front is 5\u00270 and they must weigh more than 80 lbs. Some studies have shown that drivers have an aversion towards carrying the full capacity amount of passengers due to concerns over insufficient vision through the back window.[4]\n\nAn anti-submarine seat is a kind of seat that incorporates specially shaped panels in the forward edge of the seat cushion, reducing the tendency for the occupant to slide beneath the seatbelt in a severe frontal collision. Anti-submarine seating is a safety feature that may be more important for the front seats than the rear seats.[5]\n\nA child safety seat or child restraint system is a restraint which is secured to the seat of an automobile equipped with safety harnesses or seat belts, to hold a child in the event of a crash. All 50 states require child seats with specific criteria. Requirements vary based on a child\u0027s age, weight and height. The National Child Passenger Safety Board, managed by the National Safety Council, maintains the quality and integrity of the National Child Passenger Safety Certification Training Program. The program is used to train and certify child passenger safety technicians and instructors in order to assist caregivers in safe transportation of children.[6]\n\nSide airbags are often built right into the side of the seat. Seats so equipped should not be covered which impedes the operation of the airbag.[7]\n\nSome car seat systems are set up with a battery-powered automatic control to adjust how the seat sits in the car.\n\nIn suitably equipped cars, seats and mirrors can be adjusted using electric controls. Some vehicles let the driver(s) save the adjustments in memory (memory seat) for later recall, with the push of a button. Most systems allow users to store more than one set of adjustments. This allows multiple drivers to store their comfort settings, or a single driver to store several different occupant positions. Some vehicles associate memorized settings with a specifically numbered, remotely operated key fob, resetting a seat to the position associated with that fob when the vehicle is unlocked (e.g. key fob #1 sets seats to memory position #1, #2 to #2, etc.).\n\nCar seat covers are accessories that protect the original seat upholstery from wear and add a custom look to a vehicle\u0027s interior. They can help to maintain the resale value of the vehicle and maximize the comfort of the driver and passengers.\n\nArmrest Backrest, with lumbar support Headrest\n\nSeat base Seat track\n\nAuxiliary folding seat in a 1921 Hudson Phaeton\n\nSafety\n\nPower seats\n\nThe power seat adjustments in a Lincoln Town Car. The seat controls are located on the door panels, next to the memory seat controls. Above the seat settings are the memory control settings that also set the mirrors and foot pedals.\n\nCovers\n\nSeat construction\n\nParts\n\nBackrest angle\n\nCushion edge\n\nFore-and-aft position\n\nHeadrest angle\n\nHeadrest level\n\nLumbar position\n\nSeat depth\n\nSeat height\n\nThe upper section of the seat backrest, may be tilted to the front for optimum, individual shoulder support\n\nVariable head support at the sides Cushion Tilt\n\nTurning Seat\n\nSome vehicles includes the option of seat climate control (i.e. heating by seat warmers) and ventilation. Ventilation was introduced in 1997 by Saab and heating by Cadillac in 1966.\n\n1. \"Recent Developments in Body Design\" (https://books.google.com/books?id\u003d02gfAQAAMAAJ\u0026pg\u003dPA261\u0026lpg\u003dPA2 61\u0026dq\u003dfolding+auxiliary+seats+touring+cars). of road vehicles","keywords":[{"text":"aerodynamics"},{"text":"road vehicles"},{"text":"study"}],"entities":[{"type":"Company","text":"Aircraft Research Center","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.709541},{"text":"Acura NSX","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.70753},{"text":"commonly published rating","sentiment":{"score":0.472701,"label":"positive"},"relevance":0.704605}]},"searchText":["no title\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics is the study of the aerodynamics of road vehicles. Its main goals are reducing drag and wind noise, minimizing noise emission, and preventing undesired lift forces and other causes of aerodynamic instability at high speeds. Air is also considered a fluid in this case. For some classes of racing vehicles, it may also be important to produce downforce to improve traction and thus cornering abilities.\n\n1 History\n\n2 Features of Aerodynamic Vehicles\n\n3 Comparison with Aircraft Aerodynamics\n\n4 Methods of Studying Aerodynamics\n\n5 Drag coefficient\n\n6 Downforce\n\n7 See also\n\n8 References\n\n9 External links\n\nThe frictional force of aerodynamic drag increases significantly with vehicle speed.[1] As early as the 1920s engineers began to consider automobile shape in reducing aerodynamic drag at higher speeds. By the 1950s German and British automotive engineers were systematically analyzing the effects of automotive drag for the higher performance vehicles.[2] By the late 1960s scientists also became aware of the significant increase in sound levels emitted by automobiles at high speed. These effects were understood to increase the intensity of sound levels for adjacent land uses at a non-linear rate.[3] Soon highway engineers began to design roadways to consider the speed effects of aerodynamic drag produced sound levels, and automobile manufacturers considered the same factors in vehicle design.\n\nAn aerodynamic automobile will integrate the wheel arcs and lights into the overall shape to reduce drag. It will be streamlined; for example, it does not have sharp edges crossing the wind stream above the windshield and will feature a sort of tail called a fastback or Kammback or liftback. Note that the Aptera 2e, the Loremo, and the Volkswagen 1-litre car try to reduce the area of their back. It will have a flat and smooth floor to support the Venturi effect and produce desirable downwards aerodynamic forces. The air that rams into the engine bay, is used for cooling, combustion, and for passengers, then reaccelerated by a nozzle and then ejected under the floor. For mid and rear engines air is decelerated and pressurized in a diffuser, loses some pressure as it passes the engine bay, and fills the slipstream. These cars need a seal between the low pressure region around the wheels and the high pressure around the gearbox. They all have a closed engine bay floor. The suspension is either streamlined (Aptera) or retracted. Door handles, the\n\nA truck with added bodywork on top of the cab to reduce drag.\n\nContents\n\nHistory\n\nFeatures of Aerodynamic Vehicles\n\nantenna, and roof rails can have a streamlined shape. The side mirror can only have a round fairing as a nose. Air flow through the wheel-bays is said to increase drag (German source) though race cars need it for brake cooling and many cars emit the air from the radiator into the wheel bay.\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics differs from aircraft aerodynamics in several ways. First, the characteristic shape of a road vehicle is much less streamlined compared to an aircraft. Second, the vehicle operates very close to the ground, rather than in free air. Third, the operating speeds are lower (and aerodynamic drag varies as the square of speed). Fourth, a ground vehicle has fewer degrees of freedom than an aircraft, and its motion is less affected by aerodynamic forces. Fifth, passenger and commercial ground vehicles have very specific design constraints such as their intended purpose, high safety standards (requiring, for example, more \u0027dead\u0027 structural space to act as crumple zones), and certain regulations.\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics is studied using both computer modelling and wind tunnel testing. For the most accurate results from a wind tunnel test, the tunnel is sometimes equipped with a rolling road. This is a movable floor for the working section, which moves at the same speed as the air flow. This prevents a boundary layer from forming on the floor of the working section and affecting the results. An example of such a rolling road wind tunnel is Wind Shear\u0027s Full Scale, Rolling Road, Automotive Wind Tunnel in Concord, North Carolina and Auto Research Center in Indianapolis, Indiana USA.\n\nDrag coefficient (Cd) is a commonly published rating of a car\u0027s aerodynamic smoothness, related to the shape of the car. Multiplying Cd by the car\u0027s frontal area gives an index of total drag. The result is called drag area, and is listed below for several cars. The width and height of curvy cars lead to gross overestimation of frontal area. These numbers use the manufacturer\u0027s frontal area specifications from the Mayfield Company unless noted.[4]\n\nSome examples:\n\nComparison with Aircraft Aerodynamics\n\nMethods of Studying Aerodynamics\n\nOne of the side efects of automotive aerodynamics is seed dispersal.\n\nPlay media\n\nDrag coefficient\n\nDrag area ( C d x Ft2) Year Automobile\n\n3.0 sq ft\n\n(0.28 m2) 2012 Land RoverDefender 90\n\n18.06 1993 Hummer H1\n\n20.24 1993 Land RoverDefender 110\n\n26.32 2006 Hummer H2\n\nDownforce describes the downward pressure created by the aerodynamic characteristics of a car that allows it to travel faster through a corner by holding the car to the track or road surface. Some elements to increase vehicle downforce will also increase drag. It is very important to produce a good downward aerodynamic force because it affects the car\u0027s speed and traction.[6]\n\nDownforce\n\n1.
