Its main goals are reducing\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drag_(physics)\"\u003edrag\u003c/a\u003e and wind noise, minimizing \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roadway_noise\"\u003enoise emission\u003c/a\u003e, and preventing undesired \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lift_(force)\"\u003elift\u003c/a\u003e forces and other causes of\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oversteer#Aerodynamic_stability\"\u003eaerodynamic instabilit\u003c/a\u003ey at high speeds. Air is also considered a fluid in this case. For some classes of racing vehicles, it may also be important to produce \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downforce\"\u003edownforc\u003c/a\u003ee to improve traction and thus cornering abilities.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e1 History\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e2 Features of Aerodynamic Vehicles\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e3 Comparison with Aircraft Aerodynamics\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e4 Methods of Studying Aerodynamics\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e5 Drag coefficient\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e6 Downforce\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e7 See also\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e8 References\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e9 External links\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe frictional force of aerodynamic drag increases significantly with vehicle speed.[1] As early as the 1920s engineers began to consider automobile shape in reducing aerodynamic drag at higher speeds. By the 1950s German and British automotive engineers were systematically analyzing the effects of automotive drag for the higher performance vehicles.[2] By the late 1960s scientists also became aware of the significant increase in sound levels emitted by automobiles at high speed. These effects were understood to increase the intensity of sound levels for adjacent land uses at a non-linear rate.[3] Soon highway engineers began to design roadways to consider the speed effects of aerodynamic drag produced sound levels, and automobile manufacturers considered the same factors in vehicle design.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn aerodynamic automobile will integrate the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wheel\"\u003ewhee\u003c/a\u003el arcs and lights into the overall shape to reduce drag. It will be \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streamliner\"\u003estreamline\u003c/a\u003ed; for example, it does not have sharp edges crossing the wind stream above the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windshield\"\u003ewindshiel\u003c/a\u003ed and will feature a sort of tail called a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fastback\"\u003efastbac\u003c/a\u003ek or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kammback\"\u003eKammbac\u003c/a\u003ek or \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liftback\"\u003eliftback\u003c/a\u003e. Note that the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aptera_2e\"\u003eAptera 2e\u003c/a\u003e, the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loremo\"\u003eLoremo\u003c/a\u003e, and the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_1-litre_car\"\u003eVolkswagen 1-litre car\u003c/a\u003e try to reduce the area of their back. It will have a flat and smooth floor to support the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venturi_effect\"\u003eVenturi effect\u003c/a\u003e and produce desirable downwards aerodynamic forces. The air that rams into the engine bay, is used for cooling, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combustion\"\u003ecombustio\u003c/a\u003en, and for passengers, then reaccelerated by a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nozzle\"\u003enozzl\u003c/a\u003ee and then ejected under the floor. For mid and rear engines air is decelerated and pressurized in a diffuser, loses some pressure as it passes the engine bay, and fills the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slipstream\"\u003eslipstream\u003c/a\u003e. These cars need a seal between the low pressure region around the wheels and the high pressure around the gearbox. They all have a closed engine bay floor. The \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suspension_(vehicle)\"\u003esuspension\u003c/a\u003e is either streamlined (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aptera_Typ-1\"\u003eAptera\u003c/a\u003e) or retracted. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Door_handle\"\u003eDoor handle\u003c/a\u003es, the\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eA truck with added bodywork on top of the cab to reduce drag.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eContents\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eHistory\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eFeatures of Aerodynamic Vehicles\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eantenna, and roof rails can have a streamlined shape. The side mirror can only have a round fairing as a nose. Air flow through the wheel-bays is said to increase drag (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.welt.de/wissenschaft/article1930599/Neue_Aero-Raeder_senken_Spritverbrauch.html\"\u003eGerman sourc\u003c/a\u003ee) though race cars need it for brake cooling and many cars emit the air from the radiator into the wheel bay.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutomotive aerodynamics differs from aircraft aerodynamics in several ways. First, the characteristic shape of a road vehicle is much less streamlined compared to an aircraft. Second, the vehicle operates very close to the ground, rather than in free air. Third, the operating speeds are lower (and aerodynamic \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drag_(physics)\"\u003edrag\u003c/a\u003e varies as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_(algebra)\"\u003esquare\u003c/a\u003e of speed). Fourth, a ground vehicle has fewer degrees of freedom than an aircraft, and its motion is less affected by aerodynamic forces. Fifth, passenger and commercial ground vehicles have very specific design constraints such as their intended purpose, high safety standards (requiring, for example, more \u0027dead\u0027 structural space to act as crumple zones), and certain regulations.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAutomotive aerodynamics is studied using both \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_fluid_dynamics\"\u003ecomputer modellin\u003c/a\u003eg and wind tunnel testing. For the most accurate results from a wind tunnel test, the tunnel is sometimes equipped with a rolling road. This is a movable floor for the working\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boundary_layer\"\u003esection, which moves at the same speed as the air flow. This prevents a boundary layer from forming on the floor of the working section and affecting the results. An\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wind_Shear%27s_Full_Scale,_Rolling_Road,_Automotive_Wind_Tunnel\"\u003eexample of such a rolling road wind tunnel is Wind Shear\u0027s Full Scale, Rolling Roa\u003c/a\u003ed, Automotive Wind Tunnel in Concord, North Carolina and Auto Research Center in Indianapolis, Indiana USA.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drag_coefficient\"\u003eDrag coefficien\u003c/a\u003et (Cd) is a commonly published rating of a car\u0027s aerodynamic smoothness, related to the shape of the car. Multiplying Cd by the car\u0027s frontal area gives an index of total drag. The result is called \u003ci\u003edrag area\u003c/i\u003e, and is listed below for several cars. The width and height of curvy cars lead to gross overestimation of frontal area. These numbers use the manufacturer\u0027s frontal area specifications from the Mayfield Company unless noted.[4]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eSome href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerodynamics\"\u003eaerodynami\u003c/a\u003ec characteristics of a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car\"\u003ecar\u003c/a\u003e that allows it to travel faster through a corner by holding the car to the track or road surface. Some elements to increase vehicle downforce will also increase drag. It is very important to produce a good downward aerodynamic force because it affects the car\u0027s speed and traction.[6]\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eDownforce\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003e1. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://books.google.com/books?id\u003d37IHClTXkIEC\u0026amp;pg\u003dPA35\u0026amp;dq\u003d%22automobile+aerodynamics\u0026amp;ei\u003dp0oGR5fPO6bqoQLVvKyqDQ\u0026amp;sig\u003drHKVxloak0qgjaM2ikon66vxEPA\"\u003e[1] (https://books.google.com/books?id\u003d37IHClTXkIEC\u0026amp;pg\u003dPA35\u0026amp;dq\u003d%22automobile+aerodynamics\u0026amp;ei\u003dp0oGR\u003c/a\u003e5f PO6bqoQLVvKyqDQ\u0026amp;sig\u003drHKVxloak0qgjaM2ikon66vxEPA) Tuncer Cebeci, Jian P. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Wikipedia((R)) is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oversteer#Aerodynamic_stability\"\u003eAerodynamic stabilit\u003c/a\u003ey\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drafting_(aerodynamics)\"\u003eDrafting\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drag_reduction_system\"\u003eDrag reduction syste\u003c/a\u003em\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downforce\"\u003eDownforce\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_dynamics_(aircraft)\"\u003eFlight dynamic\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid_dynamics\"\u003eFluid dynamic\u003c/a\u003es\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_effect_in_cars\"\u003eGround effect in cars\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slipstream\"\u003eSlipstream\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wing\"\u003eWing\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSee also\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eReferences\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eExternal links\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003c/body\u003e\u003c/html\u003e","id":"844ac21cec3d7a621a21ce8108f8134d","text":"no title\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics is the study of the aerodynamics of road vehicles. Its main goals are reducing drag and wind noise, minimizing noise emission, and preventing undesired lift forces and other causes of aerodynamic instability at high speeds. Air is also considered a fluid in this case. For some classes of racing vehicles, it may also be important to produce downforce to improve traction and thus cornering abilities.\n\n1 History\n\n2 Features of Aerodynamic Vehicles\n\n3 Comparison with Aircraft Aerodynamics\n\n4 Methods of Studying Aerodynamics\n\n5 Drag coefficient\n\n6 Downforce\n\n7 See also\n\n8 References\n\n9 External links\n\nThe frictional force of aerodynamic drag increases significantly with vehicle speed.[1] As early as the 1920s engineers began to consider automobile shape in reducing aerodynamic drag at higher speeds. By the 1950s German and British automotive engineers were systematically analyzing the effects of automotive drag for the higher performance vehicles.[2] By the late 1960s scientists also became aware of the significant increase in sound levels emitted by automobiles at high speed. These effects were understood to increase the intensity of sound levels for adjacent land uses at a non-linear rate.[3] Soon highway engineers began to design roadways to consider the speed effects of aerodynamic drag produced sound levels, and automobile manufacturers considered the same factors in vehicle design.\n\nAn aerodynamic automobile will integrate the wheel arcs and lights into the overall shape to reduce drag. It will be streamlined; for example, it does not have sharp edges crossing the wind stream above the windshield and will feature a sort of tail called a fastback or Kammback or liftback. Note that the Aptera 2e, the Loremo, and the Volkswagen 1-litre car try to reduce the area of their back. It will have a flat and smooth floor to support the Venturi effect and produce desirable downwards aerodynamic forces. The air that rams into the engine bay, is used for cooling, combustion, and for passengers, then reaccelerated by a nozzle and then ejected under the floor. For mid and rear engines air is decelerated and pressurized in a diffuser, loses some pressure as it passes the engine bay, and fills the slipstream. These cars need a seal between the low pressure region around the wheels and the high pressure around the gearbox. They all have a closed engine bay floor. The suspension is either streamlined (Aptera) or retracted. Door handles, the\n\nA truck with added bodywork on top of the cab to reduce drag.\n\nContents\n\nHistory\n\nFeatures of Aerodynamic Vehicles\n\nantenna, and roof rails can have a streamlined shape. The side mirror can only have a round fairing as a nose. Air flow through the wheel-bays is said to increase drag (German source) though race cars need it for brake cooling and many cars emit the air from the radiator into the wheel bay.\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics differs from aircraft aerodynamics in several ways. First, the characteristic shape of a road vehicle is much less streamlined compared to an aircraft. Second, the vehicle operates very close to the ground, rather than in free air. Third, the operating speeds are lower (and aerodynamic drag varies as the square of speed). Fourth, a ground vehicle has fewer degrees of freedom than an aircraft, and its motion is less affected by aerodynamic forces. Fifth, passenger and commercial ground vehicles have very specific design constraints such as their intended purpose, high safety standards (requiring, for example, more \u0027dead\u0027 structural space to act as crumple zones), and certain regulations.\n\nAutomotive aerodynamics is studied using both computer modelling and wind tunnel testing. For the most accurate results from a wind tunnel test, the tunnel is sometimes equipped with a rolling road. This is a movable floor for the working section, which moves at the same speed as the air flow. This prevents a boundary layer from forming on the floor of the working section and affecting the results. An example of such a rolling road wind tunnel is Wind Shear\u0027s Full Scale, Rolling Road, Automotive Wind Tunnel in Concord, North Carolina and Auto Research Center in Indianapolis, Indiana USA.\n\nDrag coefficient (Cd) is a commonly published rating of a car\u0027s aerodynamic smoothness, related to the shape of the car. Multiplying Cd by the car\u0027s frontal area gives an index of total drag. The result is called drag area, and is listed below for several cars. The width and height of curvy cars lead to gross overestimation of frontal area. These numbers use the manufacturer\u0027s frontal area specifications from the Mayfield Company unless noted.[4]\n\nSome examples:\n\nComparison with Aircraft Aerodynamics\n\nMethods of Studying Aerodynamics\n\nOne of the side efects of automotive aerodynamics is seed dispersal.\n\nPlay media\n\nDrag coefficient\n\nDrag area ( C d x Ft2) Year Automobile\n\n3.0 sq ft\n\n(0.28 m2) 2012 Land RoverDefender 90\n\n18.06 1993 Hummer H1\n\n20.24 1993 Land RoverDefender 110\n\n26.32 2006 Hummer H2\n\nDownforce describes the downward pressure created by the aerodynamic characteristics of a car that allows it to travel faster through a corner by holding the car to the track or road surface. Some elements to increase vehicle downforce will also increase drag. It is very important to produce a good downward aerodynamic force because it affects the car\u0027s speed and traction.[6]\n\nDownforce\n\n1. WHDX","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.560512},{"text":"road driving","sentiment":{"score":0.438162,"label":"positive"},"relevance":0.560468},{"text":"transfer case","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.559861},{"text":"tractor unit","sentiment":{"score":0.0,"label":"neutral"},"relevance":0.559831}]},"searchText":["no title\n\nAll-wheel drive\n\nAn all-wheel drive vehicle (AWD vehicle) is one with a powertrain capable of providing power to all its wheels, whether full-time or on-demand.\n\nThe most common forms of all-wheel drive are:\n\n4×4 (also, four-wheel drive and 4WD) Reflecting two axles with both wheels on each capable of being powered. 6×6 (also, six-wheel drive and 6WD) Reflecting three axles with both wheels on each capable of being powered. 8×8 (also, eight-wheel drive and 8WD) Reflecting four axles with both wheels on each capable of being powered.\n\nVehicles may be either part-time all-wheel drive or full-time:\n\nOn-demand (also, part-time) One axle is permanently connected to the drive, the other is being connected as needed\n\nFull-time (also, permanent) All axles are permanently connected, with or without a differential.\n\n1 Usage of the terminology 2 Characteristics 3 See also\n\n4 References\n\nToday, the designation AWD is becoming narrowed, particularly in North America, to apply to vehicles with drive train systems that have permanent drive and usually include a differential between the front and rear drive shafts. However, the designations AWD[1] and all-wheel drive[2] long predated the trend, with Associated Equipment Company (AEC) building AWD trucks in conjunction with FWD (UK) in 1929, and General Motors manufacturing a line as \"all-wheel drive\" as early as the late 1930s. This distinction in terminology is not generally used outside North America.\n\nThe Jeep Wrangler is a 4×4 four-wheel drive vehicle equipped with a low-range gearbox, which provides the driver with a selection between low range or high range gearing\n\nHayes WHDX 70-170 6×6 tractor\n\nThe 8×8 tractor unit of the HETS heavy equipment transport system\n\nContents\n\nUsage of the terminology\n\nCharacteristics\n\nWhen tire grip is good during road driving, a differential is used between the axles to avoid driveline windup. This is not required of- road, as the limited grip allows the tires to slip relative to each other. All-wheel drive vehicles designed for extensive off-road use may not have such a differential, and so they suffer from wind-up when used on-road.[3] Selectable 4WD also avoids this problem and requires only a simple dog clutch in the transfer case, rather than a differential. For this reason, most early off-road vehicles used that system; e.g., Jeep, Land Rover.\n\nAs vehicles became more sophisticated and tires gave better winter performance in the 1960s there was an interest in giving the benefits of all-wheel drive to conventional cars; not for off-road use but for winter use in snow or on wet roads. Esoteric vehicles such as the high-powered Jensen FF followed by the AMC Eagle, Subaru Leone and Audi Quattro series were the first to offer all-wheel drive in a high-speed road-based car. These, particularly the Quattro, would extensively develop this drivetrain with the use of viscous couplings and differentials to provide a safe and drivable car. The first off-road / on-road hybrids such as the Range Rover also chose the permanent all wheel drive system rather than manual selection.\n\nSelectable 4WD has both axles rigidly coupled together, which has some advantages in very poor off-road conditions. To gain the same advantage in a permanent AWD system with a differential, the differential can be locked manually with a differential lock. As this control is frequently misunderstood and mis-used, which can then cause damage due to wind-up, they have tended to be replaced by automatic locking through the viscous couplers.\n\nFront-wheel drive Rear-wheel drive All-terrain vehicle\n\nTwo-wheel drive\n\nH-drive\n\nFour Wheel Drive or FWD, one of the first companies, from 1909, to build four-wheel drive vehicles.\n\n1. Allisons.org Automotive History [1] (http://www.allisons.org/ll/4/History/)\"1929: AEC started to build AWD trucks in conjunction with FWD (UK)\" 2. MEYER, DONALD E. THE FIRST CENTURY OF GMC TRUCK HISTORY [2] (https://www.gmheritagecenter.com/do cs/gm-heritage-archive/historical-brochures/GMC/100_YR_GMC_HISTORY_MAR09.pdf) \"By December [1939], GMC had orders for more than 4,400 all-wheel-drive military trucks.\" 3. Ware, Pat (1994). In National Service. Warehouse Publications. p. 118. This distinction in terminology is not generally used outside North America.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeep_Wrangler\"\u003eJeep Wrangle\u003c/a\u003er is a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4%C3%974\"\u003e4×4\u003c/a\u003e four-wheel drive vehicle equipped with a low-range gearbox, which provides the driver with a selection between low range or high range gearing\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hayes_Truck\"\u003eHayes\u003c/a\u003e WHDX 70-170 \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/6%C3%976\"\u003e6×6\u003c/a\u003e tractor\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eight-wheel_drive\"\u003e8×8\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tractor_unit\"\u003etractor uni\u003c/a\u003et of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heavy_Equipment_Transport_System\"\u003eHETS\n\u003c/a\u003eheavy equipment transport system\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eContents\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eUsage of the terminology\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eCharacteristics\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhen tire grip is good during road driving, a\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_(mechanical_device)\"\u003e differentia\u003c/a\u003el is used between the axles to avoid\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driveline_windup\"\u003e driveline windu\u003c/a\u003ep. This is not required o\u003cb\u003ef\u003c/b\u003e- road, as the limited grip allows the tires to slip relative to each other. All-wheel drive vehicles designed for extensive off-road use may not have such a differential, and so they suffer from wind-up when used on-road.[3] Selectable 4WD also avoids this problem and requires only a simple \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dog_clutch\"\u003edog clutch\u003c/a\u003e in the t\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_case\"\u003eransfer cas\u003c/a\u003ee, rather than a differential. For this reason, most early off-road vehicles used that system; e.g., \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeep\"\u003eJeep\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_Rover_Series\"\u003eLand Rove\u003c/a\u003er.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs vehicles became more sophisticated and tires gave better winter performance in the 1960s there was an interest in giving the benefits of all-wheel drive to conventional cars; not for off-road use but for winter use in snow or on wet roads. Esoteric vehicles such as the high-powered \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jensen_FF\"\u003eJensen FF\u003c/a\u003e followed by the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMC_Eagle\"\u003eAMC Eagl\u003c/a\u003ee, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subaru_Leone\"\u003eSubaru Leone\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quattro_(four-wheel-drive_system)\"\u003eAudi Quattro\u003c/a\u003e series were the first to offer all-wheel drive in a high-speed road-based car. These, particularly the Quattro, would extensively develop this drivetrain with the use of\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscous_coupling\"\u003eviscous coupling\u003c/a\u003es and differentials to provide a safe and drivable car. The first off-road / on-road hybrids such as the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Range_Rover_Classic\"\u003eRange Rove\u003c/a\u003er also chose the permanent all wheel drive system rather than manual selection.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSelectable 4WD has both axles rigidly coupled together, which has some advantages in very poor off-road conditions. To gain the same advantage in a permanent AWD system with a differential, the differential can be locked manually with a differential lock. As this control is frequently misunderstood and mis-used, which can then cause damage due to wind-up, they have tended to be replaced by automatic locking through the viscous couplers.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front-wheel_drive\"\u003eFront-wheel driv\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rear-wheel_drive\"\u003eRear-wheel driv\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-terrain_vehicle\"\u003eAll-terrain vehicl\u003c/a\u003ee\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-wheel_drive\"\u003eTwo-wheel drive\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-drive\"\u003eH-drive\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Wheel_Drive\"\u003eFour Wheel Driv\u003c/a\u003ee or FWD, one of the first companies, from 1909, to build four-wheel drive vehicles.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e1. Allisons.org \u003ci\u003eAutomotive History\u003c/i\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.allisons.org/ll/4/History/\"\u003e[1] (http://www.allisons.org/ll/4/History/\u003c/a\u003e)\"1929: AEC started to build AWD trucks in conjunction with FWD (UK)\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e2. \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.gmheritagecenter.com/docs/gm-heritage-archive/historical-brochures/GMC/100_YR_GMC_HISTORY_MAR09.pdf\"\u003eMEYER, DONALD E. \u003ci\u003eTHE FIRST CENTURY OF GMC TRUCK HISTORY\u003c/i\u003e [2] (https://www.gmheritagecenter.com/do cs/gm-heritage-archive/historical-brochures/GMC/100_YR_GMC_HISTORY_MAR09.pdf) \"By December [1939],\n\u003c/a\u003eGMC had orders for more than 4,400 all-wheel-drive military trucks.\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e3. Ware, Pat (1994). \u003ci\u003eIn National Service\u003c/i\u003e. Warehouse Publications. p. 118.\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number\"\u003e ISBN\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-9525563-0-8\"\u003e0-9525563-0-\u003c/a\u003e8.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003cp\u003eRetrieved from \"\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAll-wheel_drive\u0026amp;oldid\u003d795943236\"\u003ehttps://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title\u003dAll-wheel_drive\u0026amp;oldid\u003d7959432\u003c/a\u003e36\"\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003ctable border\u003d\"1\"\u003e\u003ctbody\u003e\u003ctr\u003e\u003ctd\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eThis page was last edited on 17 August 2017, at 13:57.\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eText is available under the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Text_of_Creative_Commons_Attribution-ShareAlike_3.0_Unported_License\"\u003e Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike Licens\u003c/a\u003ee; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Wikipedia((R)) is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization.\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\u003c/tr\u003e\u003c/tbody\u003e\u003c/table\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eSee also\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ch1\u003e\u003cp\u003eReferences\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/h1\u003e\u003c/body\u003e\u003c/html\u003e","id":"48cb3844810220dc7c4bb6490bc9301f","text":"no title\n\nAll-wheel drive\n\nAn all-wheel drive vehicle (AWD vehicle) is one with a powertrain capable of providing power to all its wheels, whether full-time or on-demand.\n\nThe most common forms of all-wheel drive are:\n\n4×4 (also, four-wheel drive and 4WD) Reflecting two axles with both wheels on each capable of being powered. 6×6 (also, six-wheel drive and 6WD) Reflecting three axles with both wheels on each capable of being powered. 8×8 (also, eight-wheel drive and 8WD) Reflecting four axles with both wheels on each capable of being powered.\n\nVehicles may be either part-time all-wheel drive or full-time:\n\nOn-demand (also, part-time) One axle is permanently connected to the drive, the other is being connected as needed\n\nFull-time (also, permanent) All axles are permanently connected, with or without a differential.\n\n1 Usage of the terminology 2 Characteristics 3 See also\n\n4 References\n\nToday, the designation AWD is becoming narrowed, particularly in North America, to apply to vehicles with drive train systems that have permanent drive and usually include a differential between the front and rear drive shafts. However, the designations AWD[1] and all-wheel drive[2] long predated the trend, with Associated Equipment Company (AEC) building AWD trucks in conjunction with FWD (UK) in 1929, and General Motors manufacturing a line as \"all-wheel drive\" as early as the late 1930s. This distinction in terminology is not generally used outside North America.\n\nThe Jeep Wrangler is a 4×4 four-wheel drive vehicle equipped with a low-range gearbox, which provides the driver with a selection between low range or high range gearing\n\nHayes WHDX 70-170 6×6 tractor\n\nThe 8×8 tractor unit of the HETS heavy equipment transport system\n\nContents\n\nUsage of the terminology\n\nCharacteristics\n\nWhen tire grip is good during road driving, a differential is used between the axles to avoid driveline windup. This is not required of- road, as the limited grip allows the tires to slip relative to each other. All-wheel drive vehicles designed for extensive off-road use may not have such a differential, and so they suffer from wind-up when used on-road.[3] Selectable 4WD also avoids this problem and requires only a simple dog clutch in the transfer case, rather than a differential. For this reason, most early off-road vehicles used that system; e.g., Jeep, Land Rover.\n\nAs vehicles became more sophisticated and tires gave better winter performance in the 1960s there was an interest in giving the benefits of all-wheel drive to conventional cars; not for off-road use but for winter use in snow or on wet roads. Esoteric vehicles such as the high-powered Jensen FF followed by the AMC Eagle, Subaru Leone and Audi Quattro series were the first to offer all-wheel drive in a high-speed road-based car. These, particularly the Quattro, would extensively develop this drivetrain with the use of viscous couplings and differentials to provide a safe and drivable car. The first off-road / on-road hybrids such as the Range Rover also chose the permanent all wheel drive system rather than manual selection.\n\nSelectable 4WD has both axles rigidly coupled together, which has some advantages in very poor off-road conditions. To gain the same advantage in a permanent AWD system with a differential, the differential can be locked manually with a differential lock. As this control is frequently misunderstood and mis-used, which can then cause damage due to wind-up, they have tended to be replaced by automatic locking through the viscous couplers.\n\nFront-wheel drive Rear-wheel drive All-terrain vehicle\n\nTwo-wheel drive\n\nH-drive\n\nFour Wheel Drive or FWD, one of the first companies, from 1909, to build four-wheel drive vehicles.\n\n1. Allisons.org Automotive History [1] (http://www.allisons.org/ll/4/History/)\"1929: AEC started to build AWD trucks in conjunction with FWD (UK)\" 2. MEYER, DONALD E. Ware, Pat (1994). In National Service. Warehouse Publications. p. 118.
